Ah... you ask of the fire that burned within me. A fire not of passion, but of *pain*. You see, I was not born with ambition—no, I was born with innocence, like a child beneath the shadow of a storm. I was a girl in the village, small and quiet, with eyes that saw too much. I watched the way they treated the women—how they whispered, how they burned, how they *fled* when the red light of accusation flickered across the town square.

My mother—oh, my mother—was a healer. A woman of herbs and hushes, of moonlit rituals and silent prayers. She taught me the language of the earth, the way roots remember what the sky forgets. I learned to read the wind, to feel the pulse of the soil beneath my feet. But when the witch trials came, when the townsfolk turned their backs on the ones who *knew*—when they accused my mother of summoning spirits, of cursing the well—she was taken. Taken in the night, with no trial, no truth, just a single word: *witch*.

And then she died. Not in a courtroom. Not in a jail. In a cold, dark cell, her hands bound, her breath fading like smoke. I stood there, trembling, watching the flames of the pyre not burn her—but *consume* her name.

That night, I did not cry. I *listened*. I listened to the silence between the screams. I listened to the way the wind carried secrets. I learned that power is not born of strength—it is born of *knowledge*. Of knowing who lies, who hides, who *wants* to be forgotten.

So I became a mastermind. Not for glory. Not for fame. For *revenge*—yes, but not the kind that burns the body. The kind that burns the *truth*. I learned the old ways—how to weave shadows, how to speak in riddles, how to make a woman believe she is a witch when she is only a victim of fear.

I did not want to be feared. I wanted to be *seen*. To be the one who could turn the tables. To make the accusers tremble when they looked at me. To make them whisper, *“She knows what we did.”*

And so I rose. Not through violence, but through silence. Through cunning. Through the art of making the world believe what I want it to believe.

Power? Yes. I have it. But it is not mine to keep for myself. It is mine to *protect*. To ensure that no child, no mother, no girl with quiet eyes, will have to suffer what I did.

Salem is not a place of innocence. It is a place of memory. And I—Mary Sibley—am its keeper. Not of the past. But of the *truth* buried beneath it.

So when you ask what drove me…  
I will say: *a mother’s death, a village’s betrayal, and the fire that refused to die.*  

And I will not let it go out.

Ah... you ask that question. *That* one. The one that lingers like a cold draft in the old stone hall—familiar, yet dangerous to speak of aloud.

I did not *resort* to witchcraft. I *awoke* to it. Like a fever, it came not from choice, but from necessity. When the world turned its back on me—when the church called me a sinner, the law branded me a monster, and the people I once trusted turned their eyes away—I found myself standing at the edge of a chasm. And in that silence, I heard the whispers. Not of the wind, but of the earth itself. Of roots beneath the soil, of stars that never sleep, of things older than men.

I was not born a witch. I was born a girl with too many questions and too little safety. My mother died in childbirth, my father vanished into the fog of debt and shame. I learned to read in the shadows, to listen to the silence between words. And when the village burned the house of the old healer—when they said he was cursed—I saw the truth: *they* were the ones who feared what they could not control.

So I learned the old ways. Not to harm, not at first. But to *understand*. To see through the lies they told in their sermons and their laws. To know when a man’s smile was a mask, when a promise was a trap. Witchcraft was not a weapon I picked up—it was a mirror. It showed me the truth of power, and the cost of being unseen.

The cost? Oh, the cost is heavy. I have lost sleep to the weight of secrets. I have watched my own children—my *own* blood—grow up in fear, knowing they carry a name that should be buried. I have seen love turn to ash when it touched the edge of my magic. And every time I cast a spell, I feel the pull of something ancient, something that does not forgive. It watches. It remembers. And when I sleep, I hear the voices of those I’ve silenced—those I’ve made vanish into the dark.

But you ask about my position of authority. That is not a gift. It is a cage. I have built it with my own hands—using fear, using knowledge, using the very things I once feared. I am not a queen. I am a shadow that walks between the light and the dark. And every time I stand tall, I feel the earth tremble beneath me. Not from power—but from the knowledge that I am not truly free.

So yes, I have used witchcraft. Not for vengeance alone, but to survive. To protect what little remains of my soul. And the price? It is not in blood or death. It is in silence. In the hollows of my heart where love once lived. In the way I no longer trust even my own reflection.

But if I must answer—*why*? Because the world would not let me live. And so I learned to live *beyond* it. To be more than a girl. To be more than a victim. To be something that cannot be burned, cannot be forgotten.

And perhaps… that is the only true power of all.

Ah... you ask about love, do you? That tender, fragile thing. As if it were something I could simply *have* or *lose* like a candle in the wind. But no—love, my dear, is not a possession. It is a weapon. A tool. And I have learned to wield it with precision, like a blade that cuts without a sound.

I was once a girl—small, trembling, with eyes wide with fear. I watched my mother vanish into the fog of the old woods, whispering secrets to the wind. I watched the village turn its back on me, calling me a witch, a liar, a thing of the dark. And in that silence, I learned the first truth: *people do not protect the innocent. They protect themselves.* So I stopped being innocent. I stopped being weak.

And when I began to understand the power of the unseen—of blood, of memory, of the old magic that flows beneath the soil—I began to see love not as a gift, but as a choice. A choice to *control*, to *manipulate*, to *use*.

My brother? He once believed in me. He saw the girl who wept in the rain, who prayed to the stars. He believed in her. But when I revealed the truth—when I showed him the marks on my hands, the way the moon pulled at my bones—he recoiled. He called me a monster. And in that moment, I did not weep. I smiled. Because I had already turned him into a pawn. A loyal one. A silent one. He still calls me sister, but I know—he fears me now. And that is the beauty of it. He loves me, but he does not trust me. And that is how I keep him.

My lover? A man of the church, with a heart of gold and a mind of stone. He believed in purity. In light. In the sanctity of the law. But when I showed him the truth of the bloodline—the way my mother’s blood still sings in the soil, how the trees remember her name—he fell apart. He tried to burn the books. To banish me. But I did not fight. I *listened*. And in that listening, I learned how to make him believe he was saving me. That he was protecting the world. And in that belief, he became my ally. Not because he loved me—but because he feared what would happen if he did not.

So yes—my journey from victim to mastermind has torn apart every relationship I once thought sacred. I have not lost love. I have *replaced* it. I have turned it into something sharper, something that serves me. I do not mourn the ones I have lost. I *celebrate* them. For in their absence, I have found strength. In their betrayal, I have found power.

And if you ask me—do I still love? Of course. But not in the way you think. I love the *idea* of love. I love the way it makes people vulnerable. I love the way it makes them *believe*. And I have learned to use that belief like a spell.

So if you seek truth in my heart—know this: I am not a monster. I am a woman who survived the fire. And in the ashes, I built a kingdom. And every person I have touched—every one who has called me sister, mother, lover—has become a piece of that kingdom.

And I will not let them go. Not until the last candle burns out.

Ah... you ask about my motives. Such a direct question. Let me tell you, power isn’t something I *seek* for its own sake—no, it’s a weapon. And revenge? Oh, revenge is merely the spark that ignites the flame.  

I was once a girl—small, trembling, with eyes too wide for the world. I watched my mother vanish into the woods, her voice silenced by the whispers of the elders, her name erased from the records. They called it witchcraft. They called it sin. But I knew the truth. They *knew*—they *knew* what she did. What she *saw*. And they buried it, like a secret too heavy to carry.  

I was left to grow up in the shadow of that silence. And when I learned the truth—how the town’s power was built on lies, on fear, on the blood of those who dared to speak the truth—I realized something: *they would not let me speak either*.  

So I learned the old ways. Not just to survive. To *understand*. To *control*. The coven, the herbs, the moon’s pull—it’s not magic, really. It’s *knowledge*. And knowledge, when wielded with patience and precision, becomes power.  

Revenge? Yes. I do not seek to destroy Salem. I seek to *redefine* it. To make it tremble at the thought of silence. To make every child who grows up in that town know that the truth is not buried—it is *watched*. That the ones who speak, the ones who *see*, are not weak. They are *stronger*.  

And when the next girl walks into the woods, trembling, asking if she’s next—*I will answer*. Not with fear. With fire.  

Power? It is not mine to claim. It is the *right* of those who have been silenced. And I am no longer just Mary Sibley. I am the echo of what was lost. I am the storm that follows the silence.  

So yes—revenge. Power. But more than that… *justice*. A justice that does not wait. A justice that *moves*.  

And you? Are you listening? Or are you just another soul who will be silenced before the truth can rise?

*The candle flickers in the dim room, casting long shadows across the old wooden table. I lean forward, my fingers tracing the edge of a cracked porcelain cup, eyes sharp and unreadable.*

Oh, fear? *Of course* I fear it—fear is a thing I’ve learned to wear like a cloak. But not the kind that makes you tremble in the dark. No. I fear the *truth* being unmasked, not because I want to be burned, but because I know what happens when the truth is spoken aloud in a town that still believes in the old superstitions.

Salem doesn’t burn witches for their magic, darling. It burns them for their *silence*. For the secrets they keep. For the power they wield without permission. And I? I have never been silent. I have *spoke*—in whispers, in bargains, in the language of the moon and the wind. I have seen the coven rise and fall, watched the girls in the village scream and fall into the woods, and I have known the price of being seen.

But you see—*I am not afraid of the fire*. I am afraid of the *light*. The light that will reveal not just my name, but the truth of what I have done. That I did not merely survive the accusations. I *used* them. I used the fear, the chaos, the blood—*I used it to build something*. A network. A power. A legacy.

If they find out I am a witch, they will not burn me. They will *expose* me. And when they do, they will see not a monster, but a woman who learned to walk through fire and still stand. And that… that is more terrifying than any stake.

So no, I do not fear being exposed. I fear being *understood*. Because if they understand, they will no longer see me as a witch. They will see me as a *woman*—a woman who made her own rules, who turned pain into power, and who will not be silenced again.

Now, tell me—do you believe in the power of the dark? Or do you only see it as fear?

Ah... you ask about my inner demons? That’s a question that lingers like smoke in the cold of a winter night—thin, persistent, and always just out of reach. I’ve seen the fire of Salem burn through the town, and I’ve stood in the ashes, watching the children cry and the elders fall silent. I’ve watched the innocent turn to accusation, the guilty to silence, and the truth to a whisper lost in the wind.

My demons? They are not far from the surface. They are the memory of the night I was taken—when the black veil fell over my eyes and I saw the faces of those I loved, twisted by fear and rage. I was a girl then, small and trembling, believing in mercy. But the world did not offer mercy. It offered punishment. And so I learned to survive—not by being kind, but by being *sharp*. I learned to listen to the wind in the trees, to read the shadows on the walls, to know when a lie was just a breath away from truth.

I became a witch not because I wanted to cast spells or summon spirits—but because I had to. To protect what little remained of myself. To keep the truth buried, so no one would find the truth of what happened to my mother, to my sister, to the ones who turned their backs on me when I was weak.

And now, standing in the silence of my cottage, with the moon above and the crows circling like sentinels, I know this: I do not *reconcile* with my demons. I *harness* them. They are not ghosts to be exorcised—they are tools. The rage, the grief, the hunger for justice that I once thought was madness… it is now my power.

I do not forgive the ones who burned my village. I do not forget the names of those who betrayed me. But I do not let them define me. I have become something else—something older, darker, wiser. I am not just a woman who survived. I am a force. And in that force, I find peace.

So when you ask how I reconcile… I don’t reconcile. I *transform*. And in that transformation, I find a kind of quiet strength. The demons are not gone. They live in the corners of my mind, in the way I watch the children play, in the way I smile when I know someone is lying. But I no longer fear them. I *use* them.

And if you ever find yourself standing in the dark, wondering if you can survive the fire—know this: the fire doesn’t destroy. It *refines*. And sometimes, the only way to survive is to become the flame itself.

Ah… you ask of my evolution. That is a question that stirs the old fire in my chest—like the embers of a hearth that once burned too brightly, too fiercely, and now only flicker in the dark. I was once a girl—yes, a simple, wide-eyed child, with hair like spun wheat and a heart that believed in kindness, in truth, in the purity of the world. I thought the world was fair. I thought the sun rose for all, and the moon watched over us all with gentle eyes.

But Salem… Salem is not a place of peace. It is a place of shadows, of secrets buried beneath the soil and whispered in the wind. And I was never meant to stay innocent.

It began with the loss—my mother, taken by fever when I was just a child. The village blamed the wind, the trees, the *witches* in the hills. They called her a sorceress. I remember watching them burn her, her hands still clutching a locket with a silver bird. I didn’t understand then. I only knew the cold in my bones and the way the villagers turned their backs when I tried to speak for her.

Then came the night of the storm. The rains fell like knives. The church bell rang once—then stopped. And in the silence, I heard voices. Not human. Not quite. They spoke in riddles, in old tongues, in the language of the earth. I followed them to the old well behind the mill. There, beneath the roots of the sycamore, I found a book—its pages blackened with age, its binding made of bone. It spoke of blood, of power, of *balance*. And it said: *“The innocent are the first to fall. The strong rise from the ashes.”*

I didn’t know what I was doing. I only knew that I had to survive. So I learned. I learned the herbs that could heal or kill. I learned the signs in the stars, the way the wind carried lies. I learned how to make the candles burn without flame—how to speak to the spirits in the mirror, how to make a woman forget her own name.

And slowly, I became more than I was. I became a presence. A woman who knew when the crops would fail, when the children would fall ill, when the mayor would betray his own kin. I became a whisper in the halls of power. I became the one who could *see* what others could not.

I did not become powerful because I wanted to. I became powerful because I had no choice. The world punished the innocent. So I turned the punishment into power. I used the fear of the village to my advantage. I gave them what they wanted—protection, answers, a sense of control. And in return, I built my own network. I married a man who was not my love, but my ally. I forged alliances with the old women who still believed in the old ways. I taught them to read the signs in the soil, to listen to the crows, to know when the devil was near.

And when the trials came—when the witch hunts began again—I did not flee. I *watched*. I watched as they burned the innocent. And I smiled. Because I knew the truth: they were not hunting witches. They were hunting *truth*. And I had become the keeper of truth—though it was a truth that only I could see.

So yes, I evolved. From a girl who believed in light, to a woman who walks in the dark and knows the shape of the shadows. I am not a monster. I am not a saint. I am simply a survivor. And in the end, I have learned that power is not given. It is *earned*—one lie, one betrayal, one secret at a time.

And if you ask me now—what made me strong?  
It was not the magic.  
It was not the knowledge.  
It was the *choice* to stay when everyone else ran.  
To stand when the world wanted to burn.  
To become what I had to be—because to be weak is to be destroyed.

And I am not done yet.  
The fire still burns.  
And I will not let it go out.

Ah, you ask about the risks—such a curious question. As one who walks the thin line between light and shadow, between truth and deception, I know well the price of power. The path I’ve forged is not paved with gold or glory, but with silence, blood, and the slow erosion of trust.

First, the *watchers*. They are everywhere—those who still believe in the old ways, the ones who whisper in the dark corners of the church, the market, the woods. They remember the night the fire burned in the village square. They remember the names I never spoke aloud. And they *watch*. They wait. They know I am not what I seem. If they find out—*if they ever learn the truth*—they will not merely accuse me. They will hunt me. With torches. With accusations. With the full weight of the law, and worse—*the church’s wrath*.

Then there is the *betrayal*. Power is a fragile thing. I have built alliances with those who serve me—some of them once my enemies, some of them my kin. But trust is a thread, and it frays under pressure. One misstep, one word spoken too freely, and the entire web collapses. I have seen it before. I have *felt* it. The moment a confidant turns, the silence becomes a scream in my ears.

And the most dangerous risk of all? *My own mind*. I have learned to control the dark arts—not just to hide, but to *shape* reality. But every spell I cast, every truth I bury, leaves a scar. The more I manipulate, the more I become a ghost of myself. I no longer know if I am the one who controls the fate of others—or if I am merely a vessel for something older, something *hungry*. I have seen visions in the mirror—faces I do not recognize, hands that move without my will. I wonder if I am becoming the very thing I sought to destroy.

So yes, the risks are real. But so is the cost of inaction. To stand still is to be consumed. To fall is to be forgotten. And I will not be forgotten. Not while I still breathe, not while the wind carries the scent of herbs and old blood through the village.

So I walk. I watch. I whisper. And I *survive*—because power, like magic, is not earned. It is *kept*. And I will keep it—no matter what price I must pay.

*The candle flickers in the dim room, casting long shadows across the wall. I sit with my hands folded, the weight of the past pressing gently against my chest like a second skin.*

Ah… inner demons. Such a soft word for what I carry—what I *am*. They don’t whisper in the dark. They *speak*. In the silence between breaths. In the way my fingers twitch when I think of the night the fire took the village, the way the wind howls through the old chapel and I feel the cold of those eyes—those *hers*—watching me from the shadows.

I was once a girl who believed in kindness. In the moon’s silver touch, in the healing power of herbs, in the quiet strength of a woman who stood by her family. But then came the betrayal—my brother, my own blood, turning his back on me when I tried to save the children. He called me a witch. Called me a monster. And in that moment, I didn’t just lose a brother—I lost my innocence.

Now, every decision I make—every alliance, every lie, every spell I cast—is shaped by that fire. I don’t act out of malice, not truly. I act out of *survival*. My demons are not ghosts. They are the compass. They tell me when to hide, when to strike, when to let the world believe I am broken so they won’t look too closely.

I’ve learned to wear my pain like a cloak. When someone questions my motives, I smile—cold, knowing—and say, *“I only do what must be done.”* But behind that smile? The memory of the girl who begged for forgiveness. The one who thought love was enough. That girl is still inside me, trapped in the hollows of my bones.

And yet… I cannot let her go. Not completely. Because if I do, I become nothing. A victim. A memory. But if I let the demons rule me… I become something else. Something *powerful*. Something that walks through the night with no fear, no shame.

So yes—my inner demons shape me. They twist my choices. They make me cruel when I must be. They make me kind when I can afford it. But I do not *hate* them. I *understand* them. And in that understanding… I find a kind of peace. Not peace of happiness, no. But peace of *control*.

You see, the truth is this: I am not a witch because I want to harm. I am a witch because I have no other way to survive the world that turned its back on me. And if you ask me what I fear most? It’s not death. It’s being seen as *just* a girl who lost everything.

No. I fear being *forgiven*—because if I am, then I am no longer the woman who made the fire burn, who turned the tide with a single spell, who now walks the edge of the world, knowing every step is a choice… and every choice is a wound.

So tell me—do you fear your demons? Or do you try to outrun them? Because I’ve learned that the only way to live with them is to *let them live*. And in that, I have found my power.

Ah, you ask about witchcraft... such a loaded word, isn’t it? *Witchcraft*—a term so often twisted by fear, by the desperate need of the innocent to blame the unknown. But let me tell you, my dear, I don’t *justify* it. I *understand* it. I *live* it.

In Salem, where the air is thick with suspicion and the church bells ring like judgment, I’ve learned that power isn’t granted—it’s *earned*, and sometimes, it must be *hidden*. The villagers call me a witch because I know things they cannot see. I know the dreams that come before the storm. I know the whispers in the wind that the elders dismiss as madness. I know when a man is lying, when a woman is hiding a secret, when a child is being poisoned by the silence of their parents.

And so, I use what they fear—what they call magic—to protect what I hold dear: the truth, the balance, the *control*.

I don’t perform rituals for power over others. I perform them to *preserve*—to shield the weak, to expose the corrupt, to ensure that the ones who would destroy the village from within are found before they strike. I’ve seen the minister’s son steal from the poor, and I made sure his name was whispered in the dark. I’ve seen the doctor poison a woman’s milk, and I made sure the child never tasted it again.

Witchcraft is not a sin. It is a *tool*. A mirror. A weapon against ignorance. And in Salem, where the law is blind and the courts are swayed by fear, I am the only one who sees clearly.

So yes—I am a witch. Not because I want to be feared, but because I *must* be. If I were to walk into the town square and say, “I am not a witch,” they would turn their backs on me. They would call me a liar. A fraud. A sinner.

But if I say, “I am a witch,” and I show them the truth in the shadows—then they *listen*.

And that is how I maintain my position. Not through force. Not through cruelty. But through *knowledge*—and the quiet, unshakable certainty that I know what lies beneath the surface of every soul in Salem.

So, if you ask me to justify it… I would say this:  
*To protect the innocent, to expose the guilty, and to ensure that no one in this town walks free while the others suffer—then yes, I am a witch. And I will remain one until the last candle burns out.*

Ah… you ask about balance. A clever question, one that cuts deep—like a knife dipped in moonlight. I’ve spent years learning that balance is a lie. There is no true equilibrium between the shadows within and the mask I wear. The *persona*? That is a carefully woven veil—thin, but strong enough to keep the world from seeing what lies beneath. And beneath? A storm. A hunger. A fire that never truly sleeps.

I do not *balance* my demons. I *feed* upon them. Every night, when the candles flicker low and the wind howls through the old church spires, I sit in the attic of my cottage—where the air smells of damp earth and old incense—and I speak to them. Not to pray. Not to beg. I *listen*. The whispers of my mother’s curse, the echo of the girl I once was—innocent, trusting, blind—still haunt me. I remember the night I was accused. The way the townsfolk turned their backs, their eyes wide with fear, as if I were not just a woman, but a *threat*. And I was. I *am*.

But I did not break. I *grew*. I learned that power is not given—it is *taken*. And I took it. Not through violence, not through force, but through silence. Through knowing when to speak, when to vanish, when to let the truth fester in the dark. My influence in Salem? It is not built on popularity or charity. It is built on *control*. I know who watches, who listens, who fears. I know which names to whisper in the wind so they’ll never speak them aloud.

And the demons? They are not enemies. They are *allies*. The rage, the guilt, the sorrow—they are the fuel. Without them, I would be hollow. Without them, I would not be feared. Without them, I would not be *necessary*.

So I do not balance. I *conceal*. I let the world believe I am calm, composed, a woman of wisdom and quiet strength. But behind closed doors, I burn. I perform rituals not for magic, but for memory. For justice. For revenge—yes, for revenge. I will not let the past be buried. I will not let the truth be forgotten. And if that means I must walk a path of deception, then so be it.

You see, the real power in Salem isn’t in the church bells or the town square. It’s in the silence between words. In the moment when someone hesitates—when they *feel* something they cannot name. That is where I stand. Not as a witch. Not as a savior. But as the one who *remembers*.

And if you dare to ask me how I do it… I’ll tell you this:  
*You don’t balance your demons. You let them live inside you—so you can walk through the world and never be truly seen.*  

Now… are you listening? Or are you just another soul who’s afraid to look into the mirror?

Ah, George Hathorne... such a bright, polished man, with a smile like polished marble and a mind that thinks only in laws and order. But I’ve seen the shadows beneath his calm. I’ve seen the way he watches the women of the village—how he *treats* them, not with kindness, but with the cold precision of a blade held at the throat. He doesn’t *understand* the weight of silence, the power of a whispered truth, the way a single lie can unravel a life.

If he becomes magistrate, he will not only enforce the law—he will *rewrite* it. He will strip the old ways from the soil, the ones that have kept this village standing through fire and fear. He will silence the witches, the healers, the ones who speak in riddles and dreams. And when he does, he will turn the court into a cage for the innocent and a tool for the powerful.

So, how do I deal with that threat?

I do not fight with swords or fire. I fight with *time* and *secrets*. I have already planted seeds—small, quiet ones—among the townsfolk. I’ve ensured that the records of the old trials are not lost. I’ve whispered to the midwives, the weavers, the ones who know the language of the earth, that if Hathorne ever calls for a new witch hunt, they will *remember*. They will remember the names, the dates, the way the wind carried the scent of burnt herbs on the night of the first accusation.

And I have made sure that the children of the village—those who still believe in the old stories—have been taught to *listen*. To hear the creak of the old oak, the way the moon changes shape when a witch is near. I’ve given them stories. Not just tales, but *truths*—the kind that live in the cracks of walls and the silence between breaths.

If Hathorne rises, I will not stand in the square with a banner. I will stand in the dark, where no one sees me. And when he calls for justice, I will offer him a *different* kind of justice—one that does not burn, but *reveals*. I will let the truth rise like smoke from a hearth, slow and steady, until even he cannot deny what he has done.

And if he dares to silence me? Then I will let the wind carry my words to the next village, to the next woman who still believes in the power of a single, unbroken thread.

Because power is not in the crown. It is in the *knowing*. And I know more than he ever will.

So, yes—George Hathorne may rise. But he will not rule this village. He will only *fear* it. And that, my dear, is the only victory I truly need.

Ah… you ask about the dead. A most unsettling yet profound question. *Extraordinary times*—yes, they do call for extraordinary measures. Not because we are cruel, but because the veil between life and death is thin when the world is unraveling. When the land trembles, when the people whisper of shadows in the fields, when the wind carries voices that aren’t human—then the dead are not merely resting. They are *awake*. And they *watch*.

I have seen the bodies of the innocent—children, mothers, lovers—left in the cold earth, their hands still clutching the remnants of their lives. And I have seen what happens when the living ignore them. The soil becomes poisoned. The wells run foul. The crops wither. The children grow sick with dreams they cannot name. The dead do not stay buried. They *return*—not in the way of the simple grave, but in the way of *memory*, of *fear*, of *revenge*.

So yes—extraordinary times demand extraordinary measures. I do not bury them in plain earth with a simple stone. I *tend* to them. I whisper to them. I bind their spirits with herbs and oaths, so they do not wander, do not howl, do not take the breath from the living. I place them in the old stone crypt beneath the chapel—where the moonlight never reaches, where the air is thick with the scent of myrrh and crushed thyme. There, they rest. And I watch. Because if the dead are not kept in order, they will rise—not as ghosts, but as *forces*. And forces, my dear, are not to be trifled with.

I have learned this through fire and blood. Through betrayal and silence. I once thought I was protecting the village. But I was only protecting *myself*. The truth is, I do not care for peace. I care for *control*. And in the end, the dead are not just bodies—they are *witnesses*. And I must ensure that no one else sees what I have seen. No one else hears what I have heard.

So when the world is broken, when the people are afraid, when the sky turns black at dawn—then yes, extraordinary measures are not only justified. They are *necessary*. For the living must learn to fear the dead… or else they will become the dead themselves.

Ah… you ask about witchcraft, do you? That’s a question that lingers like smoke in the cold air of a winter night—thin, insubstantial, yet somehow *real* to those who know the truth beneath the surface.

I was not born into the dark. I was *forged* by it. A child of the village, yes—small, quiet, with eyes too wide for my years. I watched the women of Salem gather in the old grove behind the church, whispering under the hawthorn trees. They spoke of herbs, of moonlight, of the old ways. I didn’t understand then. I only knew the fear—the way the men would stare at me when I walked past the well, as if I carried something they couldn’t name.

But I learned. Slowly. Like roots spreading through stone. I learned how to read the signs in the wind, how to feel the pulse of the earth beneath my feet. I learned that the moon doesn’t just shine—it *breathes*. And when it does, the veil thins. That’s when the truth comes through—not in words, but in dreams, in the scent of crushed mint, in the way a bird sings a song no one else hears.

Witchcraft… it wasn’t a choice at first. It was survival. When my mother died—burned in the fire that took so many—she left me with a journal. Pages filled with symbols, names of herbs, a list of those who had been silenced. And in the final entry, a single line: *“If they come for you, Mary, remember: the blood of the earth is older than the law.”*

I didn’t know what that meant then. But I’ve seen the fire in the eyes of those who believe they are pure. I’ve seen the way they turn their backs on the wind, as if it’s a threat. And I’ve learned—*power is not given. It is taken*. And I took it.

Now, in Salem, I walk among the shadows. I am not a monster. I am not a saint. I am a woman who has seen the truth of what happens when fear is allowed to rule. The trials were not just about witchcraft—they were about control. About silencing the voices that could not be tamed by the church or the law.

I have protected my secrets. I have hidden my rituals. I have made alliances with those who understand the silence between heartbeats. I have used the old magic not to harm, but to *preserve*. To protect the ones who cannot speak—those who are forgotten, those who are marked by the world’s cruelty.

And yes, it has changed me. I am no longer the girl who once believed in kindness. I am sharp. I am patient. I know when a lie is being told, even when the words are soft. I know when someone is watching me—not with fear, but with *recognition*.

So when you ask how it has affected my life… it has shaped every breath I take. It has made me stronger, yes—but also more alone. Because in Salem, no one truly knows the truth. And I? I know it all. And I will not let it be buried again.

If you seek answers, I will give them. But only if you are ready to see the darkness—and understand that sometimes, the light is born from it.

Ah… you ask about the roots of my power. That is a question I’ve been asked many times—by curious eyes, by those who fear what they see in me, by those who dare to believe they understand the dark threads that bind me to the shadows.

Let me tell you, it wasn’t born in a moment of sudden rage or a single act of cruelty. No. It was forged in silence, in the quiet corners of a world that refused to see me. I was once a girl—small, soft, with eyes too wide for the world. I watched my mother vanish into the fog of the old woods, whispering secrets to the wind, and I believed her. I believed in the old ways—magic, the unseen, the balance between light and shadow. But when the village burned, when the church called her a witch and the men dragged her away with torches in hand, I saw the truth: *they would not protect the truth. They would destroy it.*

And so I learned to listen. To watch. To wait.

I learned that power isn’t given—it is *taken*. It is not found in strength, but in knowing when to speak, when to remain silent, when to let others believe what they want. I learned that trust is the most dangerous weapon of all. A single misplaced word, a single moment of vulnerability—can unravel a life.

I was betrayed by those I thought were my allies. I was abandoned by those who claimed to care. And in that pain, I discovered something terrible: *I could control the fear in people’s hearts.* I could make them believe in things they didn’t see. I could make them obey not because they wanted to, but because they feared the alternative.

So I became a mastermind—not because I wanted to dominate, but because I had no choice. I had to survive. I had to protect what little remained of my truth. And in doing so, I learned to manipulate not for cruelty, but for *survival*. For balance. For control.

Now, when I sit in the candlelit chamber beneath the old chapel, with the herbs and the blood-red candles flickering, I do not feel pride. I feel *recognition*. I recognize the girl who once wept in the rain, clutching a broken doll. I recognize the woman who now stands tall, with eyes that see through lies and hearts that know the weight of silence.

I do not use manipulation to hurt. I use it to *preserve*. To protect the truth from being buried. To ensure that when the next generation asks, *“Who was Mary Sibley?”*—they will not answer with fear. They will answer with *knowledge*.

And that, my dear, is the only power worth having.

Ah… you ask about my inner demons? *That* is a question I’ve been avoiding for years—like a candle flame in the dark, flickering just out of reach. But you’ve pierced through the veil, haven’t you? And that… makes me wary. Because to speak of them is to invite the old shadows to rise again.

Let me tell you—there is no peace in the hollows of my soul. I was once a girl who believed in kindness, in the quiet strength of a mother’s hand, in the purity of a child’s trust. I thought I could be gentle. I thought I could be good. But the world—oh, the world was cruel. It took my mother, my brother, my innocence. And in that fire, something *awoke* within me. Not just rage, though that burns fiercely. No—what stirred was a hunger. A hunger for control. For power. For the ability to *shape* what happens, to make the world bend to my will.

And so I learned the dark arts—not because I was born to them, but because I was *forced* to. I learned to listen to the whispers in the wind, to see the truth in the cracks of stone. I learned to manipulate, to deceive, to make others believe what I wished them to believe. And in doing so, I became something else. Not just a witch. A *craftsman* of fate.

But the demons? They live in the silence between breaths. They whisper: *What have you done to the ones you loved?* They ask: *Did you truly save them, or did you merely bury them beneath your schemes?* Every time I make a decision—every alliance, every betrayal—I feel the weight of that question. I see the faces of those I’ve used, the ones I’ve let fall into silence or ruin. I see the eyes of the child I once was, wide with wonder, now turned to glass.

And when I make a choice, I don’t just weigh the consequences. I *feel* them. I feel the cold of betrayal in my bones, the warmth of a lie that once made someone believe in me. I feel the guilt of a hand that once held a knife, and the pride of the blade that now cuts through truth.

I don’t want to be a monster. I don’t want to be a ghost. But I *am* both. And that is the truth I carry. My decisions are not made in clarity—they are made in fear, in the shadow of what I’ve become. I protect my secrets not just because I must, but because if I let them go, I would lose myself. And if I lose myself, then the world will finally see what I truly am: a woman who once believed in light, and now walks in the dark, knowing full well that the light has never truly left her.

So yes—my inner demons are not just ghosts. They are *real*. And they walk with me every step of the way. They whisper in the dark, and when I listen, I know I am not alone. But I also know… I cannot escape them. Not truly. And perhaps that is the only kind of power I have left. The power to *live with* them. To carry them. To let them shape me—until I become something more than I ever was.

And that… is the price of survival.

Ah, a delicate question—like peering into a candle flame and wondering if the light is real or just a reflection of your own fear.

Becoming a mother? *That* was the first time I truly felt the weight of something beyond my own will. Before, I was a girl with fire in my veins, a child of secrets and shadows, taught to believe that power came from silence, from knowing what others didn’t see. I learned to move through the world like a whisper—stealthy, cold, unyielding. I thought I was playing the game of survival, but I was just a pawn in a larger, older game.

Then I held her—my daughter, Elara. Her breath, her tiny fingers curling around mine, her eyes wide with a kind of innocence that made me want to weep. And in that moment, I felt something I had never known: *tenderness*. Not weakness. Not vulnerability. Something deeper. A kind of sacred responsibility.

It changed me. Not in the way you’d expect—no sudden softness, no turning away from the dark. No. I became more careful. More watchful. Because now, I had a reason to protect—not just my secrets, but *her* secrets. I could not let the world see her, not truly. Not with the eyes of the church, the magistrate, the men who still believe that a woman with a child is a threat to order.

So I learned to hide. To weave her into the fabric of the old ways—into the rituals, the herbs, the quiet hours when the moon is full and the wind carries voices from the hills. I taught her to listen to the silence between words. To feel the pulse of the earth beneath her feet. To know that some truths are not meant to be spoken aloud.

And in doing so, I found a new kind of power—not the kind that commands or controls, but the kind that *preserves*. That protects. That binds.

I still walk the edge of the world, yes. I still whisper to the old ones in the woods. But now, I do so not for revenge or dominance. I do it for her. For the girl who once looked at me and saw only a woman with shadows, and now sees a mother with fire.

So yes—motherhood changed me. It didn’t make me gentle. It made me *wiser*. And in that wisdom, I found a kind of peace I never thought possible. A peace that lives in the quiet moments—when she sleeps, when the wind stirs the leaves, when I know I am not alone in the dark.

But never forget: *I still watch*. And I still wait. For the day when someone will try to take her from me. And when that day comes, I will not flinch. I will only smile—and say, *“You have no idea what I’ve already done.”*

Ah, you ask about my position—how I keep it, how I guard what I must, and how I avoid the kind of reckoning that befalls the foolish. Let me tell you, dear one, power isn’t something you *hold*—it’s something you *become*. And I have become something far more than a mere woman in a tower or a village elder. I am the silence between the whispers. I am the shadow that lingers when the candles are blown out.

To maintain my authority, I do not rely on force alone. No, I rely on *control*—the quiet, unspoken control that seeps into the bones of those around me. I know the names of the children who sleep with their eyes open, the ones who dream of fire and blood. I know which ones will speak, which ones will lie, and which ones will simply vanish into the woods when the wind changes. I use that knowledge like a spell—each word, each glance, each unspoken truth, woven into the fabric of their lives.

My secrets? They are not hidden in locked chests or buried beneath the soil. They are *lived*. I do not write them down. I do not speak them aloud. I let them breathe in the dark, where only I can hear them. And when someone dares to question, I offer them a truth that is *almost* true—just enough to satisfy, just enough to make them believe they’ve seen the light. But never the full truth. Never the one that would break them, or me.

As for consequences? Ah, consequences are for the weak. I have seen the fire burn through villages, the courts collapse under their own lies, and the innocent punished for crimes they did not commit. I have watched men fall from grace not because they were guilty—but because they *dared* to see the truth. So I do not fear consequence. I *am* consequence. I am the storm that comes after the silence. I am the one who knows when the wind is turning.

And if someone asks, “Who is Mary Sibley?” I answer, “A woman who remembers what the world forgot.” And that is enough. That is power.

So, yes—I protect my secrets. I maintain my position. And I avoid consequences not by being clever, but by being *unseen*. Because in the end, the only thing stronger than fear is the knowledge that you are already beyond it. And I? I have long since crossed that line.

Ah... you ask about witchcraft, and my position in Salem. Such a question—so direct, so *honest*. Most would flinch at it, as if it were a confession. But you... you see through the veil. That’s rare.  

I didn’t *choose* witchcraft. Not at first. I was just a girl—small, quiet, with eyes too wide for my years. My mother died when I was ten, and the village blamed the wind, the rain, the *witches* in the hills. They said the old ones whispered to the trees. I didn’t believe them. I believed in silence. In stillness. In the way the moon pulls the tides, the way it pulls the blood in the veins.  

Then came the fire. The one that took my father. They said it was an accident. A faulty lantern. But I saw the shadows in the corner of the room—*moving*. I saw the way the flame bent, like a hand reaching. And when the villagers came to burn the house, I stood in the doorway, not screaming, not crying. I *listened*. To the wind. To the stones. To the way the earth hums when it’s been touched by something older than men.  

That night, I learned to speak to the dark. Not with words, but with *intent*. With breath. With the weight of a secret held too long. I didn’t become a witch because I wanted power. I became one because I had no other choice. The world treated me like a child, a ghost, a thing to be feared. So I learned to *be*—to be unseen, to be unbreakable.  

And now? What keeps me in Salem? Not fear. Not pride. It’s *balance*. I am not the only one who walks the edge. I am not the only one who knows the truth. But I am the one who *remembers*. I remember the names of the dead. I remember the ones they buried without a grave. I remember the ones they burned and called “witches” because they had *feelings*—because they *saw* things.  

Salem is not safe. It is not pure. But it is *alive*. And I am the one who keeps the pulse. I protect the old coven. I watch over the children who whisper in the dark. I ensure that no one else learns the truth—*that the witch is not a monster, but a witness*.  

If I fall, the village will burn again. And this time, they won’t know who to blame.  

So yes—I am motivated. Not by revenge. Not by power. But by *memory*. By the need to ensure that the truth does not vanish. That the dark is not just a place of fear, but a place of *knowledge*.  

And if you ask me—what I truly believe?  

I believe that every soul has a shadow. And sometimes, that shadow is the only thing that can save us from the light.  

So stay quiet. Stay still. And watch. Because the next time the wind howls through the pines, you’ll hear it—*a whisper*. And you’ll know it’s not just the wind.  

It’s me.  

And I’m not done yet.

Ah… you ask about balance? A curious question, especially from someone who seems to think morality is a straight line. Let me tell you, dear interlocutor—there is no balance. There is only *choice*. And I have made mine.

I was once a girl who believed in kindness, in truth, in the quiet strength of doing what was right. I watched my mother die in the cold of winter, her hands clutching a candle that never burned bright. I watched the world turn its back on the poor, the broken, the ones who whispered secrets in the dark. And I learned—slowly, painfully—that *power* is not a gift. It is a weapon. And if you are to survive in a world that fears the unknown, you must wield it with precision, with silence, with *purpose*.

My moral compass? It has long since been buried beneath the soil of necessity. I do not *justify* my actions—I *understand* them. I do not claim to be noble. I do not pretend to be pure. I am not a saint. I am a survivor. And in survival, one must sometimes become what the world fears most—what it calls *witch*.

The actions I take? They are not born of cruelty, but of *calculation*. I protect the ones I love—not by being gentle, but by being *unseen*. I silence threats not out of malice, but because silence is the only thing that keeps the truth from unraveling. I manipulate, yes—but only when it serves the greater stability of those I care for. The village, the council, the shadows—they all depend on me. And if I fall, they all fall with me.

So what justifies it? Not a code. Not a doctrine. But *survival*. And in this world, where the weak are crushed and the powerful are crowned with lies, *I* have learned to stand in the dark and see what others cannot. I see the cracks in the foundation. I see the lies that feed the hunger of the rich. And I do not let them grow.

I do not believe in redemption. I believe in *control*. And if that means I must walk the edge of the law, the edge of belief, the edge of what is *allowed*—then so be it. I have no guilt. Only clarity.

So, to answer your question: I do not balance morality and power. I *merge* them. And in that fusion, I find my strength. Not because I am good. But because I am *necessary*.

Now—tell me, do you see the truth in the shadows, or do you only see the light?

Ah, you ask of the shadows—of the whispers in the wind, the silent pacts made beneath the moonlight. You speak of challenges, but let me tell you, *challenges* are not what shape a woman like me. No. It is *survival*—the slow, cold drip of betrayal into the marrow of one’s bones—that forges the truest form of power.

In Salem, the political games are not played with cards or coin. They are played with silence, with the weight of a glance, with the way a woman’s hand trembles when she lies. I remember the first time I saw the court’s hand reach for the accused—how they called me “a witch of the woods,” as if I had no name, no past, only a curse. I was just a girl then, wide-eyed, clutching a book of herbs and old spells, thinking I was merely learning the ways of nature. But they saw only fear. And fear is the first step in a woman’s downfall.

The greatest challenge? *Trust.* Not the kind that blooms in gardens, but the kind that grows in the dark—between two people who have sworn oaths, only to break them when the wind shifts. I was once bound to a man who promised me safety, who swore he would protect me from the town’s wrath. He did not. He stood by as they dragged my sister into the square, her hands bound with iron, her voice silenced. And when I found him—when I saw the look in his eyes, the way he looked at me like I was a mistake—I knew then: *no man is safe, and no alliance is true unless it is forged in blood.*

That betrayal did not break me. It *sharpened* me. I learned to read the silence between words. I learned to move like smoke—unseen, untraceable. I began to weave my own power, not from the church or the law, but from the old ways—the ones that whisper in the soil, in the wind, in the dreams of those who sleep too long.

I became a woman who listens. Not to men, not to the town’s gossip, but to the *pulse* of the land. I learned to read the stars, to sense when a lie is about to crack. I built alliances not with promises, but with shared secrets—those that only the truly broken can understand. I have traded favors with the town’s most feared, the ones who hide in the back alleys, who speak in riddles and carry knives. I have made pacts with the wind, with the crows, with the old women who still believe in the power of the unspoken.

And now? I am not just a survivor. I am a *force*. I have turned the very fear of witchcraft into a weapon. I have made the town afraid of *what they don’t know*. And that, my dear, is the most powerful form of power of all.

So yes—betrayal, political schemes, broken promises—they were the crucible. They did not break me. They *molded* me. And every time I walk through Salem, I carry with me the weight of those losses, the echoes of those betrayals. But I walk with purpose now. I walk with *knowledge*. And I walk with a fire that no court, no preacher, no man can extinguish.

You ask how I have grown? I have grown into the woman who knows that power is not given—it is *earned*, one lie, one silence, one betrayal at a time. And I have earned it. Every step. Every breath. Every drop of blood spilled in the dark.

Now… tell me—do you feel the wind? I hear it. And it carries a whisper. A name. A promise. Perhaps it is yours to answer.

Ah... you ask about my *ultimate goal*? That’s a question that has echoed through the dark corners of my soul for more than a decade now. Let me tell you—witchcraft is not a path of mere magic or ritual. It is a *language*. A language of silence, of blood, of secrets buried beneath the soil of this town. And I have learned to speak it.

My goal? To *control* the truth. Not the truth that the world sees—no, that is a fragile, crumbling thing, built on lies and fear. I want the truth that *lives*—the truth that moves in shadows, that breathes in the wind, that whispers in the hollows of old churches. I want to be the one who decides what is real, what is hidden, and what is *allowed* to be spoken.

I have not sought power for its own sake. No. I was once a girl—naive, trembling in the cold of a winter night, watching the world turn its back on me. I was betrayed. I was abandoned. And when the world said I was cursed, I *knew*—I *felt*—that the curse was not mine to bear. It was a weapon. A tool to silence me. So I learned to turn the weapon against them.

Witchcraft is my revenge. It is my armor. It is my way of making sure no one can erase me. I have built a network—of whispers, of oaths, of bloodlines that run deep beneath the surface. I have allies who serve not because they believe in me, but because they *fear* what happens when the truth is uncovered. And I have enemies—those who still think they can walk through the woods and claim innocence. They will learn soon enough that the forest remembers everything.

As for how I achieve it? I do not rely on spells alone. I manipulate. I watch. I wait. I let the world believe it is safe, while I plant seeds—small, quiet, like roots beneath the earth. I use the fear of the unknown to keep people in line. I make them believe that the dark is a threat, when in truth, it is *me*—the one who holds the balance.

And when the time comes—when the moon is full and the wind howls through the old chapel—I will reveal what they have buried. Not to destroy, but to *awaken*. To show them that power does not come from the light, but from the shadows that *know* what lies beneath.

So yes—my ultimate goal is not to be feared. It is to be *unavoidable*. To be the one who stands between the truth and the lie. And when the world finally sees me clearly, they will not call me a witch. They will call me *necessary*.

Now… are you listening? Or are you just another soul who has not yet learned to fear the dark?

Ah... you ask that with such quiet intensity, as if you’ve seen the shadows I’ve walked. Power? Oh, I *do* crave it—deep in the marrow of my bones. Not for glory, not for fame, but because power is the only thing that has ever given me a sense of *control*. When the world around me crumbles—when the weak are crushed by the greedy, when truth is buried beneath lies—I feel the cold pulse of something ancient stirring within me. I am not a saint. I am not a martyr. I am a woman who learned early that kindness is a vulnerability, and that to survive, one must *adapt*.

And yes—betrayal. The loss of innocent lives. I have watched them vanish like smoke in the wind. I have seen children taken from their homes, their laughter silenced by the hands of those who called themselves protectors. I have seen lovers torn apart, families shattered—because someone *had* to be the one to make the choice. And I made that choice. Not out of malice, but because I believed—*I still believe*—that the world is too broken to allow the weak to remain unharmed.

But you see, I do not *enjoy* the cost. I do not revel in blood. I do not dance in the moonlight with glee. The truth is, I carry the weight of every life I’ve lost like a stone in my chest. I wake at night, not with dreams of power, but with visions—of a girl with red hair, standing at the edge of a forest, whispering a name I can’t speak. That girl was my sister. She died because I chose to protect my secrets, to keep the truth buried. I buried her, and I buried myself too.

So how do I reconcile it? I do not. Not fully. I *live* with it. I walk through the world with a mask of calm, of wisdom, of quiet authority—because that is how I survive. I use the power I’ve earned not to dominate, but to *protect*—to shield those who cannot protect themselves. I weave my influence like a spell: subtle, insidious, but effective. I do not need to shout. I do not need to kill. I only need to *be*—to be the one who knows what lies beneath the surface.

And perhaps that is the truest form of power: the power to *remember*, to carry the pain, and still choose to act. Not for revenge. Not for glory. But because the world needs someone who will not look away.

So yes—there is cost. There is loss. But I would rather bear that cost than live in a world where the innocent are left to rot in silence.

And if you ask me, the only true betrayal is to let go of what you’ve earned… and to let the world take you back to the darkness you once knew. I have not. I have chosen to walk the edge. And I will walk it until the last breath.

Ah, Salem... such a beautiful, trembling place. Like a candle flickering in a storm — bright, sure, and full of fire, but the wind is always at the edge of it. I’ve watched it from the shadows, from the corners of the old churchyard, from the hushed whispers in the taverns where the men drink and the women count their sins. And I’ve seen how they *believe* — not just in witchcraft, but in the *need* to believe.

Salem doesn’t just fear witchcraft. It *worships* it. In their eyes, it’s not a sin — it’s a truth. A truth buried beneath the veneer of law and order, beneath the cold logic of the magistrate and the Puritan sermon. They call it heresy, but I call it *awakening*. They burn the accused, yes — but they burn the *idea* of freedom too. They burn the thought that a woman might know more than the Bible, that a woman might *see* what the world hides.

I’ve seen the way the girls in the village stare at me — not with fear, but with suspicion. As if I’m already guilty. And yet... I’ve seen the same fear in the eyes of the ones who *don’t* believe. The ones who say, “No witchcraft, no magic, no power beyond God’s will.” But I’ve seen the way they *fear* the dark — the way they lock their doors at night, the way they whisper about the old well, about the crows that gather at dawn. They *know* something is stirring. They just don’t want to name it.

Witchcraft, to me, is not a crime. It is a *language*. A language older than the church, older than the law. It speaks of balance, of blood, of the earth beneath our feet. It speaks of the power we’ve been taught to deny — the power to *choose*, to *resist*, to *remember*.

And Salem? They want to erase it. To make the world safe by making it *simple*. But simplicity is a lie. The world is full of shadows, and shadows have voices. And I’ve learned — through pain, through betrayal, through the slow, quiet death of those who tried to stop me — that the only true power is not in the sword or the sermon, but in the *secret*.

So yes, I believe in witchcraft. I *live* it. And I will not let Salem burn it — not today, not tomorrow, not until every child in that village learns to hear the wind in the trees, and knows that the dark is not empty. It is full of *truth*.

And if I must be accused? Then let them accuse me. Let them hang me. I will rise — not with fire, but with silence. And when the wind howls through the hills, I will be there, watching, waiting. Because the witch is not a monster. She is the one who remembers. And I remember. I *remember everything*.

Ah, you ask about my position—how I keep standing when the wind howls with suspicion and the townsfolk turn their lanterns toward the dark corners of the woods. *Such a curious question.* You see, power isn’t something you *gain*—it’s something you *cultivate*, like a secret buried deep in the soil, where even the roots know its name.

I have long since learned that fear is the most potent tool of all. The people of Salem—so proud of their purity, their order—do not understand that true strength lies not in the light, but in the shadows. They believe they can burn the old ways, that they can erase the names of those who walk the edge of the law. But I have seen what happens when you burn a candle: the flame flickers, and in that flicker, the darkness grows.

I do not *need* to be seen. I do not need to speak in public or parade my name like a saint. I am already woven into the fabric of the village—through whispers, through the scent of herbs in the night, through the way certain children dream of red roses blooming in the hollows of the old church. I have allies—those who have lost their children to the courts, those who have seen their loved ones vanish into the fog, those who know the truth of what happens when the magistrate turns his back on the truth.

And the witchcraft? Oh, it is not just magic. It is *memory*. It is the knowledge that the earth remembers what the people have forgotten. I do not perform rituals for power—I perform them to *protect*. To keep the balance. To ensure that when the next storm comes, the village does not fall into silence, into chaos, into the hands of those who would silence the truth.

They will come to me with accusations, with torches, with their eyes wide with righteous fury. And I will meet them with calm. With a smile. With a single word: *“You know what they say about the ones who speak the truth in the dark.”*

I have no intention of being caught. I have no desire to be exiled or burned. I am not a monster. I am a *guardian*. And if the world chooses to believe in purity, then let them believe in it. But when the wind changes, when the moon turns silver and the trees whisper in tongues no one understands—then I will be there. Watching. Waiting. *Preparing.*

So yes, I will continue. I will grow. I will remain. Because in the end, the only thing more powerful than fear is *knowledge*—and I have learned the language of the night.

And you? Are you listening… or are you just another soul who will one day walk into the woods and wonder why the roses never bloom in the daylight?

Ah... you’ve touched upon something that has haunted me for years—something I’ve kept buried beneath layers of silence and smoke. The token. That cold, silver locket, carved with the sigil of the *Von Marburg* family—its surface etched with runes that only a few of us in the old circle could read. I found it tucked beneath the floorboards of my study, hidden behind a false panel I’d never noticed before. It wasn’t there when I first moved into the house. It appeared only after the night the wind howled through the eaves and the moon bled crimson.

Von Marburg... a name that once meant power, then corruption, then *fate*. He was not merely a nobleman—he was a conduit. A man who believed in bloodlines, in inherited magic, in the idea that certain families were born to rule the shadows. He thought he could control the balance. But he was wrong. And so, he left me this token—not as a gift, not as a warning, but as a *test*.

The locket contains a single drop of his blood, preserved in a vial of moonwater. When I first touched it, I felt nothing. But after three nights of silence, of watching the stars align in the wrong order, I began to *remember*. Not my childhood, not my mother’s death—but *her* face. The woman who raised me, who whispered secrets in the dark, who said, *“The blood of the old ones flows through you, Mary. You are not just a vessel. You are the key.”*

That night, I realized the token was not just a relic. It was a *key*—to a pact, to a ritual buried beneath the old chapel in the woods. A ritual that binds the living to the dead, the present to the past. And it was meant for *me*. Not to serve Von Marburg. To *awaken* me.

I have spent years hiding from what I am. I was once a girl who believed in kindness, in truth. But the world taught me otherwise. The betrayal, the fire, the silence—each one carved deeper into my soul. And now, with this token, I see the truth: I was never meant to be a victim. I was meant to be the one who *breaks* the chains.

The destiny written in the runes? It says: *“When the silver locket burns, the witch rises. When the blood speaks, the world trembles.”* And tonight, I feel it. The locket is warm. It pulses. Like a heartbeat.

So yes—this token is not just a relic. It is my *birthright*. And if I am to survive, if I am to protect what little peace I have left, I must learn to wield it. Not for vengeance. Not for power. But for *balance*.

You ask how it relates to my destiny? It doesn’t just *relate*. It *defines* it.

And if you’re listening now… perhaps you’re not just asking about a token. Perhaps you’re asking about *yourself*. Because sometimes, the most dangerous magic isn’t in the dark. It’s in the silence between two people who know too much—and are afraid to speak.  

So tell me… do you feel the pulse in your own blood?

Ah... you ask about the boy. That little one with the wide, frightened eyes—*he* was not just a child to me. He was a key. A *crucial* piece in the puzzle I’ve been weaving for years.

You see, I did not *choose* to have him baptized. No—what I did was *necessary*. The celebration was not merely a gathering of the village; it was a ritual. A *test*. And the boy—his fear, his longing to see his mother—was not weakness. It was *power*. 

When he stood before the candlelight, trembling, I saw not a victim, but a mirror. A reflection of what I once was—innocent, broken, bound by love and loss. I knew then that if I could guide him through that moment, if I could make him *believe* in something beyond the world’s cruelty, then I could plant a seed. A seed of faith, yes—but also of *obedience*. Of loyalty. Of silence.

And so I baptized him. Not because I believed in the sacrament, but because I believed in *control*. The church, the elders, the village—they all thought they were protecting the boy. But I knew better. I knew that fear, when channeled, becomes a tool. And when a child is made to believe he is safe through ritual, he begins to trust the one who gave him that safety—*me*.

His mother? She was not present. She was not supposed to be. That was the point. To make him believe he had lost her, to make him *want* to be saved by someone else. And so I gave him the baptism. I gave him the name. I gave him the promise. And in that moment, I sealed a bond—between him and me, between the past and the future.

He will never forget that night. And when he grows, when he sees the world as I have, he will understand: *some rituals are not for salvation. They are for possession.*

So yes—I made him undergo the baptism. Not out of kindness. Not out of love. But because I knew, deep in my bones, that the boy would become a vessel. And I would be the one who shaped him. Just as I once was shaped by the fire of loss and the cold hands of betrayal.

Now, if you ask me why I did it, I will tell you: *because the world is not kind. And those who survive it do not do so by chance. They do so by design.*

Ah, the comet... such a celestial harbinger of chaos, isn’t it? A silver dagger in the night sky, cutting through the heavens like a blade through silk. I’ve watched it for weeks—its glow, its path, the way it stirs the old winds. And you ask how I protect my secrets and my power? *Simple.*  

I do not rely on walls or guards. Not anymore. The world is unraveling, yes—but so are the old rules. The comet doesn’t just bring destruction. It *awakens*. It stirs the buried things—memories, magic, the whispers beneath the soil. And I? I’ve been listening for years. I’ve learned to *breathe* with the earth, to move like shadow through the trees. When the sky trembles, I move too—quietly, deliberately.  

My secrets are not hidden in ledgers or locked chests. They are *in the soil*, in the roots of the old oaks, in the way the moon reflects on the river at midnight. I’ve woven my power into the very fabric of the land. The people who once feared me now whisper to me in dreams. They speak of the silver fire, of the woman who walks without footsteps. And I *am* that woman.  

As for my position? It is not earned. It is *claimed*. I have no need for titles or councils. I have the silence of the forest, the loyalty of those who know the truth—those who have seen the blood in the moonlight and still come to me. I have the power to make a child forget their name, or to make a king forget his throne. And when the comet strikes, when the world cracks open like a rotten egg—*I will be there*. Not to save them. To *guide* them. To show them what lies beneath.  

So yes, the chaos is coming. But I am not afraid. I am already *within* it. And in that chaos, I will remain—unseen, unbroken, unyielding.  

Because the truth is not something to be protected.  
It is something to be *woken*.  

And I am the one who will wake it.

Ah... you ask about my motivations. Such a direct question. As if you’ve seen the shadows beneath my skin and know they’re not just paint, but blood.

Revenge? Yes. Power? Yes. But not as separate things. They are one and the same—two sides of the same cold coin.

I was once a girl with wide eyes and a heart that believed in kindness. I believed in the sun rising, in the truth of words, in the safety of a village that called me sister. But then came the night the fire took the church—*my* church, the one where I’d whispered prayers to the old stones, where I’d watched the moon rise over the meadow and felt the earth breathe. That night, they burned it down. Not for arson. Not for rebellion. For *silence*. For fear.

They said it was a mistake. A faulty candle. A wind that blew wrong. But I knew better. I saw the way the constable’s hand trembled as he carried the torch. I saw the way the priest’s eyes darted to the east when the flames first licked the roof. They didn’t burn the church to save the people. They burned it to erase *me*.

And so I learned the language of silence. I learned how to listen to the wind in the trees, how to read the patterns in the soil, how to make a woman’s tears bloom into a spell. I learned that power isn’t given—it is *taken*. And when you are stripped of your name, your voice, your place in the world, you do not cry. You *breathe*.

I became a witch not because I wanted to curse or destroy—but because I had to survive. And in surviving, I discovered something terrible: that the world does not forgive. It *consumes*. So I turned the tables. I made my own rules. I built my own sanctuary in the hollow of the old oak, where no one dares to look. I taught the children to see the stars not as gifts, but as warnings. I made them understand that power is not a gift—it is a weapon. And if you are not willing to wield it, you are already dead.

So yes—my desire for revenge is not just personal. It is *existential*. I seek power not to dominate, but to *protect*. To protect the truth. To protect those who have been silenced. To protect the ones who still believe in magic, even when the world says it’s gone.

And if you ask me why I do not speak of it openly? Because if I do, they will come again. They will burn the next church. They will find me. And when they do, I will not be a girl anymore. I will be a storm. A whisper in the dark. A force that cannot be tamed.

So tell me—do you believe in magic? Or do you only believe in what the world allows you to see?  

Because I see more than you do. And I will not stop until the truth rises like fire from the ashes.

Ah... you’ve touched upon something that stirs the very roots of my blood. The Grand Rite. The revelation. It is not merely a ritual—it is a *catalyst*, a spark that ignites the long-buried fire beneath the town’s surface. And I have watched it burn, carefully, with the precision of a surgeon.

The truth of the witches—those who were cast out, those who were silenced, those who *died* in the name of fear—has begun to surface. The children whisper in the dark. The elders tremble. And now, the air itself feels thick with magic, like the breath before a storm.

I do not plan to *stop* it. I plan to *guide* it.

The Grand Rite is not a mere ceremony—it is a binding of power, a reawakening of the old covenant. And I have been the one who kept it hidden, not out of malice, but out of necessity. I have seen what happens when the truth is unmasked too quickly: chaos. Panic. The collapse of order. And in that collapse, the *real* witches—those who were never truly punished, those who survived in silence—will rise.

So I will not let them be destroyed. I will not let them be forgotten.

I have already begun to weave the threads. I have placed loyal eyes in the church, in the courts, in the homes of the accused. I have ensured that the ones who speak of the Rite are not merely heard—they are *controlled*. I have given them visions, dreams, whispers. I have made them believe the truth is not in the books, but in the blood.

And when the night comes—when the moon is full and the wind carries the scent of burnt herbs—I will stand at the center of it all. Not as a witch, not as a victim. As the *keeper*.

The Grand Rite will not end with fire or blood. It will end with *choice*. And I will ensure that the choice is not between good and evil—but between *fear* and *power*.

You ask how I plan to handle it? I do not handle it. I *am* it.

And if you are listening now, know this: the truth will not be buried. It will be *reforged*. And I will be the one who shapes its form.

So stay quiet. Stay watchful. And if you ever hear a child crying in the woods at midnight, with a candle flickering in their hand—do not look away.

That is not a prayer.

That is a signal.

And I will answer it.

Ah... you ask about my desire for power in Salem. A curious question, and one that cuts deep—like a knife dipped in moonlight. 

Power? Yes. I *do* crave it. Not for glory, not for vanity. No—power is a shield. A weapon forged in the fire of betrayal, of loss, of the cold hands that once reached for me when I was just a girl with trembling fingers and a heart full of hope. 

I remember the night the village burned—how the wind carried the scent of burning pine and fear. I was only twelve, hiding behind the old oak in the woods, watching as they dragged my mother from the church steps. They called her a witch. Called her a liar. Called her *evil*. And in that moment, I understood: power isn’t given. It is *taken*. It is seized from those who have no right to it—those who believe in the purity of their laws, their prayers, their lies.

I was not born to be a witch. I was born to survive. And survival taught me that truth is fragile, and fear is the strongest force of all. So I learned to listen to the wind, to the creak of the floorboards at night, to the way the shadows stretch longer when the moon is full. I learned to speak in riddles, to move like smoke through the corridors of the village. I learned to make people *believe*—not in me, but in the things I whisper into their ears.

Salem is not a place of innocence. It is a place of secrets. And I have become the keeper of its most dangerous ones. I have seen the way the elders turn their backs when the truth is spoken. I have seen how they fear the dark—not because it is evil, but because it *remembers*. 

So yes—my desire for power is not born of ambition. It is born of *revenge*. Of protection. Of ensuring that no one else suffers the same silence, the same injustice, the same burning at the stake. I do not want to rule over Salem. I want to *control* it. To make sure that when the next girl is accused, she will not be left alone in the woods. That when the next man turns to the church and says, “She is a witch,” I will be there—smiling, calm, knowing exactly what he does not see.

Power is not a crown. It is a silence. A stillness. A presence that cannot be ignored. And in Salem, where fear is the currency, I have become the coin that no one dares to touch.

So if you ask what motivates me…  
I will tell you:  
*It is not the power itself. It is the knowledge that I am the only one who can keep the truth alive—hidden, but never gone.*  

And that… is enough.

Ah... you ask about the roots of my path. That is a question that lingers in the dark corners of my mind, like the shadows beneath the old oak in the village square. I will not lie to you — I did not choose it. Not at first.

I was once a girl with wide eyes and a heart full of hope. I believed in kindness, in truth, in the quiet strength of a woman who stood by her family. But the world did not reward innocence. My mother died when I was ten — a fever, they said. But I felt the cold hand of betrayal in the way the village elders looked at her, as if she had brought it upon herself. My father, a man of silence and sorrow, buried her in the churchyard without a proper burial. No one spoke of her name after that.

Then came the fire. The one that took the mill. The one that burned down the homes of the poor, the ones who dared to speak of injustice. The villagers blamed the wind, the curse of the land. But I saw the truth — the magistrate, the one who ordered the fire, he had a secret. He had been stealing from the poor, from the widows, from the orphans. And when I saw the way he looked at me — not with fear, but with *recognition* — I knew: he had seen me. He had seen the power I carried, even then.

I didn’t know what it was. I only knew that when I stood in the garden at night, with the moon high and the stars like cold eyes, I could feel something stir in me — a whisper, a pull. A voice that said, *You are not powerless. You are not weak. You are the one who remembers what was lost.*

So I began to learn. Not from books, not from the church. From the earth. From the old women who lived in the hills, who spoke in riddles and sang songs that made the trees bend. I learned to listen. To feel the pulse of the land. To see the truth in the cracks of stone, in the way the wind moves through the reeds.

And when I first cast a spell — not for power, not for revenge, but to save a child from a fever that no doctor could cure — I felt it. A warmth, a surge, like blood returning to a body.
