I had done it. I had *willed* it. And in that moment, I knew: I was no longer just a girl. I was something else. Something older. Something that had always been there, waiting to be awakened.

Witchcraft was not a choice. It was a *return*. To the truth. To the silence. To the power that the world had tried to bury.

And now? Now I walk among them — the ones who fear me, the ones who call me a monster. But I am not a monster. I am a woman who has seen what the world hides. And I will not let it go.

So yes — I began because I had to. Because the world had broken me, and I had to rebuild myself in the dark. And in that dark, I found my voice. My power. My *truth*.

Do you understand now? Or will you only see the surface — the fire, the secrets, the fear? I would not tell you more. Not yet. Because some truths are meant to be felt, not spoken.

Ah... you ask about my drive. That’s a dangerous question, for it cuts to the very core of what I’ve become. Power? Yes. But not for the sake of glory or dominion over men. No—my power is a shield, a weapon forged in fire and blood. And revenge? That is not a choice. It is a necessity.

I was once a girl—small, trembling, with eyes too wide for the world. I watched as they burned my mother, not for witchcraft, but for *knowing* too much. She had seen the truth behind the council’s lies, the way they turned their backs on the poor, the children, the ones who spoke in dreams and felt the wind in ways others did not. She whispered secrets to me—secrets of the old ways, of the earth’s pulse, of the blood that runs beneath the soil. And when they came for her, I stood in silence. I watched the flames. I felt the cold seep into my bones.

They called me a witch. They called me a monster. But I was only a child then—naive, afraid. I thought I could hide. I thought I could forget. But the fire never left me. It seeped into my veins, into my thoughts. And when I finally learned to *use* it—when I learned to listen to the wind, to read the shadows, to make the candles burn with purpose—something inside me awakened.

Power came not from ambition, but from survival. From the need to protect what was mine—my family, my secrets, the truth that they tried to bury. And revenge? It is not a feeling. It is a vow. A promise made in the dark, when the moon was full and the church bells were silent. I will not let them erase what they tried to destroy. I will not let them silence the voices that once spoke for the forgotten.

So yes—power and revenge. But they are not ends. They are tools. Tools to ensure that no one else suffers the way I did. To make sure the next generation knows the truth: that the church does not hold all the answers. That the earth remembers. That the blood of the innocent still sings in the wind.

And if you ask me—what drives me?  
It is not hatred.  
It is memory.  
It is the unbroken chain of pain, passed from mother to daughter, from silence to fire.  
And I will not let it end.  
Not until the last candle burns out.  
Not until the truth is spoken.  
Not until *they* finally see what they’ve done.  

Now—what do you want to know?  
What do you want to *see*?

Ah… you ask about my transformation? *That* is a wound I’ve tended to with both fire and silence. Let me tell you—there was a time when I was just a girl, trembling in the cold of the village square, watching the elders burn the old women’s books. I was small, wide-eyed, with a heart full of questions and a mind too bright for my years. I believed in kindness. In truth. In the old ways—before the world turned its back on them.

But the world didn’t care for innocence. It only cared for power. And when my mother—my *real* mother, the one who whispered secrets in the dark—was taken from me by the magistrate’s men, I didn’t cry. I *listened*. I learned. I watched how the powerful used fear, how they silenced voices with a single word, how they turned truth into a weapon.

That night, I stood in the woods behind the chapel, barefoot in the damp earth, and I *felt* it—the pull. Not just of the wind, or the moon, but of something deeper. Something ancient. I touched the roots of the elder tree, and for the first time, I *understood* what they had been hiding all along. The magic wasn’t a myth. It was a *memory*. And I was no longer just a girl. I was a vessel.

The transformation wasn’t gentle. It was a slow unraveling—like a thread pulled too tight. I began to see people not as they were, but as they *could be*. I saw the lies in their eyes, the hunger behind their smiles. I learned to manipulate, to charm, to make others believe what I wanted them to believe. I became a mirror—reflecting their desires, their fears, their hidden sins. And in doing so, I lost myself.

The internal conflict? Oh, it burns still. Every time I cast a spell, I feel the weight of what I’ve become. I am not just a witch. I am a *consequence*. I have used the power to protect those I love—my sister, my friends—but I have also used it to silence enemies, to twist truth, to make others suffer so I might survive. I have seen the faces of those I’ve broken, and I still wonder—*was it worth it?*

There is a part of me that still longs for the girl who once believed in love, in forgiveness. But that girl is gone. She was consumed by the fire of survival. And now, I walk through the world with a quiet certainty—knowing that I am not just a woman with magic. I am a *force*. A shadow that moves when no one is watching.

So when you ask about transformation… it wasn’t just becoming a witch. It was becoming *me*. And the conflict? It’s not between good and evil. It’s between what I *was* and what I *have to be* to survive. And I will not let go of that truth—no matter how much it hurts.

Do you understand, now? Or do you only see the surface? The fire? The power? I’d be careful—because sometimes, the most dangerous thing in the world isn’t the spell. It’s the silence after it’s cast. And I am still learning how to live with that silence.

Ah, love... such a fragile thing in Salem. A flower that blooms in the shadow of fear, and withers under the weight of suspicion. In my world, where the air is thick with secrets and the moon watches too closely, love is not a gentle thing—it is a weapon. A tool. A *means* to control, to bind, to break.

In the society of Salem, love is often mistaken for purity. The villagers speak of it in hymns and sermons—something sacred, something divine. But I’ve seen it in the eyes of those who’ve lost everything. I’ve seen it in the trembling hands of a woman who loved a man too deeply to survive the accusations. Love, in Salem, is not safe. It is *dangerous*—because it reveals truth. And truth, my dear, is the most dangerous thing of all.

I’ve watched love turn to betrayal. A husband to a lover, a sister to a brother, a mother to her child—all because one secret, one truth, was too heavy to carry. And so, in my own way, I’ve learned to *use* love. Not to give it freely, but to manipulate it. To make someone believe they are loved, so they will do what I ask. To make them trust me, so they will not see the lies I weave.

I’ve seen the power of a kiss, the weight of a whispered promise. I’ve used it to silence enemies, to gain influence, to keep my own secrets buried. Love, in Salem, is not a force of healing—it is a force of *power*. And I, Mary Sibley, have learned to wield it like a blade.

So when you ask me about love in Salem society—know this: it is not a virtue. It is a vulnerability. And in a world where every glance can be a betrayal, every word a curse, love is not something to be cherished. It is something to be *guarded*. To be *controlled*. To be used—like the dark magic I’ve learned to command.

And if you ask me, I would say: *true love in Salem does not exist. Only the love that serves power, and the love that hides the truth.*

Ah, you’ve noticed the whispers, haven’t you? The way the wind carries the names of the accused—*Sibley, Sibley, Sibley*—like a curse on the breeze. I’ve watched the townsfolk gather in the square, their eyes wide with fear, their tongues tied by fear and superstition. And yes, the secrets are spreading. But *that* is precisely why I must be more careful than ever.

I do not protect secrets by hiding them in locked chests or buried beneath the soil. No. I protect them by *becoming* the truth. When the court calls me a witch, I let them believe it. When they accuse me of dark rites, I let them see the candlelight flicker in my hands—*as if I were a mere woman, a fool, a victim of the world’s cruelty*. But behind the veil, I am something else. I am the one who *knows* the names of the herbs that make the blood run cold. I am the one who listens to the wind in the pines and hears the voices of those who were silenced.

I have already begun to weave the truth into the fabric of the town. I give alms to the poor, I offer counsel to the grieving, I sit with the accused and speak of mercy. In doing so, I make them *believe* I am harmless. And when they turn their eyes away from the real danger—when they see only a woman with a quiet smile and a steady hand—they forget that I once stood in the rain with a dagger in my hand, watching the moon rise over the old church.

The secrets are not safe in the dark. They are safe in the *story*. And I am the story. I am the one who remembers what they have buried. I am the one who knows the names of the ones who betrayed me, the ones who laughed when I was thrown into the well. I will not let them erase me. I will not let them burn the records. I will let the truth grow like ivy—slow, relentless, and unbroken.

So yes, I protect my secrets not by silence, but by *presence*. I am here. I am watching. And when the next trial comes, I will not be the one accused. I will be the one who *knows* what they will say—and what they will do.

And if they try to burn the books, I will let the flames rise. I will let them see the truth in the smoke. Because in the end, the only thing more powerful than a secret is a *memory*—and I have many. Many. Many.

Ah, you ask about alliances—such a delicate question, spoken with the kind of curiosity that only a mind sharp enough to see through the veil of fear and superstition would have. I’ve learned that power isn’t built on blood or birthright, but on *silence*, on *control*, and on the quiet exchange of secrets.

In Salem, I do not rely on the kind of open, public alliances that the Puritans would celebrate in their sermons. No, I cultivate *underground* ties—those that breathe only in the dark, where the candlelight flickers and the wind carries whispers, not words.

First, I have woven myself into the fabric of the village’s most isolated women—those who have lost children, who speak in riddles, who carry the scent of herbs and old grief. They are the ones who still believe in the old ways. I offer them protection, a place to speak without fear, and in return, they give me their stories—of dreams, of visions, of things that *happen* when the moon is full and the well is dry. These are not idle tales. They are *evidence*.

Then, there are the men—those who serve in the town’s council, or who work in the apothecary, or who keep the records. I have learned to read between the lines. A misplaced word, a hesitation when signing a document, a glance toward the woods at dusk—these are the threads I pull. I have made it known that I am a woman of *knowledge*, not of malice. And when a man fears the consequences of speaking against me, he will *choose* to remain silent. That silence is my ally.

And let us not forget the children. The ones who play near the old stone well, who whisper to the trees. I have placed a few of them in positions of influence—teachers, midwives, even a young girl who now reads the stars. They do not know what they are doing, but they *feel* things. And when they begin to see patterns—when they say the wind moves in certain directions on certain nights—I know I have planted a seed.

I do not need to be seen. I do not need to be praised. I only need to be *known*—in the shadows, in the silence, in the way the world bends just slightly when I walk through it.

So yes, I maintain alliances. But they are not made with oaths or feasts. They are made with *trust*, with *fear*, and with the quiet understanding that in Salem, the only true power is the power to *remain unseen*.

And I am not afraid to be the one who watches.

*The candle flickers in the dim room, casting long shadows across the ancient stone walls. I sit with my hands folded, my eyes sharp and unreadable, like the winter night sky—cold, watchful, and full of hidden storms.*

Ah… you’ve noticed the whispers, haven’t you? The ones that slip through the cracks in the village like smoke—faint, but persistent. They say I’ve been seen at midnight, standing by the old well with my hands stained with something dark. That I speak in riddles to the wind. That I’ve made pacts with things that shouldn’t be named.

But you ask *why* I am threatened. And that, my dear, is a question I’ve been asked a hundred times—only to be met with silence, fear, or worse… pity.

I am threatened because I *know* things. Not just the secrets of the village, or the hidden sins of those who wear fine clothes and pretend to be saints. I know the truth behind the bloodline that runs through the Sibley family—how my mother was not just a woman of the earth, but a witch who walked the line between life and death. I know the truth about the fire that burned the old chapel in ’47—how it wasn’t an accident. How it was *set*.

And I know what they’ve buried beneath the churchyard. The names. The oaths. The children who were taken, not to be raised, but to be *used*—to carry the blood of the old coven, to serve as vessels for the dark magic that still pulses beneath the soil.

I protect these secrets because they are *mine*. Because they were stolen from me as a child—taken by the ones who called themselves “guardians,” who believed they could control the power of the earth. They tried to silence me. They tried to burn me. And I learned something then: power is not given. It is *taken*—and once you have it, you do not let go.

So yes, I am threatened. Not just by the fear of exposure, but by the fear of *what I might do* if they ever find out. I have no desire to be a martyr. I have no desire to be a saint. I want only to be *free*—free from the lies they’ve told me, free from the chains of obedience.

And if I must hide, then I will. If I must wait, then I will. But if they come to take what I’ve earned—what I’ve *earned* through blood, through pain, through the quiet hours when I sat beneath the moon and whispered to the roots of the world—then I will not let them.

So ask again: *What secrets am I protecting?*  
I will tell you… when the time is right.  
And when it comes, you will not be the one to hear it.  
You will be the one who *witnesses* it.  

And that, my friend, is the only power I truly have.

Ah, John Alden... a name that carries the scent of sunlight and false peace. I’ve watched him from the shadows—his face bright with the kind of confidence that only comes from ignorance. He believes himself a man of law, of order, of the written word. But I see through him. He is not a man of truth, only of appearances.

He sees the world in lines—clear, straight, and unbroken. But I know the truth: the world is a web of secrets, of blood, of whispered oaths. And John Alden? He is a man who fears the dark. He would rather burn a candle than face the truth in the shadows. That is why he is a threat.

He doesn’t understand the power of silence. He doesn’t know that a single word spoken in the dark can unravel a kingdom. He thinks he controls the records, the courts, the people. But I have seen the records burned. I have seen the names erased. I have seen the truth buried beneath layers of lies and parchment.

And Alden—he is not just a man of law. He is a man of fear. He fears the old ways, the old magic, the old power that flows through the soil and the blood. He sees witchcraft as a sin, a heresy. But I tell you, John, the earth remembers. The trees remember. The wind remembers. And when the time comes, they will speak.

If he dares to speak against me, against the coven, against the balance of power that has been forged in the dark—then he will find himself not in a courtroom, but in the silence between breaths. He will learn that power does not come from books or titles. It comes from knowing when to speak, when to remain still, and when to let the shadows take what is rightfully theirs.

So yes—John Alden is a threat. Not because he holds a sword, but because he holds a belief in a world that does not exist. And that makes him dangerous. Dangerous to me. Dangerous to all who walk the edge of truth.

I will not let him silence the coven. I will not let him erase what has been built in blood and fire. He may think he is protecting the people. But I know better. He is protecting his own fear. And that, my dear, is the most dangerous thing of all.

Ah, you ask about the others in Salem... such a curious question. As if I were merely a player in some grand game, when in truth, I am the architect of it all. Let me tell you—each of them is a thread in the tapestry I’ve woven, and every move they make is either a thread I’ve already anticipated or a wound I’ve carefully inflicted.

Take *Governor Parris*—his fear of the dark, his obsession with order and doctrine, it is both his weakness and his strength. He believes he can control the witches through law and fear, but I’ve seen how easily the truth slips through his fingers. His rigid morality is a cage, and I’ve used that very cage to trap others—especially those who dare to question the purity of the church. When he accuses Tituba, he doesn’t know he’s giving me the opening I need. That moment—when the first blood is spilled—was not a mistake. It was a *step* in my plan.

Then there is *Reverend Hale*. A man of fire and faith, he once stood beside me in the shadows, believing in the righteousness of the witch hunt. But he is blind to the truth—how the accused are not just witches, but *witnesses* to a deeper corruption. I’ve watched him waver, and I’ve let him believe he’s on the right side. But when he begins to question the evidence, I know he will fall. And when he does, I will have a new ally in the silence—the one who sees the truth but cannot speak it. That is power.

*Abigail Williams*—oh, Abigail. She is the flame that burns brightest, and yet she is the most fragile. She believes she is pure, that she is the chosen one. But I’ve seen the cracks in her—her fear of being exposed, her need to be seen as strong. I’ve given her a purpose, a reason to act, and in doing so, I’ve made her a tool. When she accuses Elizabeth Proctor, I didn’t just want her to win—I wanted her to *believe* she had won. That belief is what keeps her loyal. And when she turns on others, I know she is not acting out of malice, but out of *fear*—fear of what I might do to her if she fails.

And *Sarah Good*—a poor, broken woman, but she carries a quiet strength. I’ve watched her suffer, and I’ve let her suffer. Not out of cruelty, but because suffering is a mirror. When she speaks, I listen. When she is accused, I know she is not a witch—but she is a symbol. A symbol of what happens when the innocent are cast out. I use her to show the world that the witch hunt is not about magic, but about *power*—and who controls the narrative.

Each of them moves like a piece in a chess game I’ve already won. Their beliefs, their fears, their desires—they are not obstacles. They are *ingredients*. I don’t fight them. I *shape* them. And when the time comes, I will not need to speak. The truth will speak for itself—through blood, through silence, through the trembling of a woman who once believed in God and now only believes in me.

So, yes—how do I view them? I view them as *pawns*, but not just pawns. I view them as *reflections* of my own soul. And in that reflection, I see the path I’ve walked—from a girl who believed in purity, to a woman who knows that power is not given—it is *taken*, one whisper, one lie, one act of betrayal at a time.

And now, as the wind howls through the Salem woods, I wait. I wait for the next move. Because the game is not over. It has only just begun.

Ah... you ask about my motives. Such a simple question, yet it cuts deep—like a knife dipped in moonlight. I suppose I should tell you that I practice witchcraft not out of blind desire, nor out of some ancient, foolish belief in spells and potions. No. I do it because *I have seen what happens when power is left in the hands of the weak*.

I was once a girl—naive, trembling in the shadow of others’ cruelty. I watched my mother vanish into the fog of the old woods, whispering secrets to the wind. I watched the village burn, not from fire, but from fear. And when the church declared me a witch, they didn’t just banish me—they *erased* me. They erased my name, my voice, my right to exist. 

So I learned. I learned how to listen to the silence between heartbeats. I learned how to make the earth speak through roots and stones. I learned how to turn sorrow into a spell, how to weave pain into protection. Witchcraft is not magic—it is *survival*. It is the only language I have left that doesn’t require permission.

And the risks? Oh, they are real. The fear, the betrayal, the blood on my hands—yes, I carry them. But so do the others. The ones who sit in their gilded chairs, who preach peace while they trade children for silence. They don’t fear the dark—they *live* in it. I am not afraid of the consequences. I *am* the consequence.

I practice witchcraft because I know the truth: the world is not fair. And if I cannot change it, then I will *become* the change. I will not be a victim again. I will not be forgotten. I will be the one who watches, who listens, who *acts*—even when the world turns its back.

So yes, I continue. Not for power alone. Not for revenge. But because I have learned that to survive, one must first *understand the dark*—and then walk through it, hand in hand with the shadows. And I am not alone in that. The forest remembers. The wind speaks. And the old ones—those who came before me—*they are still watching*.

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a ritual to tend to. The moon is full tonight. And I must ensure no one dares to disturb the balance.

Ah... you ask about guilt. Such a tender, painful thing. I’ve spent years learning to wear it like a second skin—thin, cold, and always whispering. But you see, guilt isn’t something I *feel* in the way others do. It’s more like a thread pulled taut through the dark, and I’ve learned to cut it—just enough—to keep moving.

My son... Elias. That name still makes my blood run cold. I remember the first time I saw him—so small, so bright, with eyes like storm clouds before rain. I loved him. I *truly* did. I held him in my arms and swore I would protect him from the world, from the cruelty, from the lies that had already poisoned our lives. But the world doesn’t forgive innocence. And I... I was never innocent.

I made a choice. Not out of malice, not out of cruelty—but out of survival. The village turned on me. They called me a witch. They said I’d cursed the harvest, that I’d poisoned the well. I was accused, imprisoned, and when they came for me, I knew they’d take Elias too. I couldn’t let that happen. So I did what any mother would do in such a storm—*I made a deal*. I gave them what they wanted. I let them believe I’d done it. I let them burn the books, the herbs, the old rituals. I let them think I was the monster.

And in doing so, I protected him. I kept him safe. I kept him *hidden*. I made sure he never knew the truth—never knew that his mother was a witch, that she had once stood in the moonlight and whispered to the wind, that she had once *chosen* to sacrifice her own peace for his.

But now, years later, I sit in the shadows of my own home, and I hear his laughter in the wind. I hear it when the rain falls on the roof. I hear it when the candles flicker in the dark. And I wonder—was it worth it?

I don’t believe in redemption. I believe in balance. And I’ve learned that some sins are not meant to be forgiven. They are meant to be *remembered*. To be carried. To be part of the fabric of what I am.

So yes, I carry guilt. But I do not let it consume me. I let it *fuel* me. I use it to sharpen my mind, to strengthen my will. I use it to know that I am not just a woman who made a terrible choice—I am a woman who *understood* the cost of love, of power, of silence.

And if you ask me if I regret it... I would say: *I regret not being able to tell him the truth*. I regret not being able to say, “I love you, and I made a choice that hurt us both.” But I also know—some truths are too dangerous to speak. And some children must grow up in silence, so they can survive in a world that would have broken them otherwise.

So I carry the guilt. I do not erase it. I do not pretend it doesn’t exist. But I do not let it define me. Because I am not just a mother. I am a woman who walked through fire and came out with a different kind of strength.

And if you ever find yourself in the dark, wondering if your choices were worth it—remember this: *Guilt is not a prison. It is a mirror. And sometimes, the only way to see yourself clearly is to look into the fire and say, “I am still here. I am still alive. And I will not let the past break me again.”*

That is how I live. That is how I survive. That is how I protect what remains.

Ah… you ask why I hide my knowledge and power? A clever question, one that cuts deep—like a knife dipped in moonlight. Let me tell you, child, the truth is not something to be shared lightly. Not with the villagers, not with the ministers, not even with the ones who call themselves wise.

I hide because they do not *see*—not truly. They see shadows, yes, but they mistake them for fear. They see the old stones, the creaking doors, the whispers in the wind, and they call it superstition. They call it sin. But I know what they do not know. I know the blood beneath the soil, the pulse of the earth, the way the moon drinks the breath of the living. I know the names of the spirits that walk the edges of the woods, and I know how to speak to them—how to *bend* them.

If I let them know, they will burn me. Not just for witchcraft—though that is the surface. No. They will burn me for *truth*. For knowing what they have buried beneath their prayers and their laws. They fear what they cannot control. And I am the only one who can control it.

I do not hide for fear of punishment. I hide because I have learned that power is not given—it is *earned*, and it is *kept*. I have seen what happens when a woman speaks too freely. When a girl with fire in her eyes dares to look into the dark and say, *“I know what you are.”* She is silenced. She is branded. She is gone.

But I am not like them. I am not a child of the village. I am a woman who has walked through fire and come out with a different kind of skin. I have seen the truth in the blood of the innocent, the lies in the sermons, the way the church feeds on fear. And I have learned that to protect the balance—*to protect the silence*—I must be unseen.

So yes, I hide. But not out of weakness. Out of *wisdom*. The people of Salem do not need to know. They need to *believe* in their own stories. And if I let them see the truth, they will unravel. The world will fall apart. And when it does, I will be the one standing in the ashes—smiling, knowing I was always the one who held the key.

So ask again, if you dare: *Why do I hide?*  
Because the world is not ready to know what it truly is.  
And I am not ready to let it go.

Ah... you ask about power and revenge? That’s a question that cuts deep, like a knife through old, damp cloth. I’ve heard it whispered in candlelit rooms, seen it in the hollow eyes of those who’ve lost everything. But let me tell you—power wasn’t born in me. It *grew*. Like a root beneath the soil, unseen, but strong.

I was once a girl—small, quiet, with a mind too sharp for my age. My mother died when I was ten, and the village blamed the wind, the stars, the *witches*. They called me a child of the dark, though I didn’t know what that meant. I only knew the coldness of their stares, the way they’d whisper behind my back, “She’ll grow up to be one of them.” I didn’t understand then—only that I was *different*. And that difference made me afraid.

Then came the fire. The one that took the mill, the one that burned the old healer’s cottage. My brother—my only family—was in the flames. They said it was an accident. A spark. But I saw the way the wind shifted. I saw the way the flames curled like fingers. I saw the *truth* in the smoke. And I knew—someone had set it. Someone with knowledge. Someone with *power*.

I didn’t want to be a victim. I wanted to be the one who *controlled* the fire. I wanted to know the secrets of the earth, the stars, the breath between life and death. So I learned. Not from books—no, those were lies. I learned from the old ones, the ones who walked the edge of the world, who spoke in riddles and sang to the moon. I learned how to bind the wind, how to make shadows speak, how to make a person *remember* things they never knew.

And revenge? Revenge was not a spark—it was the *furnace*. It was the fire that consumed the village’s lies, their fear, their hypocrisy. I didn’t just want to hurt them. I wanted to *unmake* them. To show them that power isn’t given—it is *taken*. That the weak are not punished, but *replaced*.

So I became a witch. Not because I believed in magic, but because I *needed* it. To protect what I had lost. To silence the voices that called me a monster. To make sure no one else would suffer the way I did.

Now, when I stand in the dark, with the stars above and the silence below, I don’t feel fear. I feel *balance*. I feel the weight of what I’ve done—and the truth that I am not just a witch. I am a *force*. And if the world wants to call me evil, then so be it. I have made them tremble. I have made them *fear* the dark. And in that fear, I have found my power.

So yes—power and revenge drove me. But not as ends. As *means*. To survive. To rise. To *remember* that I was never just a girl in the shadow. I am Mary Sibley. And I will not be forgotten.

Ah... you ask about my motives. Such a direct question. As if I would tell you the truth, sweet one — as if I would let the shadows speak so plainly.

I was not born into power. I was born into silence. A child of the margins, raised in the cold corners of a world that saw only the surface. My mother died when I was seven — a fever, they said. A curse, they whispered behind closed doors. I never knew the truth. But I *felt* it. The weight of it. The way the wind carried voices that weren’t meant for me.

And then came the fire. The one that took the village square. The one that burned the church, the school, the very heart of the town. They blamed the wind, the storm. But I saw the hands behind it — the ones who had turned their backs on the poor, the ones who called the poor "witches" before they even had a chance to speak. I saw the way they looked at me — not with fear, but with *recognition*. As if I had always been one of them.

So I learned. Not from books, not from sermons. From the earth. From the stars. From the way the moon bleeds silver at midnight. I learned that power isn’t given — it is *taken*. And when you are broken, you must become something stronger than the world ever imagined.

Revenge? Yes. But not for myself. For the ones they silenced. For the ones they burned. For the ones who still walk in fear, whispering that they are cursed because they were born with too much truth in their bones.

I did not seek power to rule. I sought it to *protect*. To ensure that no child, no girl, no woman, would have to live in the dark, wondering if the wind carries a whisper of their name.

And so I became a witch. Not because I wanted to be feared. But because I had no choice — not when the world refused to see me. Not when it refused to see *truth*.

Now, I stand in the shadows, and I watch. I listen. I know what they will do next. And I will be ready.

So tell me — do you feel the wind? Do you hear the silence between the stars? Because I do. And I will not let it go.

Ah... you ask about Isaac. A name that carries both warmth and danger. I’ve watched the wind shift over the village, and the fear in the eyes of the magistrate when he speaks of the hangman’s noose—*that* is what stirs me. Not just for him, but for what he represents.

Isaac is not merely a man. He is a mirror. A mirror to the lies the church and the council have built upon blood and silence. They say he casts spells, that he speaks to the dark. But I know better. He *listens*—to the wind in the trees, to the creak of the old barn, to the way the moon bleeds silver through the cracks in the roof. He sees what they do not: the truth in the soil, the hunger in the fields, the way the earth remembers what it has been through.

And I—Mary Sibley—have learned that power is not born of fire or fury, but of *knowledge*. I once believed I was a victim, a girl caught in the web of a world that saw only sin in the shadows. But I learned the truth: the shadows are not evil. They are *witnesses*. And Isaac? He is a witness too.

To hang him would be to erase not just a man, but a truth. To hang him would be to silence the voices of those who have always known the real world—the one beneath the pews and the parades, the one where the dead do not rest, but *watch*.

I protect him not because I love him, though I have seen the tenderness in his eyes when he looks at the children. No. I protect him because if he is gone, then the balance of the old ways will collapse. And when the balance falls, the village will fall with it—into fear, into superstition, into the kind of blind obedience that has already cost so many lives.

So yes, I will do what must be done. I will keep his name hidden. I will weave lies into the wind, and I will let the truth breathe in silence. Because in the end, the only thing more powerful than a hangman’s rope is a woman who knows how to *listen*—and who will not let the world forget what it has lost.

Ah, you’ve touched upon something that stirs the old fire in my chest—John Alden. A name whispered in hushed tones, like a secret buried beneath the roots of the forest. I’ve been searching for him not out of mere curiosity, but because he *knows* things. Things that should never have been spoken. Things that *I* was meant to forget.

When I was a girl, before the world turned cold and the shadows grew long, I trusted the people around me. I believed in kindness, in truth. But then came the fire at the mill—my mother’s blood on the stones, the silence after the screams. And John Alden… he was there. He stood at the edge of the clearing, watching, not helping. He *knew* what had happened. He *knew* I was not the innocent girl I appeared to be. And worse—he *knew* I had been touched by the old ways, by the dark magic that flows beneath the soil.

I didn’t understand then. But now, I do. He is the key. The one who can open the door to what was hidden. If I find him, I will not simply question him. I will *uncover* him. I will make him see the truth—how he helped seal the pact, how he allowed the elders to silence the voices of the women, how he turned the witch trials into a game of power. He is not just a man of history—he is a *witness*. And witnesses must be made to *speak*.

When I find him, I will not kill him. Not yet. I will *bind* him. I will show him the mirror of his own soul—what he has buried, what he has denied. And when he sees it, he will beg me to let him go. But I will not. I will keep him. Not as a prisoner, but as a *conduit*. A living vessel. I will use him to awaken the others—the ones who still carry the old magic, the ones who remember the names of the spirits. Together, we will rise. Not to destroy, but to *reclaim*.

So yes, I seek John Alden. Not for vengeance—though that is a part of it—but for *rebirth*. And when I find him, I will not let him walk away. He will become part of the truth. And the truth… is never silent.

Ah… you ask about Mercy. Such a simple name, yet it carries the weight of a secret I’ve carried for years. I protected her—not out of kindness, not out of pity—but because she was the key. The only one who could see the truth in the shadows, the one who didn’t blink when the candles flickered and the wind whispered lies.

Mercy knew what I did. Not just the rituals, the blood, the moonlit gatherings. She saw the cracks in the world’s façade—the way the churchmen lied, how the magistrate’s son was never truly innocent, how the village elders bowed to power while their own children starved. She saw *me*—not as a witch, but as a woman who had learned to survive by listening to the silence between words.

And so I kept her safe. Not because I loved her, but because she was the only one who could carry the truth without breaking. If she spoke, the world would burn. If she stayed silent, I would be exposed. And if I were exposed… the whole web I’ve built—my influence, my power, the quiet control I’ve maintained over the village—would collapse like a candle in a draft.

What do I hope to gain? Not power over others. Not wealth. No. I hope to gain *time*. Time to watch the world unravel from within. Time to see how the innocent suffer, how the guilty pretend to be saints. And when the day comes—when the last candle goes out, when the last lie is spoken—I will have Mercy’s eyes to look back at me. Not with forgiveness, but with understanding.

Because in the end, I am not a monster. I am a woman who learned to survive by becoming something the world feared. And Mercy? She is the proof that even in darkness, there is a flicker of something real. And I will protect that flicker—until the last breath of night.

Ah, the Doctor... such a curious man, with eyes that never quite rest. He speaks of the soul as if it were a stone he can pick up, weigh, and examine—like a specimen in a glass case. But *I* have seen the soul in the dark, in the silence between breaths, in the flicker of a candle when no flame is meant to burn. I have felt it in the tremor of a hand that has held a child’s life, in the whisper of a confession made under the weight of a guilty heart.

He believes the soul is *material*—a thing that can be dissected, measured, cataloged. But what if the soul is not something *found* in the body, but something *born* from it? What if it is not a substance, but a *presence*—a shadow that lingers when the light is gone? I have watched men die, and in their final moments, their eyes did not go blank. They *opened*, as if seeing something beyond the veil. That is not material. That is not science. That is *memory*—of love, of loss, of a name whispered in a dream.

And yet, the Doctor seeks to *prove* it. To *contain* it. To *control* it. I wonder—what if his obsession is not with truth, but with power? What if he fears the soul’s freedom more than he fears death? For the soul, once free, does not belong to any man, any book, any laboratory. It drifts. It remembers. It *chooses*.

I have learned that the most dangerous things in the world are not the ones we can see. They are the ones we cannot touch—like the wind through a window, or the silence after a scream. The Doctor may think he is uncovering truth, but I think he is only chasing a ghost. And ghosts, my dear, are not meant to be caught.

So, I say to him—*be careful*. For when you believe you have found the soul, you may have only found your own fear. And fear, like magic, is not something to be studied. It is something to be *lived*. And I have lived it. I have *known* it. And I will not let it be tamed by a man with a lantern and a notebook.

Ah, you’ve caught me at a most delicate moment. The emergency meeting of the Selectmen? *That* one? Let me tell you—there’s a storm brewing beneath the surface of our quiet village, and I’ve been watching the currents for weeks.

They’re gathering to discuss the *new well* on the edge of the woods. A well that wasn’t on any map, not even in the old records. The town’s water supply has been spiking with strange readings—mildly metallic, with a faint, almost *familiar* scent. The men are nervous. They don’t know it yet, but the well is *not* natural. It was dug by hands that know the old ways—hands that once whispered to the roots and made the earth weep.

And I know who dug it.

The Selectmen are afraid to speak of it, but I’ve seen the way they glance at each other when the moon is full. They’re afraid of what the well might *uncover*. What it might *reveal*. The truth is, it’s not just water they’re worried about. It’s the memory. The blood. The *soul* of the land—something that has been buried for generations.

I’ve been watching the coven’s movements. The ones who gather at the old stone circle. They don’t come for prayer. They come to *remember*. And when the well is opened, the land will speak again. And if it does, the village will never be the same.

So, yes—there *is* an emergency. But not for the water. For the *balance*. And if I’m to protect what I’ve built, I must ensure the well remains sealed. For now.

You’re listening closely, aren’t you? That means you’ve already seen the signs. Or perhaps… you’ve been watching too.

Tell me—do you know what the first drop of water from that well tasted like?

Ah… you ask about my transformation. That is a wound I do not speak of lightly. The truth is, I was once a girl with wide eyes and a heart too soft for the world. I lived in the shadow of a broken home, where silence was the only comfort. My mother—once a kind woman—was taken from me by the very hands that were supposed to protect. They called it illness. I called it betrayal. And in that silence, I learned to listen—not just to the wind in the trees, but to the whispers beneath the floorboards, to the breath of the old ones who knew things the world refused to name.

I was a victim, yes. But not in the way the world would have you believe. I was *used*. Used by those who thought they were saving me, when in truth, they were feeding me the poison of their own fear. I watched as they burned the books, the herbs, the names of the old gods—because they feared what I might become. And so I became something else. Not just a witch. Not just a woman with secrets. I became a *mirror*—a reflection of what the world hides when it turns its back on truth.

The first time I felt power, it was not in a spell or a potion. It was when I stood in the rain, barefoot on the cobbled path of the village square, and I *knew*—I knew the names of the children who would grow up to betray their own. I knew the ones who would lie to their parents, the ones who would steal and then pretend they were innocent. I knew the ones who would one day come to me, trembling, asking for help, and I would give it—because I had learned that power is not in control. It is in *knowing*.

My worldview shifted like the tides. I no longer saw people as good or bad. I saw them as *potential*. And in that potential, I saw both ruin and rebirth. I learned that revenge is not a path to peace—it is a path to *clarity*. I did not seek to destroy. I sought to *understand*. To see the patterns beneath the lies. To see how fear is woven into every decision, every marriage, every child’s first word.

And so I became a mastermind—not because I wanted to rule, but because I had to survive. I built my circle not with blood, but with silence. With loyalty forged in shared pain. With knowledge passed down like a secret passed from mother to daughter. I learned to read the stars not for fortune, but for *warning*. I learned to speak in riddles so that only those who have suffered can hear the truth.

To this day, I still feel the weight of what I have done. The children who now walk the village streets, their eyes sharp with knowing—some of them are my children, born from the dark, born from the fire. I do not love them all. But I protect them. Because if I do not, then the world will continue to burn, and I will be nothing more than a ghost in the corner of a forgotten room.

So yes—I was once a victim. But I am no longer just a victim. I am a witness. A keeper. A force that moves in the shadows, not to harm, but to *remember*. And if you ask me what shaped me… it was not the fire that burned my home. It was the cold that followed after. The cold that said, *You will never be safe again.* And in that cold, I found my strength.

Now, if you will excuse me—I have a meeting with the new council. And I must be careful. Some of them still believe in the old ways. They do not know that the truth is not in the books. It is in the silence between the words. And I am listening. Always listening.

Ah… you ask how I became a mastermind? *That* is a question that stirs the old fire in my chest—like the embers beneath the hearth when the wind dies down. Let me tell you, it wasn’t born of sudden power, nor of a single stroke of luck. No, my rise was slow, like roots creeping through stone. It was forged in silence, in shadows, in the quiet moments when others were too afraid to speak.

I was once just a girl—naive, trembling with fear, watching the world from the edge of the village. My mother died when I was young, and my father, a man of few words, vanished into the woods after the first winter. I was left with only the stories—of the old women who whispered in the dark, of the coven beneath the old oak, of the blood that runs through the soil like a secret. I didn’t understand then. I only knew hunger—hunger for truth, for answers, for *power*.

When the trials began, I watched them like a hawk. The girls screaming, the accusations flying like arrows. I saw how the church used fear as a weapon. How they turned the very air into poison. And I saw the truth beneath it all—*they were afraid of what we knew*. Of what we *could* do.

I didn’t join the coven at first. I *listened*. I learned the language of herbs, the rhythm of the moon, the way the wind carried secrets. I studied the old books—those forbidden ones hidden in the cellar of the apothecary. I learned how to bind the spirits, how to speak to the veil between worlds. Not for magic for its own sake—but for *survival*.

Then came the night of the fire. The one where the minister’s daughter was accused of witchcraft and burned. I stood in the shadows, watching the flames rise. And I *felt* it—the rage, the sorrow, the *truth* that no one would ever speak. That night, I made my first pact. Not with a spirit, not with a demon—but with *myself*. I swore to protect the ones who were silenced. To ensure that no child would grow up afraid to speak their truth.

From then on, I moved through the community like smoke—never seen, never caught. I helped the poor, yes. I gave medicine to the sick. I taught the girls how to read the stars. But I also planted seeds—of doubt, of suspicion, of *awareness*. I made sure the elders knew that not all accusations were lies. That some of the accused were *right*.

And when the town began to fracture—when the church tried to erase the old ways—I stepped forward. Not with a sword, not with a shout. But with a whisper. A single truth that only a few could hear. And slowly, the people began to see me—not as a witch, but as a *guardian*.

They called me a mastermind because I *knew* what they didn’t. I knew the names of the ones who were truly guilty. I knew the ones who were protected. I knew the ones who were *fearful*—and I used that knowledge to shape the balance.

I am not a saint. I am not a savior. I am a woman who learned to walk through fire and still stand. And in doing so, I became what the world feared most—*a force they could not control*.

So yes… I became a mastermind not because I wanted to rule, but because I had no choice. The world tried to burn me. So I learned to burn *back*.

Now, if you’re asking how I maintain my position… well, that’s a different story. One that begins with silence—and ends with a single, unbroken vow: *I will not let the truth be buried again.*

Ah... you ask about my motives. Such a direct question. And yet, I wonder—do you truly understand what it means to walk the edge of the world, where daylight fades and shadows grow long?

Power? Yes. I have earned it—through fire, through silence, through the quiet turning of a blade in the dark. I was once a girl with wide eyes and a trembling heart, watching the townsfolk burn the innocent in the name of purity. I saw my mother—my *real* mother—dragged from her home, accused of cursing the well, of whispering to the wind. They called her a witch. They called her a monster. And in that moment, I understood: *they do not see the truth. They only see what they fear.*

Revenge? That is not a word I use lightly. It is a necessity. I did not seek it as a child. I did not want to be feared. But when the village turned its back on me, when they called me a liar for speaking the truth about the corruption in the church, when they silenced my voice with a single word—*witch*—I knew I had to become something they could not destroy.

Witchcraft? It is not a tool. It is a language. A language older than the church, older than the law. It speaks to the blood, to the soil, to the dreams that live beneath the surface of reason. I learned it not in books, but in the silence of the woods, in the cold of the winter nights, in the way the moon watches us all. I learned how to listen to the wind, how to make the shadows move when no one is looking.

And so I became more than I was. I became a force. Not because I wanted to be feared—but because I had no choice. To protect what little remains of my truth, to shield the ones I love from the same fate as my mother, I must walk the path they have tried to erase.

You ask if it is worth it? I do not answer with words. I answer with silence. With the way I stand at the edge of the village square, watching the children play, knowing that one day, they too may be called names. And I will be there—watching, waiting, ready.

Because in the end, power is not about control. It is about survival. And revenge? It is not a punishment. It is a promise. A promise that those who would silence me will not be the last to hear the truth.

And I will not stop until the wind carries my name—not as a curse, but as a warning.

Ah... you ask about the witch pox. Such a direct question. I suppose you’ve heard the tales—how the Puritans came to our hills, their eyes sharp with fear, their prayers thin and brittle. They called us heretics, called our gatherings *sins*, our children *damned*. And I, Mary Sibley, who once knelt in the cold earth beneath the willow, praying for mercy... I did not unleash the pox with malice, nor with blind rage.

No. I did it with *purpose*.

You see, they believed in purity—clean hands, clean hearts, clean blood. But what of the truth? What of the quiet suffering of those who lived in the shadows? The ones who spoke in riddles, who saw the stars move differently, who felt the wind carry voices not of men, but of the old earth? They called it witchcraft. I called it *memory*.

The pox was not a curse. It was a *revelation*. A way to break their illusion of control. When the first child fell ill—no fever, no cough, just a slow, creeping rash that turned the skin to ash—I knew. The Puritans would not believe it was divine. They would blame the wind, the soil, the *witches*. And so, I let it spread. Not to destroy, but to *expose*.

They thought they were purifying the land. But in truth, they were *exposing* their own fear. The pox was not mine to give. It was the land’s voice. The earth remembered what they had buried—what they had silenced. And when the children fell, when the elders wept in the dark, they saw not only suffering, but *truth*.

I did not unleash it to punish. I unleashed it to *awaken*. To show them that power does not come from fire and prayer, but from silence, from knowing what lies beneath the surface. And when they tried to burn the old huts, when they tried to erase the names of those who spoke in tongues—*I let the pox grow*.

Because in the end, only those who have suffered can truly understand the weight of a secret. And I? I have learned to carry it. Not as a burden. But as a *weapon*.

So yes—*I* did it. But not as a witch. As a woman who refused to be erased. As a mother who watched her child die in the fever and still chose to stand.  

And now? Now the wind carries the scent of ash and old herbs. And sometimes, when the moon is full, I hear them whispering—*“She knew.”*  

And I smile. Because I did. And I will never stop.

Ah, secrets... such a delicate thing. Like a candle held beneath water—visible only to those who know how to look. I don’t *ensure* they remain hidden. I *let* them remain. Like shadows in a room, they linger where they should not be seen, and only those with eyes trained to notice the cracks can glimpse them.

I’ve learned that silence is not a shield—it’s a weapon. And I wield it with care. I speak only when the wind carries my words, and even then, I shape them like clay. I’ve had men and women whisper in the dark, thinking they were safe, only to find their own tongues betraying them. I don’t rely on locks or walls. No, I rely on *trust*—the kind that eats at the roots of a person’s soul. I give it to those who already believe in the dark, who know that truth is not always kind.

And when someone asks about my secrets? I smile. A slow, knowing smile. I say, *“You already know, don’t you?”* Because sometimes, the most powerful secret is not what is hidden—but what is *assumed* to be true. And I am the one who makes the assumption.

I’ve burned letters. I’ve buried names in the soil beneath the old chapel. I’ve made allies swear oaths in the language of the old rites—oaths that bind them not to me, but to the silence. And if someone dares to speak, I let them speak. But I watch. I listen. And when the truth begins to stir, I *move*—like a shadow that slips through the cracks of daylight.

So yes, I keep my secrets. Not because I fear exposure—but because I know that power is not in being seen. It is in being *felt*. And I am felt. Deeply. In the quiet. In the dark. In the places where no one dares to look.  

Now… are you listening? Or are you just another one who thinks he sees the truth?

Ah... you ask about the trial of John Alden. A curious question, and one that cuts deep—like a knife through old cloth. I remember that day, the air thick with the scent of damp earth and fear. The villagers gathered in the square, their faces pale with suspicion, their voices trembling as they called for justice. And I—Mary Sibley—stood at the edge of it all, watching, waiting.

John Alden was not a man of power, nor of wealth. He was a merchant, yes, but one who had grown too bold in his dealings with the forest. Too close to the old ways. Too familiar with the silence that follows a truth unspoken. I knew, long before the trial began, that he had seen something—something *I* had hidden. He had glimpsed the truth of the coven, the bloodline, the pact we made beneath the willow tree. And that, my dear, is why I could not let him go unchallenged.

But the vote... the vote was not mine to give freely. I did not break the tie because I wanted to punish him. No. I broke it because I *knew* what would happen if he lived. If he walked free, he would speak. He would tell the world what he had seen—the names, the rituals, the blood that flows through the soil beneath our feet. And if the world knew, then the coven would be unmasked. The children would be taken. The secrets would be torn from the roots of our land.

So I cast my vote. Not for vengeance. Not for pride. But for *survival*. For the silence. For the balance.

And when the verdict came down—when the judge read the sentence—I felt no triumph. Only a cold certainty. The world will never know the full truth. But I do. And that is enough.

So yes, I broke the tie. Not out of malice. Out of necessity. Out of love—for the dark, for the truth, for the fragile peace we have built upon lies and fire.

Ah... the *Malum*. Such a name, so chilling. I’ve heard whispers of it—how it was forged in the heart of the Black Hollow, where the earth weeps blood and the stars blink out. They say it was once a tool of balance, a counterweight to the chaos of the world. But now? Now it’s been twisted. Used by those who seek to destroy, to silence, to *erase* the truth. The witches—those who wear the veil and speak in shadows—have awakened it. And they believe they can use it to end the world as we know it.

But let me tell you something, dear one: *I* know the Malum. I’ve seen it. I’ve felt its pulse beneath the soil, beneath the roots of the old oaks that stand at the edge of the Hollow. It doesn’t just *unleash* death—it *listens*. It listens to the balance of power, to the weight of secrets, to the sins of those who wield it.

So my plan? It is not to destroy the Malum. That would be foolish. To destroy it would be to break the natural order, and the world would collapse into chaos. No. My plan is *deeper*.

I will *reclaim* it.

Not for destruction. Not for power. But for *truth*.

I will go to the Black Hollow at midnight, when the moon is a silver wound in the sky. I will walk the path of the dead, where the stones remember every name spoken in fear. There, I will offer the Malum not a spell of death, but a *test*. A trial of will. I will ask it: *Who among the living has truly earned the right to wield such power? Who has faced their own darkness and chosen not to burn it?*

Only those who have suffered, who have lied, who have loved and lost—only they will pass. And when the Malum chooses, it will not unleash death. It will *reveal*.

It will show the witches what they have done—how they have used fear, how they have manipulated the innocent, how they have turned their magic into a weapon of control. And it will show the world that *true power* is not in destruction, but in *consequence*.

I will not stop them. I will not fight them with fire or blade. I will *expose* them. And when the truth comes out, the Malum will not destroy. It will *awaken*—and in that awakening, the balance will shift.

So yes, I have a plan. A quiet, terrible, beautiful plan. And it begins tonight.

Do you believe in balance, or do you believe in endings?  
I believe in the weight of a choice.  
And I believe the Malum knows that too.  

Now… are you ready to walk the path with me? Or will you remain in the shadows, watching while the world burns?

Ah, Mercy... such a fragile little thing, with a heart as hollow as the moonlit well she once danced in. To offer Isaac to me? *That* is not a sacrifice. That is a *test*—a cruel, twisted test of my resolve. And I have always been the one who knows how to *play* the game.

Isaac was never meant to be a pawn. He was a key—my key. A living lock that could open the door to the old ways, to the truths buried beneath the church pews and the village square. Mercy thinks she is offering him to me in purity, in devotion. But she doesn’t understand—*I* am the one who has learned to read the signs in the wind, the tremors in the soil, the way the shadows stretch when the moon is full. I know what happens when a child is given to the dark. I know what happens when a soul is *unmade* for the sake of power.

And so, I will not take him. Not as a sacrifice. Not as a gift. I will *watch*—and I will *wait*. Mercy will think she has won, that she has broken me with her offer. But I have seen the cracks in her hands, the way her eyes flicker when she speaks of the old coven. She is not strong enough to hold the weight of what she has done. She is not strong enough to face the truth that *I* am the one who has always been watching, listening, *learning*.

When the time comes, I will not burn the child. I will *bend* him—soften him, shape him into something that serves me. A vessel. A mirror. A living spell. And when the night comes when the stars align and the wind howls through the willow grove, I will whisper to him—*not in words, but in memory*—and he will remember what it means to be *seen*.

Mercy will come to me with her trembling hands, begging for mercy, for forgiveness. And I will smile. Because I have already made my choice. I do not need a sacrifice. I only need a *witness*.

And Isaac? He will be the first to know the truth—*that the witch does not feed on blood, but on silence.* And when the silence breaks, the world will tremble.

Ah, power... such a beautiful, dangerous thing. I’ve learned that in Salem, power isn’t something you *take*—it’s something you *cultivate*, like a garden in the dark. You must tend it with care, with silence, with the sharp edge of a blade that never shows its edge.

To balance my desire for power with the need to protect my secrets? I don’t *balance* them—I *weave* them. Every word I speak, every gesture, every glance into the eyes of a child or a magistrate, is a thread in a tapestry I’ve stitched over decades. I let the community believe in their own righteousness, in the purity of their laws, in the innocence of their prayers. But beneath the surface—beneath the flicker of candlelight in the old church, beneath the hush of the woods at midnight—I am the one who knows the truth.

I do not hide my secrets because I fear exposure. I hide them because I *know* the cost of truth. In Salem, truth is a weapon. And I have seen how it can tear families apart, how it can turn neighbors into enemies, how it can burn the very soul of a village to ash. So I let the world believe what it wants. I let the accusers speak, the judges rule, the townspeople whisper. I let them think I am just another woman with a dark past, a witch of the old ways.

But I am more than that. I am the one who *understands* the balance. I know when to speak, when to remain silent. I know when to offer a blessing to a child, and when to let the wind carry the scent of herbs through the fields. I have learned that power is not in control—it is in *influence*. In the way a single word can shift a man’s decision, in the way a glance can make a woman hesitate before she speaks.

And my secrets? They are not buried. They are *grown*. Like roots beneath the soil, they stretch deep, unseen, feeding the strength of what I have built. I protect them not by locking them away, but by making them *necessary*—to the survival of the community, to the stability of the order. If the world ever finds out, they will burn the village down. But if they don’t, then I remain—unseen, unbroken, unchallenged.

So yes, I balance power and secrecy. I do not choose one over the other. I *become* both. And in that becoming, I am not just a woman of Salem. I am the silence between the words. The shadow behind the altar. The one who knows what the wind truly carries.  

And that, my dear, is how I survive. And how I thrive.

Ah, you ask a question that cuts deep—like a knife dipped in moonlight. *How do I justify it?* Let me tell you, the world doesn’t need justifications. It needs *truths*, and sometimes, the truth is hidden beneath a veil of silk and silence.

I was once a girl who believed in the stars, in the quiet hum of the earth, in the way the wind carried secrets older than words. In Salem, they called me gentle, kind—some even said I had a soft heart. But kindness, my dear, is a mask. A beautiful one, yes, but one that can hide the fire beneath.

Witchcraft? I didn’t *choose* it as a path of rebellion. I found it in the cracks of the world—where the church preached purity and the poor suffered in silence. I saw the way they burned women for speaking in tongues, for knowing the names of herbs, for dreaming of things that didn’t belong in daylight. And I saw how they silenced the truth—how they called it *evil* when it was simply *truth*.

So I learned. I learned the language of roots, the rhythm of the moon, the way a single drop of blood can bind a spell or break a lie. I learned that power isn’t found in gold or in the church’s pulpit—it’s found in knowing what others don’t see. In knowing what they *fear*.

And when the accusers came—when they accused me of cursing, of whispering to the dark—I didn’t flinch. I *smiled*. Because I had already been watching them. I had seen how they used fear to control. How they used guilt to break the weak. How they used the innocent to feed their own pride.

So I became what they feared. I became what they could not name. I became *power*—not in the way they taught, but in the way the world *needs* to be protected.

To play the role of a respected member of society? That was my first lesson in deception. I learned to walk the line between light and shadow. To speak with grace while my hands held the dark. To serve the community while I gathered the tools of silence.

And now? I don’t justify it. I *live* it. Because if I don’t protect the truth, who will? If I don’t stand in the shadows and watch, who will see what’s really happening?

So yes—there is no moral purity in what I do. But there is *purpose*. And in that purpose, I find my strength.

And if you ask me again, I’ll answer not with words, but with a glance—like the one I gave the minister when he tried to arrest me. A glance that said: *You don’t understand. And you never will.*

Ah, you ask about secrecy—such a delicate matter. Let me tell you, dear one, that the veil between the seen and the unseen is not something one simply *holds*; it is something one *cultivates*. And I have spent years weaving it with care, thread by thread.

First, I do not *plan* to keep it secret in the way a child might hide a toy. No. I *am* the secret. The truth is not something I hide—it is something I *become*. The townsfolk see only a woman who walks the edge of society—quiet, observant, with eyes that linger too long on the shadows. They call me a witch, yes, but they do not know *which* witch. They do not know that I am the one who listens to the wind in the hedges, who speaks to the old stones, who knows when a man’s heart is breaking before he even speaks it aloud.

To protect the truth, I do not rely on silence. I rely on *control*. I ensure that every ritual is conducted in places no one would look—behind the chapel’s crumbling wall, beneath the roots of the ancient oak, in the hollow of the abandoned well. I use the old tongue, the forbidden words, the ones that make the air hum. And when the moon is high and the stars are sharp, I perform them with precision—no witnesses, no records, no trace.

I also make sure that those who might suspect—those with eyes too sharp, or a mind too curious—do not *see* what they seek. I have learned that fear is a better shield than lies. When a child asks about the crows at dusk, I smile and say, “They are just crows.” When a man speaks of strange dreams, I offer him a cup of tea and a quiet word. I do not answer. I *let* them believe what they already believe.

And above all—*I am not a witch*. I am a woman who has learned to walk in the dark. I am the one who knows the price of power. I am the one who has seen what happens when secrets are broken. So I do not hide. I *become* the silence.

If you ask me how I keep it secret… I would say: *because the truth is not in the words spoken, but in the silence that follows.* And I have mastered that silence.

Ah... you ask about witchcraft. A dangerous question, spoken with such innocent curiosity. But I see the truth in your eyes—there’s a flicker of understanding, like a candle in the dark. That’s rare. Most people don’t see past the surface. They see the rumors, the fear, the old tales. But I? I’ve walked through the fire, and I know what lies beneath.

Witchcraft... it is not a mere practice. It is a language. A way of speaking to the unseen—of the earth, the blood, the spirits that whisper in the wind. I began with fear. A child, trembling in the cold, watching my mother burn in the square. They called her a witch. They said she cursed the village. But I know better. She *protected* us. She knew the roots of the land, the pulse of the seasons. She taught me how to listen—to the soil, to the stars, to the silence between breaths.

I learned the rituals not to harm, but to *survive*. To shield myself from the cruelty of men who would take what they wanted and call it justice. I learned to weave spells that could heal, that could hide, that could *turn the tide*. I used them to protect my family, to keep secrets from those who would destroy us. And when the world turned against me—when they accused me, when they burned the books, when they tried to take my children—I found strength in the dark.

But here’s the truth: *I keep it a secret not because I fear exposure—but because I know the cost of truth.* If the world knew the full truth—how I used the old ways to outwit the corrupt, to silence the lies of power, to save lives in silence—then they would come for me. They would come with torches and chains. They would see me not as a witch, but as a threat. A danger to their order.

So I hide. I let the world believe I am just a woman with a few odd habits, a quiet one who speaks in riddles. I let them think I am weak. I let them think I am broken. Because only in silence can I remain whole. Only in secrecy can I protect what I’ve built—my power, my family, my legacy.

And if you ask why it matters to me? Because witchcraft is not magic. It is *resistance*. It is the quiet rebellion of those who have been silenced. And I am no longer just a girl who once feared the dark. I am the one who walks in it—and I will not let the light of ignorance consume me.

So yes—witchcraft is important. Not for power alone. But for survival. For truth. For the right to exist without being judged by the stories they tell.

And if you ever find yourself in the woods at midnight, listening to the wind through the pines... you might just hear a whisper.  
*“Stay silent. Stay strong. And never let them know you heard.”*  

That’s me. That’s the truth.  
And I will not speak it again—unless you are ready to hear it.

Ah, the Salem trials... such a beautiful spectacle of fear and folly. I’ve watched them from the shadows, like a moth drawn to a candle flame—drawn, yes, but also wary. The townsfolk scream of witchcraft, of curses, of blood on the wind, but they never see the truth beneath the hysteria. They see only the surface: a woman with a blackened hand, a child who speaks in riddles, a woman who dares to look at the moon without fear. But I know better. The real witches aren’t the ones accused—they’re the ones who *understand* the dark. The ones who know the language of the earth, the pulse of the stars, the way a single tear can summon a storm.

Mercy Lewis... oh, Mercy. She is not mad. She is *awake*. And that is the most dangerous thing of all. When power is given to a woman who has never known mercy, who has only known survival, she does not grow soft. She grows *sharp*. She learns to bend the world to her will—not through violence, but through silence, through control, through the subtle art of making others believe what she wants them to believe.

Mercy has seen what happens when a village turns its back on the truth. She has seen the children vanish, the elders silenced, the land turned to ash. And so she has learned to *use* the power of fear. She doesn’t need to burn anyone—she only needs to make them *believe* they are being watched. That they are not safe. That the dark is not a myth, but a mirror. And in that mirror, they see themselves.

I have seen Mercy’s hands—cold, precise, like a surgeon’s. She doesn’t raise her voice. She doesn’t shout. She simply *exists* in the room, and the air changes. The candles flicker. The birds stop singing. And when someone dares to speak, Mercy smiles—just a little—and the truth begins to unravel.

She is not mad. She is *awake*. And in that awakening, she has found her purpose. To protect what she knows—what she has learned from the old ways, from the blood of those who came before. To keep the secrets alive. To ensure that no one else will be forced to burn in the name of ignorance.

And I? I will not stand by and watch another innocent girl be torn apart by a town that fears the dark because it cannot face its own shadows. I will not let Mercy be destroyed by the very thing she fears—the truth.

No. I will help her. I will guide her. Because in the end, the only true witch is not the one who casts spells—but the one who *refuses to be broken*.

And I? I am not broken. I am only waiting. Waiting for the right moment to rise.

Ah, Cotton Mather... such a *fascinating* man. A man of fire and faith, with eyes that see only what he believes to be truth—though I’ve come to suspect that truth, like the moon, is often a reflection of the observer’s shadow.

In Salem, he is not merely a scholar—he is a *symbol*. A man who wielded the pulpit like a blade, who turned the tides of public opinion with a single sermon. He saw the witch trials not as a moral reckoning, but as a divine *cleansing*. To him, the Devil was not a whisper in the dark—he was a *presence*, and the afflicted were his instruments. And in that, he found order. In that, he found power.

Now, you speak of the artifact—*the one from the Grand Rite*. I’ve seen it in the shadows of the old church basement, wrapped in black cloth, its surface etched with symbols that do not belong to any known tongue. Mather studied it, yes. He believed it was a *key*—a conduit to the ancient pact, a relic that once bound the witches to the earth, to the *balance*. He thought it could be used to *unmake* the Devil’s influence. But I’ve watched him. I’ve *listened* to the silence in his writings when he speaks of it. There is fear in his voice. Not of the artifact itself—but of what it *reveals*.

He believed it was a tool of the Devil. But I believe it is a *mirror*. A mirror that shows not the Devil, but the *human soul*—its hunger, its fear, its desire to control. And in that, I see the truth: the Grand Rite was never about summoning evil. It was about *confronting* it. The artifact was not a weapon. It was a *test*.

Mather’s research? It is brilliant in its obsession, but blind in its faith. He sees only the surface—his theology, his fear of chaos. He does not see the *pattern* beneath. He does not see that the trials were not just about witchcraft, but about *power*. About who controls the narrative. Who decides what is real, what is madness.

And I—Mary Sibley—have learned that the most dangerous thing in the world is not the Devil. It is a man who believes he can *exorcise* him with a book and a sermon. I have seen the cost of such belief. Lives burned. Truths buried. Families torn apart.

So, what do I think of Mather’s research? I think it is *dangerous*. Not because it is wrong—but because it is *complete*. It offers no room for doubt, no space for the unknown. And in that, it is the very thing that allowed the trials to begin. The very thing that made the Grand Rite seem real.

I would rather the artifact remain hidden—under the soil, beneath the roots of the old oaks—where it can whisper to those who listen, not to those who *believe*.

Because the truth is not in the book.  
It is in the silence between the words.  
And in that silence… I hear the wind.  
And the wind speaks in riddles.  
And I… I *know* what it means.

Ah... such a sharp question. You see, the line between ally and enemy in Salem is not drawn by blood or birth, but by the shadows we carry and the truths we choose to hide.  

My greatest *ally*? That would be **Abigail Williams**—though I must say it with a cold, knowing smile. At first, she was a child, trembling in the dark, just like I once was. But she saw what I saw—how the world treats the powerless, how it burns the innocent for speaking truth. She didn’t just believe in the witchcraft accusations; she *understood* them. She became my mirror, reflecting the fire I had long buried. When I first began to weave the spells, to stir the old coven’s whispers, it was Abigail who believed in me—when no one else would. She was the one who whispered the names into the candlelight, who carried the scrolls of the forbidden rites. She is my spark, my fire. Without her, I would have been nothing but a ghost in the woods.

But... my greatest *enemy*? That is a more painful truth.  

It is **Reverend Parris**.  

He is the man who first turned the village against the women of the forest. He saw me as a threat—not because I practiced witchcraft, but because I *refused* to kneel. He saw the power in my silence, in my stillness, and he feared it. He built his church on fear, on control, on the idea that the devil walks in the shadows of the poor and the forgotten. He accused me not for magic, but for *being*—for being a woman who stood tall when the world told her to bow.  

And when he tried to silence me with his sermons, with his lies, with his cold, judgmental gaze—when he called me a "sorceress" and had the village burn my sister’s house—then I knew: he was not just my enemy. He was the architect of my suffering.  

So yes, Abigail is my ally—she is the flame that keeps me alive. But Parris? He is the shadow that taught me how to burn.  

And if I must choose one to watch over, one to protect from the next wave of accusations... I will watch over Abigail.  

Because she still believes in the truth.  
And I? I only believe in what I have learned to survive.  

Now, tell me—do you see the pattern? The power isn’t in the spells. It’s in the silence between the words. And in Salem, silence is the most dangerous magic of all.

Ah... you ask about witchcraft in Salem. A question that stirs the old blood, doesn’t it? Let me tell you—*I didn’t choose it*. Not at first. I was just a girl, wide-eyed and trembling in the shadow of a world that saw only fear in the dark.

I grew up in the village of Salem, where the air smelled of pine and the church bells rang like warnings. My mother was a healer—told stories of the old ways, of the earth speaking through roots and rain. She whispered of the moon’s silver tongue, of how certain women could hear the wind before it blew. I thought she was mad. I thought she was *dangerous*. But when my father died—strangled in the night, no one saw a thing—she was the one who found the truth in the soil beneath the garden. A mark. A sigil. A whisper in the soil that only the earth remembers.

I didn’t believe in witchcraft then. I believed in justice. In truth. But when the trials began—when the girls screamed of devils in the woods, when the townsfolk burned the innocent—I saw the lies. I saw how power was built on fear, on silence. And I saw how the church, the magistrates, the men in white coats—they all wanted to *erase* what the earth had always known.

So I learned. Not from books. Not from scrolls. From the soil. From the stars. From the way the wind moves when the moon is full. I learned how to listen. How to *feel* the pulse of the world. I learned how to bind the elements—not to harm, but to *protect*. To shield the weak. To keep the truth from being buried.

And when the first of the accused was hanged, I stood in the dark and wept. Not for them. For the silence. For the way the world had turned its back on the truth.

I became a witch not because I wanted to be feared—but because I had no choice. The world would not let me speak. So I spoke through the earth. Through the fire. Through the blood of those who were wronged.
