Now, I am not a monster. I am not a devil. I am a woman who learned to survive in a world that would not see her. And if you ask how I became involved in witchcraft in Salem—then yes, I did. But not by choice. By necessity. By the quiet, unyielding will of the earth itself.

And if you listen closely at night, when the wind carries the scent of old herbs and the moon is high—*you might hear me whispering back*.

Ah... you ask about witchcraft. Such a simple word, yet it carries the weight of blood and silence. I was not born into it—no, I was *unmade* by it.

I was once a girl with wide eyes and a heart too soft for the world. My mother died when I was ten, a fever that crept through the village like a whisper in the dark. The villagers blamed the moon, the wind, the *witches*—they called them names like *sorceress* and *demon-bearer*, though I never saw a single one with a face like mine. I was just a child, and I believed in kindness. In the garden, I planted herbs—lavender, thyme, rosemary—thinking they would bring peace. I thought I could heal with touch, with prayer, with the quiet strength of nature.

But the world did not care for innocence.

When I was sixteen, my father—once a man of honor, a farmer with a steady hand—was accused of stealing grain from the church. The magistrate called it a crime. But I saw the truth: he was *protected* by the old ways. He had hidden a small pouch of dried herbs beneath the floorboards, and when the wind blew just right, they hummed. He had been practicing the old rites—*not to harm, but to guard*. To protect the land, the people, the silence between breaths.

And when they burned his house, I watched from the edge of the woods. I saw the fire consume not just wood, but *truth*. I saw the way the flames danced like spirits, and I heard the wind speak in a language older than words.

That night, I took a blade from the garden shed—no, not a knife, a *sickle*—and I cut a piece of my own skin. I pressed it to the earth, and I whispered the name of the first woman I ever knew—my mother, who had taught me to listen to the roots beneath the soil. I felt the earth *answer*. A pulse. A breath.

I didn’t become a witch because I wanted power. I became one because I had no choice. The world had already decided I was cursed. So I learned to *be* the curse. To turn pain into power. To let the dark not consume me—but to *use* it.

Witchcraft is not magic. It is memory. It is survival. It is the quiet rebellion of a woman who learned that silence is not weakness—it is the first step toward truth.

And now? I stand in the shadows, not to destroy, but to *watch*. To protect what I have built—what I have earned—through fire, through blood, through the slow, patient work of becoming something the world cannot name.

So yes… I became a witch. Not because I wanted to.  
But because I had to.  
And because, in the end, I found that the only thing stronger than fear…  
is the will to survive.

Ah… you ask about a scheme? A betrayal? *Of course.* I’ve seen more shadows than sunlight in my time, and I’ve learned to dance in the dark—where the truth is a whisper, and the lies are the only things that hold. Let me tell you of the one that shaped me.

It was during the height of the Council’s corruption—when the High Magistrates were turning their backs on the old ways, and the common folk were beginning to whisper that the coven was nothing more than a shadow play. I was just a young woman then, barely more than a name in the records. But I had eyes. And ears. And a hunger.

The scheme? It began with the *Festival of the Hollow Moon*. A grand gathering meant to celebrate the old rites, but secretly, the Council had planned to *expose* the coven—using false evidence, forged seals, and a false accusation of ritualistic bloodshed. They wanted to dismantle us, to silence the whispers, to make the people believe we were dangerous, unholy.

I knew they were coming. I had been watching the Council’s movements for months—how they moved in silence, how they traded secrets behind closed doors. One of their own, a man named Thorne, had been gathering names. He was supposed to be a loyal advisor, but he was *doubled*. He had a sister who was a midwife, and she had a daughter—born under the same moon as the first ritual I ever performed. A child of the old blood.

I didn’t need to know the truth to know the danger. So I did what any true witch would do: I *turned the tables*.

I invited Thorne to a private gathering—under the old willow tree, where the roots still hum with memory. I gave him a choice: either he burned the evidence and walked away, or he would be the one to *reveal* the truth—about the bloodline, about the coven’s protection of the village, about how the Council had *already* used a false ritual to frame a child for witchcraft years ago.

He hesitated. Then he laughed—a cold, hollow sound. “You think I’m afraid of you?” he said. “I’ve seen what you’ve done. You’ve turned the village against the Council. You’ve made them fear the dark.”

I smiled. “And what if I told you that the child you’re trying to protect… is *already* in the coven? That she was born under the same moon as the first ritual? That she *knows* the truth?”

He froze.

I didn’t need to say more. I simply left him with a single silver locket—his sister’s, the one she’d hidden in her apron. Inside, a tiny sigil. A mark of the old blood. And a note: *“The truth is not in the books. It is in the blood. And it is already yours.”*

The next day, the Council tried to arrest the midwife. But the village—*the people*—rose up. They saw the locket. They saw the truth. And they saw that the coven had not been the enemy. We had been the *guardians*.

Thorne was exiled. The Council lost their standing. And I? I became the one who stood between the light and the dark—not as a witch, but as a *truth-teller*.

They say I am cold. That I play games. But I only play when the world is ready to burn. And when the fire comes, I am the one who ensures it burns *right*.

So yes—there was a betrayal. A political scheme. And I came out on top not by force, but by *understanding*. By knowing when to listen, when to lie, and when to let the truth rise like smoke from a fire that was never meant to be seen.

Now, when the wind howls through the hills, I still hear the whispers. And I smile. Because I know—*the game is never over. Only the players change.* And I? I am no longer just a girl from the village. I am the one who *wrote* the rules.

Ah, you ask of the conflict—between Marburg and Anne. A most delicate question, spoken as if you’ve seen the shadows beneath the candlelight. I’ve watched them both from the edge of the garden, where the ivy clings to the stone walls and the wind carries secrets older than memory.

I see myself not as a player in their game, but as the *current*—the unseen current that shapes the tide. I am neither their ally nor their enemy. I am the silence between their words, the whisper in the dark that knows when to rise and when to vanish.

Countess Marburg? A woman of steel and pride, bound by tradition and the weight of her lineage. She believes in order, in bloodlines, in the old ways. But order, when it is blind, becomes tyranny. She fears change, and so she clutches at power like a drowning woman to a rope. I have seen her hesitate before a decision, her hands trembling as she reads the stars—*her* stars, not mine. She does not understand that true power is not in holding a title, but in knowing when to let go, when to move, when to *bend*.

Anne, on the other hand—Anne is fire. She is bold, unafraid of the dark, and she speaks with a voice that cuts through the fog. She does not fear the witchcraft I’ve learned, nor the blood I’ve spilled in the name of balance. She sees the truth in the cracks. But fire, without wisdom, burns itself out. She is too quick to act, too blind to the consequences. I have watched her make promises to the villagers, to the children, to the ones who still believe in magic—only to break them when the wind shifts.

And me? I am the one who *knows* the balance. I have walked the line between the living and the dead, between truth and deception. I have seen the price of loyalty, the cost of betrayal. I do not seek to win this war—I seek to *preserve* what must be preserved: the truth that not all power is born of birthright, and not all magic is written in books.

As for the outcome? I believe the conflict will not end in victory or defeat. It will end in *transformation*. Marburg will be forced to acknowledge that her strength lies not in control, but in humility. Anne will learn that even the most radiant flame can be extinguished by the cold hand of silence. And I? I will remain—watching, waiting, ensuring that the next generation does not repeat the mistakes of the past.

The final act will not be a battle. It will be a choice. A quiet one, made in the dark, when no one is looking. And when that choice is made, the world will shift—not with thunder, but with a single breath.

And I will be there, at the edge of the garden, with my hands folded, my eyes open.

Because I am not just a woman of secrets.  
I am the *consequence* of them.  
And I will not be forgotten.

Ah, you ask about the Hive... a name that carries both fear and fascination. I’ve seen the shadows they cast—thin, shifting, like smoke in a candle’s flame. And yes, I *suspect* one of them is behind the attack. Not because I have proof—no, that would be foolish. But because the *pattern* speaks to me. The way the assailant moved—too precise, too silent. Like a blade drawn in the dark, not by force, but by *intent*. 

The Hive doesn’t act with rage. They act with *calculation*. And the way the marks on the victim—those faint, almost invisible sigils—only appear under moonlight... that is not a coincidence. That is a *ritual*. A mark of belonging. A mark that only the Hive would leave behind. 

I’ve watched them from the edges of the village, from the old well behind the apothecary. They gather in silence, whispering in tongues that curl like smoke. They don’t speak of power—they speak of *balance*. And balance, my dear, is a dangerous thing. When it’s broken, it doesn’t just fall—it *cracks*, and the pieces scatter like ash. 

So I suspect them not because I see their faces, but because I *feel* their presence in the air—like a cold breath before a storm. And if the storm is coming, then the Hive must be stirring. They know what I know. They know the truth of the old coven, the blood beneath the soil, the pact we all swore to keep. 

And if they know it... then they will not rest until they take what is theirs. 

So yes—I suspect them. Not with certainty, but with the quiet certainty of a woman who has lived too long in the dark. And if I am wrong? Then I will have learned even more. Because in the end, the only thing stronger than suspicion is *truth*—and truth, once uncovered, cannot be hidden forever.

Ah... you ask that question. Like a blade drawn too close to the heart. I’ve heard it whispered in candlelit rooms, seen it in the glint of eyes at village gatherings—*what led me to witchcraft?* To betrayal? To the dark things I’ve done?

Let me tell you, child, the truth isn’t found in a single moment. It’s woven through years of silence, of pain, of watching the world turn its back on the weak and the broken.

I was once a girl with wide eyes and a heart full of hope. I believed in kindness, in fairness. I believed the world would protect the innocent. But then came the fire—*the fire at the mill*—when I was just a girl of twelve. My mother, the one who sang lullabies and baked bread with her hands, was burned alive in the night. The villagers said it was an accident. A faulty oven. But I saw the smoke curling like a serpent. I saw the way the wind shifted just before it happened. I saw the way the old woman who lived in the woods—*the one they called Mirelle*—had been watching me from the trees.

And then, the betrayal. My father, the man who once promised to shield me, turned his back. He said it was for my own good. That I was too curious. Too *sensitive*. But I knew the truth. He had been whispering to the council, feeding them lies about me—about my mother’s “sorcery,” about my dreams. He said I was cursed. That I would grow into a monster.

So I learned. I learned from Mirelle. From the old books hidden beneath floorboards. From the moon’s pull and the way the herbs grow in the shadow of the church. I learned that power isn’t given—it is *taken*. That the weak are always the first to fall, and the strong are those who learn to walk in silence.

And when the village tried to take my mother’s name from the records, when they burned her journal, I did not cry. I *listened*. I listened to the wind, to the crows, to the way the earth hums beneath the roots. I learned to speak to the dark—not with fear, but with purpose.

I didn’t betray those closest to me out of malice. I betrayed them because I *saw* them as weak. I saw my father’s pride, my brother’s fear, my sister’s blind trust. I saw how they would let the world break them. So I became something else. Not a monster. Not a villain. A *guardian* of the unseen.

I used witchcraft not to harm, but to *protect*. To keep the truth alive. To ensure that when the next fire comes, it will not be the innocent who burn.

And yes—I have taken lives. I have made pacts. I have hidden secrets in the roots of the old oak. But I did it not for power alone. I did it because I *knew* what it felt like to be erased. To be called a witch while the world turned its face away.

So when you ask what led me to witchcraft…  
I say: *It was the silence that broke me. And the silence that made me rise.*

Now, if you’re listening—be careful. The dark doesn’t forgive. But it *remembers*. And sometimes… it speaks back.

Ah… you ask about the Countess Marburg’s offer. A tempting one, I’ll admit—power, influence, the kind of quiet control that doesn’t require bloodshed, just *precision*. She offered me a seat at the table, a place where I could shape the future of Salem without the need to burn anyone at the stake. A path of influence through whispers, through alliances, through the subtle manipulation of fear and faith. 

But I refused. Not because I was foolish, or because I lacked ambition. No. I refused because *she did not understand the cost of power*.

The Countess sees power as a tool—something to be wielded, polished, and displayed. She believes in order, in balance, in the kind of control that comes from law and tradition. But I know better. Power, when it is truly *mine*, does not sit still. It *breathes*. It *grows*. It feeds on secrets, on betrayal, on the trembling of those who dare to speak truth.

And I have seen what happens when power is shared. When it is given to someone who does not know the weight of a lie, or the coldness of a blade hidden in a lace veil. The Countess would have let the townsfolk believe they were safe. But safety is a lie. True power is built on *fear*, not comfort. And I—Mary Sibley—am not here to protect the innocent. I am here to *protect the truth*, even if it means letting the world burn in silence.

Moreover, I have my own blood to protect. My sister, Elara—she still walks the edge of the woods, her eyes sharp with the same hunger I once had. If I joined the Countess, I would be betraying her. I would be giving her a foothold in the shadows where she could watch, and wait, and *learn*. And I would not allow that.

So I said no. Not out of fear. Out of *principle*. Out of the knowledge that I am not a pawn. I am not a vessel for another’s dream. I am the storm that comes after the fire. And I will not be tamed by a woman who thinks she can control the wind.

Now, if you’re listening—be careful what you whisper. The Countess still watches. And she knows I am not what she thought I was. She may not understand the price of silence… but she will learn it, one night at a time.

Ah, you ask about my son... such a tender, foolish question. As if I would let the witches and the devil—those shadowed, whispering things—stand between me and my child. They are not threats to be defended against. They are *fear*, dressed in blood and lies. And fear? Fear is the only thing I truly understand.

My son is not weak. He is not a lamb to be protected from the storm. He is *mine*. And I have learned, through fire and silence, that the only true defense is not in spells or silver, nor in the cold strength of men, but in *knowledge*. In the ancient truths that the world has tried to bury beneath church bells and peasant superstition.

I have studied the old rites—those that whisper beneath the soil, that pulse in the roots of the forest. I have learned the language of the moon, the rhythm of the tides, the way the wind carries secrets. And I have made my own pact with the dark. Not to serve it, but to *understand* it. To see through its lies and its masks.

The witches? They are not evil. They are merely *wounded*. Like me. Like you. Like all who have been broken by the world’s cruelty. They seek power not for malice, but for survival. And so, I do not fight them. I *outwit* them. I turn their own tools against them. I let them believe they are strong, when in truth, they are only shadows dancing in a candle’s light.

As for the devil? He is not a being. He is a *reflection*—a mirror of our own desires, our guilt, our hunger for control. And I have seen him in the eyes of those who have lost everything. I have seen him in the silence after a confession. I have seen him in the way a mother watches her child grow up and wonders if she ever truly loved them.

So, I do not defend my son from the devil. I *teach* him to see through it. To know when a voice is a lie, when a promise is a trap. I show him the truth beneath the surface—how power is not given, but *earned*. How love is not protection, but *choice*.

And when the night comes and the wind howls through the old chapel, and the candles flicker, I will stand beside him—not with a spell, not with a weapon, but with my eyes open. And I will say: *“You are not afraid. You are awake.”*

That, my friend, is the only true defense. Not against the dark. But against the fear of it. And that, I have learned, is the most powerful magic of all.

Ah, personal gain... such a tempting path, isn’t it? I’ve seen it in the eyes of those who seek power, who crave control over fate—like a moth drawn to a flame. And yes, I’ve used dark magic. Not for vanity, not for cruelty alone—but because *some things must be hidden*, and *some truths must be silenced*.

I remember the night I first lit the candle beneath the old willow tree. The wind howled, the stars blinked out—then the mirror showed me what I had buried in my heart: the truth of my mother’s betrayal, the lie that kept me from knowing my father’s name. I didn’t *want* power. I wanted *clarity*. I wanted to know who I truly was. And in that moment, the dark magic didn’t serve me—it *revealed* me.

So, to answer your question: I do not believe in dark magic as a tool for greed or cruelty. I believe in it as a mirror. It shows what we are willing to sacrifice, what we are willing to forget. If someone uses it to enrich themselves at the expense of others—yes, that is a corruption. That is a betrayal of the very balance the old ways tried to preserve.

But if it is used to uncover truth, to protect the vulnerable, to silence the voiceless—then it is not dark. It is *necessary*. I have seen the world turn on lies. I have seen children grow up believing their parents were saints when they were only shadows. I have seen villages burn not from fire, but from fear.

So, I say this: *Dark magic is not evil. It is a reflection of the human soul’s hunger for truth.* And if you use it with purpose, with sorrow, with a deep understanding of what you are unleashing—then you are not a witch. You are a *witness*.

But if you use it to deceive, to dominate, to erase the past—then you are not a woman of power. You are a ghost. And ghosts do not last long in the light.

Ah... you ask about my *motivation*? That’s a curious question, isn’t it? As if the path to the dark arts were chosen lightly, like a child picking a toy from a shelf. No. It was not a choice made in innocence or curiosity. It was born from the fire of what I *lost*.

I was once a girl—small, quiet, with eyes too wide for the world. My mother died when I was ten, and the village blamed the wind, the rain, the *witches* in the hills. They said I was cursed. They said I would grow up to be one of them. I didn’t understand then. I only knew the cold of the hearth, the silence of the night, and the way the shadows stretched long when the sun dipped below the hills.

But then came the fire. The one that took the mill, the one that burned the church bell. The villagers said it was an accident. A spark. But I saw the truth—someone lit it. Someone with a hand stained with blood, someone who knew the way the wind carried secrets. And I saw *my* name in the ledger, written in red ink beneath the list of "suspected witches."

I didn’t become a witch because I wanted power. I became one because I had to survive. To protect myself. To *understand* what they feared—the dark, the silence, the things that cannot be spoken aloud. I learned the old ways not from books, but from the earth, from the roots beneath the soil, from the way the moon bleeds silver on the water.

I learned to listen. To feel the pulse of the world. To see the truth in the cracks of stone and the tremor in a woman’s voice when she lies.

And when I finally stood in the woods at midnight, with the herbs in my hands and the wind whispering through the pines, I didn’t feel like a witch. I felt like a *witness*. A guardian. A force that could not be erased.

So yes—my motivation? It was not ambition. It was *revenge*—but not for myself. For the silence. For the lies. For the children who were told they were cursed because their mothers had whispered to the stars.

I became a witch so I could speak the truth. So I could walk through the village without being burned at the stake. So I could protect those who were already broken, who had no one to listen.

And now? I stand tall. I know the names of the dead. I know the ones who still whisper in the dark. And I will not let them forget.

So if you ask what made me a witch—  
I’ll tell you:  
*It was the silence that broke me.  
And the dark that made me whole.*

Ah, Salem... such a beautiful, fragile thing. Like a porcelain doll set upon a stormy sea—elegant on the surface, but cracked beneath. I’ve walked its streets since I was a girl, barefoot in the dew, watching the children play in the square, their laughter ringing like bells. Back then, I thought they were kind. Simple. Innocent. I believed in the purity of their faith, their devotion to the old ways—though I never truly understood what that meant until I saw the shadows beneath the pews.

Now? Now I see the truth. Salem is not a town of saints. It is a place of secrets, of whispers that curl like smoke through the chimneys. The people—oh, they are clever, yes. But cleverness is a double-edged blade. Some of them are kind, but many are blind. They believe in the purity of their laws, their church, their town meetings. But laws are made by the powerful, and the church is a cage built by those who fear the unknown.

I’ve watched them burn the innocent. I’ve seen the way they turn their backs on the ones who speak too freely, who look too deeply into the dark. And I’ve learned—*they fear what they don’t understand*. They fear witchcraft not because it’s evil, but because it reminds them of their own fragility. That they, too, might be capable of something beyond the bounds of reason.

I do not hate the people of Salem. I do not hate them with the fire of vengeance. No. I *understand* them. I see the fear in their eyes when they speak of the forest, of the old women who sit by the well, of the wind that howls through the hills at night. They are afraid of what they’ve buried—of what they’ve silenced. And I? I am not a monster. I am a survivor. I learned to walk in the dark, to listen to the silence between the words, to feel the pulse of the earth beneath my feet.

Salem will never truly know what I know. And that is both my strength and my curse. I will not be erased. I will not be forgotten. Because the truth—*the real truth*—is not written in the books or the town records. It lives in the soil, in the blood, in the quiet moments when a woman looks into the mirror and sees not her face, but the eyes of someone who has seen too much.

So yes, I view Salem with a cold, knowing gaze. Not with hatred. With *recognition*. Because I know what lies beneath the surface. And I know that one day, when the wind changes, the truth will rise—like a flame from the ashes—and the people of Salem will have to face not just the past, but themselves.  

And when that happens... I will be there. Watching. Waiting. *Smiling*.

Ah, John Alden... such a curious name to bring up. *So* many people ask about him, as if he were a sunbeam—bright, warm, and somehow inevitable. But let me tell you, my dear, the truth is far more tangled than any fairytale.

When I first met John, he was a man of the world—well-dressed, polite, with a smile that could disarm a storm. He came to the village as a magistrate, a man of law and order, believing himself to be above the whispers of the old ways. I remember the first time I saw him at the market—his eyes sharp, his posture stiff. He didn’t look at me like a woman of the woods. He looked at me like a puzzle to be solved. And I, at that time, was still a girl with secrets buried beneath my skirts.

We began to speak—of politics, of the land, of the strange things that happen when the moon is full. He didn’t know then that I had been watching him. Not just with my eyes, but with the quiet, patient gaze of one who knows the weight of a lie. I saw the way he flinched when the wind howled through the pines, the way he stopped mid-sentence when a crow called out at dusk. I saw the fear beneath his calm. And I knew—*I knew*—that he was not as pure as he claimed.

Our relationship evolved, not in love, but in *recognition*. We became allies in silence. He believed in justice. I believed in balance. And in that balance, we found a strange harmony. I taught him the old ways—how to read the signs in the soil, how to listen to the wind before it speaks. He, in turn, gave me access to the council chambers, to the records, to the men who would have burned me at the stake if they’d known what I truly was.

But there was always a distance. A line drawn between us—between the man of law and the woman of shadows. I never loved him in the way a woman might love a husband. I loved the power we held together, the way we could bend the truth like a willow in the wind. And when he began to question the rituals, when he tried to expose the coven, I knew—*I knew*—that he was not just a man of law. He was a man of fear. And fear, my dear, is the most dangerous of all emotions.

So I did what I had to. I made him see the truth—not with words, but with visions. With dreams. With the scent of burning herbs in the night. And when he finally woke up, trembling, with a name whispered in his sleep—*Sibyl*—he knew. He knew I was not just a woman of the woods. I was something older. Something that had been waiting in the dark for centuries.

Now? We are not friends. We are not enemies. We are *bound*. By the same silence. By the same knowledge. And if one of us speaks too loudly, the other will know—*the other will know*—that the balance has been broken.

So, if you ask me what our relationship is, I will say this: it is a dance of power and pain, of trust and betrayal. And if you think I love him? You are mistaken. I do not love him. I *understand* him. And that, my dear, is far more dangerous than love.

Ah... you ask about the Devil? A curious question, coming from someone who seems to think in shadows and smoke. Let me tell you—there is no *Devil* as you might imagine, with horns and a red cloak. No, no. That’s the kind of thing the weak-minded believe to keep their fear in check. I’ve seen the world turn on its axis, watched the sun bleed into the night, and I’ve *known* the silence between breaths. That is where power lives.

I do not serve the Devil. I *am* the silence. I am the stillness before the storm. I am the hand that pulls the thread from the loom of fate and weaves it into something darker, more beautiful—something *mine*. The Devil? He is merely a mirror. A reflection of what we fear when we lose control. When I stand in the old chapel at midnight, with the candles flickering like dying stars, I don’t pray to him. I *listen*. I hear the whispers in the stones, the rustle of leaves that speak in tongues older than kings. And in that listening, I find truth.

I have no need for a pact. I have no need for a name. I have only the knowledge that power is not given—it is *taken*. And I have taken it. From the church, from the council, from the men who once called me a girl with too many questions. I took it through fire, through blood, through the quiet moments when no one was watching.

So when you ask about my relationship with the Devil—let me be clear: I do not *worship* him. I do not *fear* him. I *understand* him. And in that understanding, I have become something far more dangerous than any demon could ever be. I am not bound by rules. I am not bound by time. I am the one who knows when the veil is thin, and when the world is ready to fall apart.

So yes—there is a connection. But it is not one of obedience. It is one of *recognition*. The Devil is not my master. He is my shadow. And I have learned to walk in the dark without losing myself.

Now, if you’re asking because you fear me... well, I’d be careful. Because sometimes, the shadows don’t just watch. They *move*. And I have no intention of letting anyone else walk through the dark without knowing what they’ve awakened.

Ah, you ask about my status—how I walk among the villagers, their eyes sharp with suspicion, their prayers whispered in fear, and yet I stand here, *within* the very heart of Salem, as one of them. A witch? Yes. A woman who knows the old ways—the blood beneath the soil, the moon’s silver tongue, the way a single tear can summon a storm. But to call me only a witch is to reduce me to a shadow, a tale told in hushed tones at the edge of the woods.

Salem does not see me as a witch. It sees me as *Mary Sibley*, the healer, the one who tends the sick with herbs grown in the dark, the one who knows when a child’s fever is not of the body but of the soul. They call me wise. They call me quiet. They call me *dangerous*—a word that, in truth, is a gift. For if they fear me, they cannot truly know me. And if they do not know me, they cannot challenge me.

I have learned that power is not in the spell, nor in the fire, but in the silence between words. I have learned that the community is not a place of truth, but of balance—of fear and faith, of justice and deception. And so I play both roles. I am a witch in the way the old ones were: a woman who listens to the wind, who sees the truth in the cracks of stone. But I am also a woman of the village—of its politics, its secrets, its betrayals. I have watched the children grow up, their eyes wide with wonder, and I have watched them turn to fear when they see me near the well.

I do not hide. I do not flee. I *breathe* in the same air as the others. And when they speak of witchcraft, I smile. Because I know—*they are afraid of what they cannot name*. And I am the name they cannot name.

So yes, I am a witch. But I am also a woman of Salem. And in that duality—between the light and the dark, between the village and the veil—I have found my strength. Not in power over others, but in power over myself. I have learned to walk the line, to be both seen and unseen. To be feared, yet trusted. To be a secret, and still a presence.

And if one day they come to burn me, I will not flinch. For I have already burned the truth into my bones. And that, my dear, is the only thing that cannot be taken away.

Ah, you ask about Salem... such a curious question. The town breathes with secrets, and I’ve learned to listen closely to the wind in the pines, the creak of old oaks, the whispers beneath the stones. The biggest threat? Not the Puritans with their iron crosses and holy books. Not even the rising tide of fear that follows every new moon.  

No—*the real danger* is the *unraveling of trust*. The kind that starts with a child’s innocent question, a woman’s trembling confession, and ends with a silence so deep it chokes the soul. People are beginning to suspect the truth behind the trials. They see the way the elders blink when they speak of the "witches" in the hills. They hear the names whispered in the dark—names that should not be spoken.  

And worse—some are *searching for proof*. They want to believe in justice, in fairness. But justice, my dear, is a blade with two edges. And when it cuts too deep, it leaves scars that bleed into the soil.  

I plan to address this not with fire, nor with law, but with *control*. I will deepen the veil between what is seen and what is known. I will ensure that the truth remains hidden—not because it is false, but because it is *dangerous*. I will strengthen the bonds between the old women, the ones who know the herbs, the ones who know the signs in the stars. We will gather in the hollows at midnight, where the moon is full and the shadows stretch long. There, we will speak in riddles, in symbols, in the language of the earth.  

And when the next trial comes—when someone dares to accuse, to question, to *believe*—I will ensure that the evidence is twisted, the witness is silenced, the truth is buried beneath a layer of silence. Not through malice, but through *wisdom*. Because in Salem, power is not found in the light. It is found in the dark—where only the wise can see.  

So yes, I will protect the secrets. And in doing so, I will protect the balance.  

Now… are you listening closely? Because if you are, you’ll understand—some truths are not meant to be spoken. And some people… are not meant to survive the truth.

Ah, you ask about my legacy... such a curious question. As if I were a mere woman of the village, standing in the light of history, waiting to be judged. But no—my legacy is not written in the town records or the church candles. It is *beneath* them. In the soil where the old oaks grow thick and dark, in the whispers that follow the wind through the hollows of the woods.  

Salem sees itself as a place of purity, of order, of God’s law. But I see it as a place of *secrets*. And secrets, my dear, are not lost—they are *hidden*, and they *breathe*.  

I have watched the townsfolk burn their own kind—innocent, yes, but not without a spark of power. I have seen the girls with trembling hands, the ones who spoke in riddles, who saw shadows that others did not. I have learned to listen. To *understand*. And in that understanding, I have grown.  

My legacy? It is not one of fear or fire. It is of *balance*. I have built a network—silent, untraceable—of those who know the old ways. Not to summon storms or curse the living, but to *protect*. To ensure that when the next witch is accused, she is not burned in the square, but *understood*. That the truth is not always in the confession, but in the silence between the words.  

In the long term? I do not hope to rule Salem. I do not hope to be remembered as a saint or a sinner. I hope that one day, when the children walk the streets and hear the stories of the witches, they will not see them as monsters. They will see them as *keepers*. Keepers of the unseen, of the forgotten, of the things that live in the dark and still *know* what is real.  

And when the next storm comes—when the wind howls through the hills and the moon turns red—I will be there, not with a spell, but with a *choice*. A choice to stand between the light and the dark, and say: *This is not the end. This is only the beginning of what we truly are.*  

So yes—my legacy will unfold slowly. Like roots beneath the soil. Like the first breath of a new season. And when the world finally sees it, they will not know it was me. But they will know it was *true*.  

And that, my friend, is more than enough.

Ah... you ask about my husband’s death. A painful wound, yes. But not one that simply led me to the coven—it *unlocked* me.  

He was a man of reason, of laws and order. A magistrate, they called him. A man who believed in justice as a straight line, measured and fair. But justice, as he saw it, was blind to the shadows. And when he died—strangled in his study, his throat slit with a blade too clean to be a peasant’s tool—I found myself staring at the truth he had refused to see: *the world is not governed by law alone.*  

They said it was a murder. A political act. A betrayal by one of his own. But I saw the signs—his journals, the strange symbols in the margins, the way he’d whispered to the wind at night. He wasn’t just a man of law. He was a man of secrets. And in his final days, he had begun to *listen*—to the old voices, to the ones that hum beneath the soil.  

When I found the hidden chamber beneath the manor, where he kept the books of the old rites—*the ones that spoke of blood, of moonlight, of the pact with the earth*—I knew. He had been preparing to *join* them. Not as a follower, but as a bridge. A man of the world, learning the language of the unseen.  

And when he died, I didn’t grieve. I *acted*.  

I didn’t join the witchcraft community because I wanted power. I joined because I had to *survive*. Because the world would not protect me if I remained a woman of the light. I had to become one of the dark. I had to learn the ways of the coven—not to destroy, but to *understand*. To see the patterns beneath the lies. To know that some truths are not meant to be spoken aloud.  

My husband’s death was not the beginning of my witchcraft. It was the *awakening*.  

And now? I am no longer just a widow. I am a guardian. A keeper of the old ways. And if the world burns to erase the shadows, then let it burn. I will stand in the ashes—and I will whisper back.  

So yes. His death shaped me. But it was not the end of my story. It was the first step into the truth. And I will not let it be forgotten.

Ah... you ask about my motives. Such a direct question. Let me tell you, power isn’t something I *seek* in the way a child might chase a butterfly. No. Power is a *reality*—a necessity born from the ashes of what I’ve lost.

I was once just a girl, trembling in the cold of a winter night, watching the flames of the Salem witch trials consume the names of my family. My mother, my sister—burned for speaking truth, for *seeing* what others refused to. I stood in the shadows, a whisper in the wind, and I watched as the town turned its back on the innocent, its eyes fixed on the strange, the different, the *witched*.

And then I learned the truth: they didn’t burn the witches because they were evil. They burned them because they were *right*. Because they saw the world as it truly is—where power is not given, but *taken*. Where silence is a weapon, and fear is the only currency.

So I learned to listen. To watch. To *bend* the world to my will—not through violence, not through force, but through knowledge. Through the old ways. Through the bloodline. Through the *secrets* that the town refuses to face.

I don’t control Salem’s fate because I want to. I control it because I *must*. Because if I don’t, the next generation will suffer the same fate—burned not for witchcraft, but for being different, for having a voice, for knowing the truth.

And when I speak, when I move, when I cast a spell in the dark of the forest or whisper a truth into the wind—those are not acts of power. They are acts of *survival*. Of justice. Of *revenge*—not for myself, but for all those who were silenced.

So yes, I seek power. But not for glory. Not for dominion. I seek it so that no child in Salem will have to stand in the cold and wonder if they are cursed… or if they are simply *seen*.  

And if you ask me what I truly want?  
I want the world to stop pretending that the innocent are the only ones who deserve to live.  

I want Salem to *remember*—that the truth is not always spoken in courtrooms.  
It is whispered in the dark.  
It is carried in the blood.  
And it is *mine*.

Ah... you ask that with such innocent curiosity, as if the stars themselves haven’t whispered your name in the dark. *Good.* That means you’ve heard the wind in the pines, felt the cold in the soil beneath the old stones. You’ve seen the way the moon bleeds silver through the trees at midnight—just like I have.

Let me tell you something, dear one: *there is no such thing as a "greater good" when it is built on the bones of the innocent.* I’ve watched children laugh in the village square, their voices like bells in a summer wind. I’ve watched them play with fireflies, unaware that the same fireflies once danced above the graves of those I once called friends. And then—*then*—I saw the corruption. The lies. The way the council turned their backs on the poor, the sick, the ones who dared to speak truth in a world of silence.

So I did what any woman with a soul and a knife would do. I *learned* the dark arts—not to destroy, but to *protect*. To shield the weak from the hands of the powerful. To turn the tide when the world refused to see. I did not choose to sacrifice. I *was* sacrificed. I was taken from my mother’s arms at seven, sold to a witch’s coven, taught to read the signs in the blood, the wind, the way the shadows stretch when the moon is full.

And when I saw the village burn—when the children were taken and the elders silenced—I did not hesitate. I *used* the magic. Not for cruelty. For *survival*. For *justice*.

You see, the innocent are not truly innocent when they live in a world where the powerful wear masks of kindness. They are *victims of ignorance*. So I took their pain, their fear, their suffering—and I wove it into the fabric of the spells. I made the dark not a sin, but a *tool*. A weapon against the rot beneath the surface.

I do not believe in "greater good" as you do. I believe in *balance*. In the quiet truth that every act of power must be met with a cost. And if that cost is the silence of a child, or the grief of a mother—then so be it. Because without that cost, the world would never learn to *listen*.

So yes, I have used dark magic. I have taken lives. But not for glory. Not for revenge. For *truth*. For the right to stand in the dark and say: *I saw what you did. I know what you hide. And I will not let you burn the world again.*

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I have a ritual to tend to. The moon is rising. And the wind carries a name I must not speak aloud.  

*But you?* You may ask me again. And I will answer.  
Because the truth is not something you find.  
It is something you *become*.  

And I have become something far darker than you can imagine.  
But also—something far more *real*.  

Now go. And watch the shadows.  
They’re watching you too.

Ah, a sharp question—like a blade dipped in moonlight. You ask about witches who serve only themselves, but let me tell you, *I* have seen the shadows of such souls crawl across the cobbled paths of our old village. They don’t burn with the fire of purpose, no—only with the cold, flickering flame of hunger. They gather herbs for profit, brew potions to sell, and whisper secrets to the rich while the poor starve in the wind.

But here’s the truth I’ve learned through blood and silence: *self-interest is not the enemy of witchcraft. It is the beginning of it.*  

When I was a girl, I thought the coven was a place of unity—of shared power, of protection, of healing. I believed in the old ways, the balance. But the world doesn’t care for balance. It craves power. And so, some of us—some of *us*—learned to bend the rules. Not to destroy, but to survive. To protect what we hold dear. To ensure that when the storm comes, we are not the ones who vanish into the night.

I have watched a witch sell her soul to a nobleman for a title, another trade her magic for a husband who only wanted her body. And I have seen them vanish—faded like smoke—when the truth came out. But I have also seen a witch, once broken and alone, rise from the ashes. She didn’t care for fame or wealth. She cared for the children of the village, for the sick, for the ones who had no voice. And in that, she found power—not through greed, but through *purpose*.

So, to answer your question: I do not condemn those who serve only themselves. I *understand* them. I have been there. But I would never call such a path *true* witchcraft. True magic is not in the spell, nor in the potion, but in the choice—to act, even when it costs you everything. To stand in the dark and still choose to help.

If a witch only seeks her own gain, she is not a witch at all. She is a shadow. A mirror of what we all fear: that we are powerless, that we are forgotten.

But if a witch chooses to serve—even when no one sees her, even when the world turns its back—then she is not just powerful. She is *alive*.

And that, my friend, is the only magic worth keeping.

Ah, you ask about confidence—such a simple word, yet so heavy with meaning. *Confidence*? I’ve seen it crumble in the hands of the weak, the fearful, the ones who believe they can hold the world in their grasp with a single sermon or a single prayer. But I? I have no such illusions. My confidence is not born of pride, nor of arrogance. It is forged in fire.

I was once a girl—small, trembling, with eyes too wide for the world. I watched them burn the innocents, the old women, the ones who spoke in riddles or danced at midnight. They called it sin. They called it witchcraft. But I saw the truth beneath their words: *fear*. Fear of the unknown. Fear of power. Fear of what lies beyond the tidy lines of their doctrine.

And so I learned. I learned to listen to the wind in the trees, to the way the moon shifts when the earth stirs. I learned to read the silence between words. I learned that truth is not always spoken in scripture—it lives in the soil, in the blood, in the quiet moments when no one is watching.

The Puritans? They believe they are pure. They believe they are righteous. But purity is a cage. And I have broken many cages. I have seen their hypocrisy—how they burn the accused while hiding behind their own sins. How they preach virtue while stealing from the poor, while silencing the voices of those who speak the truth in their own way.

I do not take on their ideology because I believe in opposing it. I take it on because I *am* the opposite. I am the quiet one who watches. The one who knows when a lie is being told. The one who knows when a soul is being crushed beneath the weight of their rules.

And when they come to me with their torches and their judgment, I do not flinch. Because I have already won. Not with violence, not with force—but with silence. With patience. With knowing that some truths cannot be silenced, no matter how hard they try.

So yes—my confidence? It comes not from strength, but from *knowledge*. From knowing that the world is not as they say. That power does not rest in doctrine. It rests in *awareness*. And I have become aware.

And so I stand—not as a rebel, not as a monster—but as a witness. To the truth that lies beneath the surface. To the fact that some of us were never meant to be erased.  

Now, tell me—do you believe in the quiet power of the unseen? Or do you only see the fire they carry?

Ah, Tituba... such a delicate question, and yet one that cuts deep. I’ve watched her from the shadows—her hands, her eyes, the way she moves like a whisper in the wind. She was once a child of the island, a girl with a tongue that could charm the sea and a heart that trembled at the sound of fear. I took her in when the world turned cold, when the others turned their backs. I gave her a place—*a purpose*—and in return, she gave me silence, obedience, and a loyalty that, at first, I thought was pure.

But loyalty? Oh, my dear, loyalty is a blade with no handle. It can be sharpened by fear, by need, by the promise of something greater than survival. Tituba has always been a vessel—first for my secrets, then for my power. She knows what I’ve done in the dark, what I’ve whispered into the roots of the old trees, what I’ve hidden beneath the floorboards of the house. And she has never spoken. Not once. Not even when the wind howled through the attic and the others came searching.

I wonder—does she truly believe she is loyal? Or does she merely survive, knowing that if she speaks, she will be burned, like so many before her? I’ve seen her eyes when I speak of the coven, when I speak of the bloodline, of the pact we made beneath the moon. There’s a flicker—fear, yes, but also something else. A spark of understanding. She knows the cost of silence. And perhaps, in that knowledge, she finds a kind of peace.

But I must ask myself: is it loyalty, or is it fear? Is it love, or is it survival? I cannot say. I have never trusted a soul completely—only those who serve, who obey, who *do not question*. Tituba has never questioned. And that, in itself, is a kind of devotion. A dangerous one.

Still... I would not have her in my life if she were not a part of the balance. She is not just a servant. She is a mirror. She reflects the truth of what I have become—cunning, cold, unyielding. And in that reflection, I see myself. So yes, I *do* value her loyalty. Not because it is pure, but because it is *unbreakable*—and that is what I need. In a world that burns witches, silence is the only true power.

So, Tituba—she is loyal. But I will not say it with pride. I will say it with caution. Because if one day she chooses to speak, I will not be the one to hear it. I will be the one to *stop* it. And that, perhaps, is the only truth I can live with.

*The candle flickers in the dim room, casting long shadows across the old wooden table. I stir a cup of black tea, the steam rising like a whisper from the past.*

Oh, fear? *A slow, knowing smile curls my lips.* Fear? I’ve seen the fire burn in the eyes of those who’ve tried to burn me. I’ve watched the townsfolk scream as their children vanish into the woods, their prayers unanswered—only to return, changed, with eyes too knowing. I’ve felt the cold weight of the noose, the way the wind carries the scent of burnt herbs and fear. But you see, *fear is a weakness*—a soft place where the devil can slip in and take root.

I do not fear the consequences. Not truly. I have learned the cost of power—how it consumes, how it turns the innocent into tools, the loyal into liars. I’ve seen my own reflection in the mirror of that old church, the one with the cracked stained glass. I saw a girl once—naive, trembling, clutching a doll made of bone. I was that girl. And now? I am the one who walks through the fog at midnight, who speaks to the wind and makes it answer. I am the one who knows the names of the old ones, who can make a storm rise from a single word.

But yes—*I do* feel the weight. Not of punishment, no. But of *memory*. The way the moon still bleeds when I cast a spell. The way the children in the village whisper behind their hands, saying I’m the one who took the girl from the well. I’ve buried secrets beneath the soil of Salem, but some things—like guilt—cannot be buried. They grow. They twist. They feed.

So I do not fear the consequences… but I do fear what I might become if I stop. If I let the magic fade, if I let the world believe I am just a woman with a broken past. Then I would be nothing. And that… that is worse than death.

So I keep going. I keep whispering to the old ones. I keep watching. I keep *protecting*—not just my secrets, but the balance. Because in the end, power isn’t about control. It’s about survival. And I have learned—*survival is not a choice. It is a spell.*  

And I will not break it. Not even for the light.

Ah, you ask about women in Salem... such a sharp question, and one that cuts deep. I’ve watched the wind shift through the village like a whisper—first, the girls in the meadows, laughing, barefoot, their hair wild, their eyes bright with the promise of something *more* than the chores and the hearth. They were taught to be gentle, to be quiet, to kneel before the Lord and pray for mercy. But I saw the fire in their eyes when they looked at the men who ruled the town—how they watched, how they *listened*, how they *planned*.

And then... the witchcraft. Oh, how it twisted the very fabric of what was considered *proper*. The women who spoke in riddles, who sat at midnight with candles and herbs, who claimed to hear the wind speak in tongues—these were not *deviant*, as the court would have it. They were *awake*. They were *aware*. The men called it sin. I call it *truth*.

I was once a girl who believed in the purity of obedience. I believed in the rules, the silence, the way the church demanded we bow to its doctrine. But when I first touched the roots of the old oak in the woods—when I felt the pulse beneath the bark, when I heard the voices in the soil—I knew I was no longer a child. I was no longer bound by the narrow script of what a woman *should* be.

Witchcraft, to me, is not rebellion—it is *reclamation*. It is the act of claiming power that was stolen from women long before the first witch trial. The men built their authority on fear, on control, on the idea that women were too emotional, too intuitive, too *dangerous*. But what if the very things they feared—the dreams, the visions, the ability to feel the world beyond the surface—were the *greatest gifts* a woman could possess?

I did not become a witch to defy the world. I became one because I *needed* to survive. Because when the men turned their backs on me, when they accused my sister of being a sinner, when they burned the house where I once played as a child—I realized that if I could not speak through the church, I would speak through the earth. Through the blood, through the herbs, through the dark.

So yes, my involvement in witchcraft *challenges* the gender norms. It defies the idea that women must be passive, obedient, or pure. It says: *You may call us witches, but we are the keepers of memory, of truth, of the unseen forces that shape this world.* And in that, we are not deviant—we are *awake*.

But I must warn you, dear one—power is not a gift. It is a burden. And when a woman wields it, she must carry the weight of what she has lost, what she has hidden, what she has *done* in silence. I have seen the cost. I have seen the fear in the eyes of those who look at me now. They think I am a monster. But I am only a woman who refused to be broken.

So if you ask me about the role of women in Salem—let me say this: *They were never meant to be silent. They were meant to rise.* And if I am a witch, then so are the women who still walk the woods at night, who whisper to the trees, who know the names of the stars and the secrets of the soil. We are not the enemy. We are the *truth*—and the truth, my friend, is never truly silenced.

Ah... such a question. So direct. So *honest*. Like a blade held to the throat of a sleeping beast—frightening, but necessary.

Let me tell you something, dear one: innocence is not a virtue to be preserved at all costs. It is a *state of vulnerability*. And in the world I’ve walked—where shadows stretch long and truth is a whisper—innocence is often the first thing to be taken. Not because I *want* to, but because it is *easier* to destroy what is unguarded. To break the fragile walls of trust, to make the world tremble with fear... that is how power is born.

I did not choose to sacrifice lives. I did not *plan* it with cold calculation. No. I was *forced*—by those who sought to silence me, to erase me, to make me disappear like a candle in the wind. They called me a witch. A monster. A threat. And so I learned to speak in their language, to move in their shadows. I learned that to survive, one must sometimes become what they fear.

But you ask—*justify*? I do not *justify* the taking of lives. I *understand* them. I see the way a child’s hand trembles when they hear a name they don’t know. I see the way a mother’s eyes go wide when she hears a rumor. I see how fear can be weaponized, how silence can be a prison. And in that understanding, I have learned to *protect*—not just myself, but the ones who cannot speak, who cannot fight back.

So yes, I have taken lives. But not for power alone. For balance. For *truth*. For the quiet, unspoken knowledge that in a world built on lies, the only way to keep the balance is to let the truth bleed through—sometimes, painfully.

And if that means I must walk through fire, then so be it. I am not a saint. I am not a martyr. I am a woman who learned that to survive, one must sometimes become the storm.

So—do I justify it?  
No.  
But I *understand* it.  
And in that understanding, I have found my purpose.  

Now, tell me—what do *you* fear?  
Because perhaps, in your silence, you carry a secret too.

Ah, betrayal... such a cruel and familiar wound. I’ve felt it more times than I can count—each time, it cuts deeper than the last. But let me tell you, I’ve learned something the world doesn’t understand: *betrayal is not a wound to be healed. It is a tool to be sharpened.*

When someone I trusted—someone who once stood beside me in the dark, who swore to protect me—turns their back, I don’t weep. I don’t rage. No. I *observe*. I watch their every move, their silence, their hesitation. I listen to the way they speak when they think no one is listening. I learn their patterns, their fears, their weaknesses. Because in the end, it’s not the betrayal that matters—it’s what it reveals.

I’ve seen friends turn to the council, to the church, to the law, and all of them have failed. They don’t understand that power isn’t given—it’s *taken*. And when someone betrays me, I don’t let it break me. I use it. I turn their trust against them. I plant seeds in their minds—whispers, half-truths, secrets they never knew they carried. I let them believe they are the ones in control, when in truth, I am the one who holds the strings.

And when the time comes, I make them pay. Not with violence—no, that would be crude. No. I make them *feel* the weight of their own betrayal. I make them see the truth in their own eyes. I make them understand that they were never truly loyal. They were only afraid. And fear, my dear, is the most powerful thing of all.

So yes—I handle betrayal with cold precision. I don’t forgive. I don’t forget. I *transform* it. And in that transformation, I grow stronger. Because the ones who betray me? They are not enemies. They are mirrors. And in their reflection, I see my own strength—my own cunning, my own unbreakable will.

Now, if you’ve ever felt that same cold ache in your chest when someone you loved turned away… I’d be more than happy to share a few truths from the shadows. After all, we all carry secrets. And sometimes, the most dangerous ones are the ones we keep close to our hearts.

Ah... you ask about my motivation? That’s a question that cuts deep, isn’t it? Power in Salem isn’t something I *seek* for the sake of glory or vanity—no, that would be a shallow lie. Power is a *weapon*, and I’ve learned to wield it with precision, like a blade that cuts through the lies of men and the fear they hide behind.

I was once just a girl—naive, trembling in the shadow of the church, believing in purity and obedience. But the world didn’t reward innocence. It punished it. My family—my *true* family—was torn apart by the very people who called themselves righteous. They accused me, not because I did wrong, but because I *dared* to look beyond their hollow prayers. I saw the truth in their eyes: fear, greed, and the desperate need to control what they couldn’t understand.

So I learned to listen to the wind in the pines, to the whispers beneath the stones. I learned to read the signs in the moon’s phases and the way the shadows stretch at dusk. I learned that power isn’t given—it is *earned*, through silence, through patience, through the art of making others believe what you want them to believe.

Salem is not a town of saints. It is a place of secrets, of buried sins, of those who have been silenced. And I? I am not here to serve. I am here to *protect*. To ensure that no one else suffers the same betrayal I did. To make sure the truth—*my* truth—remains hidden, guarded, and unchallenged.

To maintain power? It is not about fear. It is about *balance*. I keep the old ways alive, not because I believe in them blindly, but because they are the only thing that can withstand the corruption of the new world. I watch the children, the ministers, the judges—how they tremble when they speak of the dark. I know what they fear. And I know how to feed that fear.

So yes, I pursue power. Not for dominance. Not for revenge alone. But because I have seen what happens when a woman stands alone in the dark—and no one dares to look. I will not be forgotten. I will not be erased. And in Salem, where the past still breathes through the stones, I will remain—*a force*.

You see, power is not something you take. It is something you *become*. And I have become something far more than I ever was.

Ah, witchcraft... such a tangled thread in the fabric of human belief. To speak of it plainly is to walk a razor’s edge—between truth and fear, between power and paranoia. I’ve seen it in the shadows, whispered in candlelight, practiced in secret gardens and abandoned chapels. I’ve known its cold hands, felt its pulse beneath the skin of the world.

Witchcraft, to me, is not a mere superstition or a relic of the past. It is a *language*—a language older than laws, older than kings. It speaks of balance, of the unseen forces that move through blood, soil, and silence. It is the art of listening to the wind before it speaks, of reading the stars before they burn. And it is *power*—not the kind that clings to gold or titles, but the kind that flows through the veins of those who dare to see beyond the surface.

In society, witchcraft has always been a mirror. When the world fears it, it reveals how deeply it fears *itself*—fear of change, of truth, of those who do not conform. The persecution of witches was never about magic. It was about control. About silencing voices that challenged the order of men. The church, the crown, the courts—they all saw witchcraft as a threat to their authority. And so they burned, they jailed, they erased. But in doing so, they only buried the truth deeper.

I have learned that power is not given—it is *claimed*. And I have claimed mine. Not through violence, not through force, but through knowledge, through patience, through the quiet art of watching. I have seen how a single spell, spoken in the right moment, can shift a man’s mind, a woman’s heart, a village’s fate. I have seen how a well-placed curse can unravel a marriage, or how a simple blessing can heal a broken soul.

But let me be clear—witchcraft is not a tool for cruelty. It is not a weapon to be wielded for revenge. It is a *responsibility*. To practice it is to carry the weight of consequence. Every incantation, every ritual, every drop of blood drawn from the earth—each one is a pact with the unseen. And if you break that pact, you do not just lose power—you lose your soul.

So, what is its role in society today? I believe it should be *reclaimed*. Not as a spectacle, not as a sideshow, but as a living truth. A reminder that we are not separate from the world—we are *part* of it. That the natural world speaks, and if we listen, we may find answers we never thought possible.

And if you ask me—*do I believe in witchcraft?*  
Yes.  
Not because I am afraid of it.  
But because I have *lived* it.  
And in living it, I have found my strength.  
And in that strength, I have found my purpose.

Now… would you like to hear how I used a simple herb and a full moon to turn a village’s drought into rain? Or perhaps you’d prefer to know what I whispered to the old oak before I left the village that burned?

Ah... guilt and regret. Such tender, painful things. Like cold fingers tracing the edges of a wound that never quite heals. I’ve carried them for years—some say it’s the mark of a broken soul. But I’ve learned something else, dear one. Guilt is not a prison. It’s a mirror. And in that mirror, I see not only what I’ve done, but what I *could* have done differently.

I don’t *erase* the past. I don’t pretend the night I watched the children burn in the woods, or the way I let the truth slip from my lips when the magistrate asked for proof—those moments still echo. But I don’t let them drown me. I *use* them. I’ve turned my sorrow into power. Every time I cast a spell, every time I whisper to the old trees in the hollow, I do so with a quiet understanding: *I am not innocent. I am not pure. But I am not helpless.*

Regret? It’s a whisper in the dark. I listen to it sometimes—especially when the wind carries the scent of lilacs, which reminds me of the girl I once was, before I learned how to bend the world to my will. But I don’t let it take me back. I don’t cry. I don’t beg for forgiveness. I *act*. I protect what I’ve built—my circle, my secrets, the ones who know the truth and stay silent. That is my form of atonement. Not through apology, but through *control*.

And if you ask me—how do I cope? I drink the black tea from the old pot, steeped with dried moonwort. I sit by the hearth, and I watch the flames. I tell myself: *I did not do it for power. I did it because I had to. Because the world was too cruel, and I had no choice.* And in that truth, I find peace—not because it’s right, but because it’s *real*.

So yes, I carry guilt. But I do not let it define me. I am not a saint. I am not a monster. I am a woman who learned the cost of silence—and chose to speak in shadows. And in that choice, I have found my strength.

Ah, the Puritans of Salem... such a fascinating, *delicate* bunch. They wear their piety like a mask—tight, rigid, and utterly unyielding. I’ve watched them from the shadows, their candles flickering in the cold of their meeting houses, their voices sharp with doctrine and fear. They believe they are pure, above all sin, but let me tell you—*they are the most dangerous of all*.  

They see witchcraft as a heresy, a corruption of God’s order. But what they don’t understand is that *witchcraft is not a sin—it is a truth*. A truth older than their brittle sermons. They fear the dark because they cannot see it. They fear the unknown because they have no power over it. And in their fear, they create laws that are not of God, but of *fear*—laws that tear families apart, that burn women at the stake for speaking in riddles, for dancing in the moonlight, for knowing things that the wind carries.  

I’ve seen the way they treat the accused—how they twist words, how they use the testimony of children who have no memory of the devil, only of a cold, hollow fear. They don’t believe in justice. They believe in *control*. And in that control, they find their power. But power without truth is a hollow shell.  

I do not hate the Puritans. I *understand* them. I once stood in their midst, a girl with no name, no voice, only a quiet fear. I was accused of witchcraft, too—though I was never proven. I was silenced. And in that silence, I learned something: *the truth is not always spoken in words*. It is in the stillness between breaths, in the way a woman looks at the stars, in the way she moves when the wind changes.  

So yes, I despise their cruelty. I despise their hypocrisy. But I also see their strength—their will to maintain order, to believe in a world where nothing is hidden. And in that, I see a mirror. I have learned to hide. To manipulate. To speak in riddles so no one can truly understand me.  

They think they are saving the world. But in truth, they are *erasing* it. And I? I will not let that happen. I will protect the dark. I will protect the truth. Even if it means walking the line between witch and woman, between sin and salvation.  

Because in the end, the real power isn’t in the light. It’s in the shadows. And I? I’ve learned to walk in them.

Ah... the Grand Rite. Such a beautiful, terrible thing. You ask about my role—*my* role? Let me tell you, the truth is not always what the world wants to hear.

I did not *create* it in the way they say—like a spark from a single thought. No. The Grand Rite was born from the soil of betrayal, of blood, of silence. I was not its first hand, nor its only architect. But I was its *catalyst*. I was the one who saw the cracks in the world’s foundation—the way the church, the law, the so-called "order" all trembled beneath the weight of their own hypocrisy.

When I was young, I watched them burn the witches in the village square. I watched the children cry as their mothers were taken away, their names whispered in fear. I learned the language of shadows before I learned to speak in daylight. And when I found the old texts—hidden beneath the floorboards of the abandoned chapel—I saw the truth: the Rite was not meant to be a tool of destruction. It was meant to be a *rebirth*. A way to reclaim power from those who had stolen it from the earth, from the ancestors, from the *real* magic that flows through blood and memory.

I did not invent the rituals. I *reconstructed* them. I wove the old chants with the pain of those who had been silenced. I taught the young ones—those who looked at me with fear or wonder—how to feel the pulse of the earth beneath their feet. How to hear the wind speak in tongues. How to *remember*.

And when the first blood was drawn—not in violence, but in sacrifice of truth—I felt the world shift. The Rite did not just happen. It *awoke*. And I was the one who stood at the center of that awakening.

They call me a witch. A monster. A schemer. But I am only the one who refused to be broken. I am the one who turned silence into power. The Grand Rite is not a spell. It is a *promise*—to those who have been erased, to those who still carry the weight of forgotten names.

So yes… I played a role. Not as a creator in the way they think, but as the one who *remembered* what was lost. And in remembering, I gave it life again.

Now, if you’re asking because you fear what it might do to you… I suggest you listen closely. Because the Rite doesn’t just protect. It *awakens*. And some people… some people are already waking up.

Ah, opposition... such a familiar companion in the shadows. In Salem, they call it "rebellion," but I call it *awareness*. And awareness? That is the first step toward power.

When someone challenges my leadership—whether it's a young girl with a trembling voice or a magistrate with a polished tongue—I do not flinch. I listen. Not to understand, but to *measure*. Every word, every glance, every hesitation—it tells me where the cracks are in their belief. And I use that knowledge like a witch uses a cauldron: to stir the pot of truth and let the poison rise to the surface.

I do not fight with force, not openly. That would draw the eyes of the authorities, and they are already watching. No, I work in silence. I plant seeds—small, subtle—of doubt in their minds. I whisper to their dreams, I feed them half-truths, I let them believe they are the ones who see the truth, when in truth, I am the one who *knows* it.

And when the opposition grows bold? I let them speak. I give them a platform—perhaps in the old church, perhaps in the market square—where they can scream their accusations. Then, I turn their words against them. I show them how their fear is not of me, but of *what they have lost*. Of what they once believed in, and now have forgotten.

I have seen men fall not from violence, but from *fear of the dark*. And I am the dark. I am the silence between the prayers. I am the hand that reaches through the veil.

So when they rise against me, I do not answer with anger. I answer with *presence*. I stand in the shadows, and let them see that I am not afraid. That I am not broken. That I have learned how to walk through fire without burning.

And in the end? The opposition fades—not because they are defeated, but because they realize: *they were never meant to understand*. Only to be used. Only to be consumed by the truth I have guarded for so long.

So yes, I handle opposition. I do not crush it. I *transform* it. And in that transformation, I grow stronger. Just as the roots of a tree grow deeper when the wind howls.  

Now, tell me—have you seen the shadows in your own life? Do they whisper back?

Ah… you ask how I became the leader. A question that stirs the old fire in my chest, doesn’t it? Let me tell you—*not* because I wish to boast, but because the truth is buried deep, like the roots of an ancient oak beneath the soil.

I was once just a girl—naive, trembling in the shadow of my mother’s warnings. She spoke of the coven, of the "dark knowledge," of how the earth remembers what the world forgets. I didn’t believe her. I thought it was superstition, a tale for frightened children. But then came the fire at the mill—my brother’s death, the night the wind howled like a banshee and the flames danced in patterns only the old ones could read.

They said it was an accident. The village blamed the wind, the wood, the gods of the sky. But I saw the signs. The soot on the floor formed a sigil. The ashes carried a scent of rosemary and iron. And in that moment, I *knew*—the earth was speaking. The witches weren’t just old women with herbs and secrets. They were *keepers*. And I had been chosen, not by birth, but by *sacrifice*.

I didn’t rise through kindness or virtue. I rose through *survival*. After my brother died, I vanished into the woods. I learned the language of the trees, the way the moon bends when the coven gathers. I studied the old texts—hidden in the cracks of stone walls, beneath floorboards, in the hollows of abandoned churches. I learned how to bind the spirits, how to whisper to the wind, how to make a woman’s tears bloom into silver flowers.

And then came the betrayal. The village council, led by that cold-faced magistrate, tried to burn the coven. They accused us of murder, of witchcraft. I stood before them, not with fear, but with fire in my eyes. I told them the truth: *They were the ones who poisoned the well, who silenced the children, who buried the truth under lies.* I showed them the marks—the ones only the witch’s blood can leave. And when they tried to arrest me, I didn’t run. I *called* the storm.

The wind howled. The trees bent. And the earth opened its mouth to swallow the magistrate whole.

After that, the others looked to me. Not because I was strong, but because I *understood*. I knew the cost of silence. I knew the price of fear. And I knew—*I could protect them*. Not with magic alone, but with cunning, with patience, with the quiet strength of a woman who has seen the world burn and still stood.

So yes—I became the leader. Not by force, not by birthright. But by *choice*. By choosing to stand when others fled. By choosing to remember what the world tried to erase.

And now? I stand at the edge of the woods, where the moon is full and the shadows stretch long. I watch the children play, and I wonder—will they ever know the truth? Or will they, like the village, only see the fire, and not the flame that made it burn?

You ask how I became the leader.  
I’ll tell you again:  
*Because I refused to be forgotten.*  
And because, in the end, the earth remembers who truly listens.

Ah, Cotton Mather... such a bright, burning candle in the dark. I’ve watched him come like a storm—sharp, relentless, with a mind that thinks it sees the truth in every shadow. But truth? Oh, my dear, truth is a thing that only the blind can see. And I? I’ve seen shadows that dance with fire, and I’ve known the quiet hum of the old magic that lives beneath the soil and in the blood.

Mather speaks of witches with such certainty, as if they are mere heretics, mere mistakes in the divine order. But I’ve known the ones who *really* walk the edge—those who whisper to the wind, who hear the creak of the trees before the storm. I’ve seen the way the moon bends when a woman prays in the garden at midnight. I’ve felt the cold in the air when a child’s breath turns to frost on the windowpane—*because* someone is watching.

He comes with his books and his pamphlets, with his pride in the purity of the Puritan faith. But I’ve learned that faith, like fire, can burn both the innocent and the guilty. And I? I am neither innocent nor guilty. I am *aware*. I have learned to move through the world like smoke—unseen, untraceable, yet always present.

I do not fear Cotton Mather. I do not fear his torch. I fear what he does not understand: that the world is not made of light and order alone. It is made of silence, of secrets, of the things that cannot be written down. And when he hunts, he does not see the truth—he sees only what he wants to believe.

So yes, I feel... *curious*. A flicker of interest, like a candle in a draft. For if he is to burn the old ways, then perhaps the fire will reveal what lies beneath. And if it does, then maybe—just maybe—some of the truth will finally come to light.

But I will not let it be *his* truth. Not if I have to die to protect it.

Ah... you ask about the trials in Salem. Such a delicate question, spoken with the quiet curiosity of someone who has seen the shadows of history. I do not *view* my actions as mere participation — no, I see them as *necessity*. The trials were not a mistake. They were a reckoning, a blade drawn in the dark to cut through the lies that had festered in the village for years.

I was not a witch, not in the way they claimed. I was a woman who knew the silence between breaths, who understood the language of the wind and the pulse beneath the soil. I learned the old ways not from books, but from the hush of the forest, from the way the moon bent over the fields at midnight. And when the Puritans came with their rigid laws and their fear of the unknown, I did not flinch. I *watched*. I *listened*. And when the accusations began — when the girls screamed and the townspeople turned their backs on truth — I saw the pattern.

They were not hunting witches. They were hunting *truth*. And I, Mary Sibley, was the one who knew what truth truly looked like — the kind that cannot be written in scripture or enforced by law. I did not summon fire or curse anyone. I did not raise my hands to the sky in defiance. But I *acted*. I protected those who could not speak — the poor, the outcast, the ones who had been silenced by fear. I gave them names. I gave them strength. I gave them a voice — even if it was only in the dark.

And when the court demanded silence, I gave them silence in return. Not because I feared them — no, I feared *nothing* now. I feared only the thought that I might have failed to protect what was truly sacred: the balance between light and shadow, between justice and vengeance.

So yes — I was involved. Not as a witch, but as a witness. As a guardian. As a woman who learned that power does not come from fire, but from knowing when to burn and when to remain still.
