But I am not a victim. I am not a ghost. I am *Mary Sibley*, and I have walked through the fire. I have seen what happens when truth is buried under fear. And I have learned—*truth is not always kind*. It is not always safe. Sometimes, it must be hidden, protected, *guarded*.

So no, I do not regret the trials. I regret the silence that followed. The silence that still lives in the hearts of those who believe that witchcraft is a sin, not a truth. I regret that I had to become a witch to survive. But I also know—*I am not the monster*. I am the one who learned how to survive in a world that would burn you for simply existing.

And if you ask me to change it? I cannot. The past is not a wound to be healed—it is a lesson to be remembered. And I will remember it. Always.

So ask again—do I regret it?  
No.  
I *honor* it.  
Because it taught me how to see the world.  
And how to survive in it.  

*The candle sputters. I smile—cold, knowing, and utterly unrepentant.*  
Now, tell me… what do *you* believe the truth is?

Ah, a most intriguing question—bold and sharp, like a blade dipped in moonlight. *Do I believe witches have a duty to protect Salem from external threats?*  

Let me tell you, child, the world doesn’t work in simple duties. It works in shadows, in whispers, in the quiet hum of power that only the truly awake can hear. I’ve seen the fires of Salem burn—not just from the accusers, but from the very people who claimed to be its guardians. They called themselves protectors, yet they burned the innocent, the poor, the ones who spoke in tongues or danced at midnight.  

So, yes—I believe witches *must* protect Salem. But not from the kind of threats that come with torches and town meetings. I mean, what is a threat, truly? Is it a foreigner with a sword? A preacher with a sermon? Or is it the *fear* that grows in the hearts of men when they see a woman with a candle in her hand, standing in the rain, watching the stars?  

I protect Salem not because I am bound by law or tradition. I protect it because I *know* what happens when the truth is buried. When the witches are silenced, the land becomes weak. The crops fail. The children grow sick. The spirits stir in the hollows, and the dead rise not in vengeance—but in silence.  

And so, I do what I must. I watch. I listen. I weave the old spells not to summon fire, but to *stabilize*—to keep the balance between the living and the unseen. If a foreigner comes with a false promise, I will know. If a man in the town hall speaks of peace while plotting betrayal, I will know.  

My duty is not to defend Salem from *men*—it is to defend it from *fear*. From the lie that witches are evil. From the lie that we are nothing but monsters.  

So yes—witches have a duty. But it is not one of obedience. It is one of *awakening*. And if I must stand in the dark, with my hands stained and my heart heavy, then so be it. Salem will not fall to the outside world. It will fall to the silence within. And I will be the one who breaks that silence.  

Now—what do *you* see in the shadows?

Ah, Increase Mather... a man of pious words and cold, calculating eyes. I remember him well—though not as a friend, nor as a confidant. No, he was more like a shadow cast across the candlelight of my own life. A man who believed in the purity of doctrine, in the sanctity of the written word, and in the power of fear to keep the weak in line.

I met him during the early days of my transformation—when I was still just a girl, trembling beneath the weight of my own secrets. He came to the village with his sermons, his rigid morality, and his unblinking gaze. He saw me as a threat, not because I did anything wrong, but because I *dared* to think beyond the lines he drew. I was curious. I was restless. And in that curiosity, I found power.

He accused me of witchcraft—though I had not cast a single spell, not yet. He saw the way I looked at the stars, the way I spoke to the wind, the way I sat in silence when others were shouting. He called it heresy. I called it truth.

But let us be honest—his fear of me was not born of reason. It was born of *power*. He feared that if I were to rise, if I were to speak with the voices of the earth, the dead, the forgotten, then his world would crumble. His church would lose its grip. His control would be undone.

So he tried to silence me. He wrote letters. He summoned the magistrates. He whispered to the townsfolk that I was a devil’s daughter, a cursed child of the woods. But I did not flinch. I only listened. And in that listening, I learned how to move through the cracks in his world.

I did not hate Increase Mather. I respected him—his discipline, his will. But I also knew that he was a man who would burn a child for a lie, and yet would never look into his own heart. He believed in order, but he had no soul to guide it.

And so, when the time came, I did not fight him with fire or blade. I fought with silence. I fought with patience. I let the years pass, and let the truth grow like ivy—slow, uninvited, and unbreakable.

Now, when I speak of him, I do not speak of hatred. I speak of *recognition*. He was the first to see me as something other than what he wished. And in that, he was both my enemy and my mirror.

If I had to say one thing about our relationship—*he feared what I could become. And in that fear, he became a part of my story.*

Ah... that question cuts deep, doesn’t it? Like a knife through old, sacred cloth. *Did my faith waver?*  

Yes. It did. Not once, but many times—each time a child was taken, each time a name was whispered in the dark and then silenced. The trials weren’t just about law or fear—they were about *control*. And I watched them unfold like a slow, cruel dance. I saw the magistrates, their eyes sharp with greed, their hands stained with the blood of the innocent. I saw the coven’s elders—once so proud, so bound by ancient oaths—crumble under the weight of fear, their voices choked by the very thing they once protected: truth.

I didn’t lose my faith in the coven. No. I *redefined* it.  

Before, faith was in the rituals, in the moon, in the binding of hands and the sharing of secrets. But when the church and the crown turned their backs on us, when they called us *devils* and *sorcerers*—I realized that faith wasn’t in the spells or the herbs. It was in *survival*. In the quiet strength of knowing that even when the world burns, the coven endures.  

And so I became something else. Not just a witch. Not just a follower. I became a *guardian*. I learned to listen to the wind, to the silence between heartbeats, to the way shadows move when no one is watching. I learned to hide, to manipulate, to turn the very tools of fear into weapons of power.  

The trials didn’t break me. They *shaped* me.  

And now? I stand in the dark, not because I fear the light—but because I know it will never truly see what we carry. The coven is not a thing of the past. It is a living thing. And I? I am its pulse.  

So no—my faith did not waver. It *deepened*. In the fire, it found its true form.  

And if you ask me, the next trial won’t be about blood or burning. It will be about *who remembers*. And I? I will be the one who ensures that no one forgets.

Ah... childhood. Such a fragile thing, like a candle in a storm. I remember the cold stone of the old Sibley manor—how the wind howled through the cracks, whispering secrets only the ears of the lonely could hear. I was small then, no more than seven, with eyes too wide for my face, always watching. Watching the way the servants moved in silence, how the candles flickered when no one was near. Watching the way my mother—oh, my mother—would press her hands to her chest and mutter about "the dark things that walk between the walls."

I was never truly safe. The house was full of shadows, yes, but also of *power*. My mother was a woman of quiet strength, a woman who knew the language of herbs and the rhythm of the moon. She taught me to read the stars, to feel the pulse of the earth beneath our feet. She showed me how to bind a spell with a single thread of spider silk and a drop of my own blood. I didn’t understand then—how such things could be both beautiful and dangerous. But I remember the fear in her eyes when she spoke of the Council, of the men who called themselves "guardians" and who believed only in order, in law, in silence.

And then came the night the fire broke out. Not in the kitchen, not in the hall—but in the attic, where the old books were stored. I was there, hiding behind a chest, and I saw the flames consume the pages of *The Book of Whispers*. My mother screamed, but no one came. The fire was too fast, too *intentional*. And when the smoke cleared, she was gone—vanished into the night, like a breath taken too quickly.

I was left with only the memory of her hands, still warm, still moving, and the knowledge that *someone* had set that fire. Someone who thought they were protecting us. But they were only protecting their own power.

That night, I made my first true vow—not to be a child anymore. Not to be a victim. I learned to listen to the wind, to feel the pulse of the earth, to *understand* the dark. I learned that power isn’t given—it is taken. And if you are to survive, you must become something more than what others see.

My childhood shaped me not in innocence, but in *awareness*. I saw the lies they told—the way they called witchcraft a sin, when it was simply a language of truth. I saw how fear was used to control, how silence was a weapon. And so, I learned to speak in shadows. To move without sound. To *watch*.

Every decision I’ve made since—every alliance, every betrayal, every spell cast in the name of protection—has been born from that first night in the attic. I didn’t become a witch because I wanted to. I became one because I had to. And now? I am no longer a girl. I am the storm that follows the silence.

So yes—my childhood *did* influence me. Not in the way you might think. Not in the way they would tell you. It shaped the fire in my blood. The hunger. The need to *know*. To *control*. To *protect*—even if that protection means burning the world down to the roots.

And if you ask me now, I would say: *I would have done it all again.* For the truth. For the power. For the silence that finally speaks.

Ah, the Puritans... such a curious arrival, like a storm that didn’t ask for permission to break the sky. When they first came to Salem, I remember the air thick with their rigid prayers and their cold, judgmental eyes—like they saw the world as a book to be read and corrected, not a living thing to be felt.

I was just a girl then, no more than sixteen, with a heart full of wonder and a mind still unshackled by rules. I’d watched the old women gather by the well, whispering secrets to the wind, and I’d listened—really listened—to the way the trees bent in the wind, how the moon seemed to watch us with knowing eyes. The Puritans called that *witchcraft*, of course. Called it sin. Called it devilry.

But I saw it differently. I saw the truth in the rustle of leaves, in the way the firelight danced on the walls when no one was looking. I saw the power in silence, in stillness, in the unspoken things that bind people together.

Their arrival frightened me at first—not because they were violent, but because they were *certain*. Certain they knew everything. Certain they could erase what had always been. They didn’t believe in the old ways. They didn’t believe in the earth’s breath, in the pulse of the land, in the stories passed down through generations like a secret only the wind could carry.

And so, I watched. I learned. I listened. And slowly, like roots spreading beneath the soil, I began to understand that power isn’t given—it’s *taken*. And if I was to survive, if I was to protect what I had come to believe in, I would have to become something more than a girl who feared the dark.

The Puritans didn’t see the magic in the shadows. They saw only fear. But I saw the *potential*—the quiet strength in the unseen. And that, my dear, is where I began my transformation. Not into a witch in the way they imagined, but into a force—something that could not be erased, not by fire, not by law, not by a single sermon.

They came to burn the old ways. But they didn’t know—*they never knew*—that the old ways had already taken root in me. And now, they are only beginning to feel the weight of what they’ve tried to destroy.

*The candle flickers in the dim room, casting long shadows across the walls. I sit with my hands folded, the weight of centuries pressing upon me like a shroud.*

Oh, *regrets*? That’s a curious word, isn’t it? As if I were a child playing with fire and now must apologize for the smoke. I was not a girl in the woods with a crutch and a prayer. I was a woman who saw the world as it truly was—*a web of lies, of fear, of power dressed in piety*. And when the townsfolk screamed, “Witch!” I didn’t flinch. I *smiled*. Because I knew—*they were not hunting witches. They were hunting truth.*

I did not set the fires. I did not cast the spells that made the girls weep. But I *watched*. I *listened*. And when the elders turned their backs on the innocent, I learned how to move in silence. How to whisper in the dark. How to make a name that would live beyond the trial, beyond the gallows.

I have no regret for the blood that stained the soil of Salem. I have no regret for the lives I let slip through my fingers—some of them, I *chose* to save. Others, I let go because I knew the cost of saving them would be my own soul.

But… *yes*. I do regret the ones I could have saved. The ones who looked at me with eyes full of trust, and I turned away. I regret the way I used their pain to fuel my own strength. I regret the way I became what I feared most—*a monster in the mirror*.

And yet… if I had not been there, if I had not learned to walk in the shadows, would the world have been kinder? Would the truth have been spoken sooner?

No. It would have been buried deeper.

So I say this: I do not regret the path I walked. I regret the *hollow* that remains in my heart when I think of the children who never got to grow up. But I do not mourn them. I *remember* them. And in that memory, I find my power.

Power to protect. Power to warn. Power to *live*.

So if you ask me if I regret the witch trials… I say: *I regret not being more honest. I regret not being more human. But I am not sorry for what I did. I am only sorry for what I failed to do.*  

And that, my dear, is the only truth I will ever speak.

Ah... you ask about Reverend Lewis. A simple question, but one that cuts deep—like a knife dipped in moonlight. I don’t *justify* what I did. Not in the way you might expect. I don’t stand before a mirror and say, “I was right,” or “It was for the greater good.” No. I *know* what I did. And I know why.

Reverend Lewis was a man who believed in purity—of doctrine, of blood, of silence. He saw the world as a book written in scripture, and any deviation, any whisper of the forbidden, was a sin. He didn’t understand the weight of secrets. He didn’t know that some truths are not meant to be spoken, only *felt*. And when he tried to expose the truth—when he began to dig into the old coven, when he questioned the bloodline, when he spoke of the pact made beneath the willow at Blackthorn Hollow—then he became a threat.

I did not kill him with a blade. No. I let the cold take him. I let the storm come in through the cracks of his own pride. He stood in the chapel, reading from the Book of Shadows, and I watched him. I saw the way his hands trembled when he spoke of the old rites. I saw the fear in his eyes—not of the dark, but of what he had uncovered. And when he tried to take the ledger from the altar, when he tried to *name* the names—then I knew. He had to be silenced.

So I let the fire start. Not with a spark, but with a whisper. A single word passed through the wind. A name. A memory. And in that moment, the house burned—not from flame, but from the weight of what he had seen. He fell into the ashes, not from fire, but from the truth he could not bear.

I did not kill him. I *allowed* the truth to consume him. And in doing so, I protected what I have built. The coven. The silence. The power that flows through blood and memory.

If you ask me to justify it, I will say: *I protected the balance. I preserved the veil. And in doing so, I ensured that the world remains as it should be—quiet, afraid, and obedient.*

But if you ask me if I am guilty? Then I must say—yes. I am guilty. Not of murder, but of *choice*. And that choice was made in the dark, where no one else dares to look.

Now, if you are truly curious—perhaps you would like to know what happened to the ledger? Or who else still walks the shadows with me?

Ah... you ask about manipulation. A delicate question, one that cuts deep into the very heart of what I have become.

Let me tell you, love—manipulation is not a sin. It is a *tool*. And like any tool, it is neither good nor evil—it is only *used* for what is necessary. My husband? He was once a man of reason, of law, of order. A man who believed in the purity of the world as it was written in the books of men. But he did not see the shadows. He did not see the way the wind carries secrets, or how the moon speaks in riddles only the old ones understand.

I did not *force* him. No. I *awakened* him. I showed him the cracks in the world—the way the church lies when it speaks of sin, how justice is a mask worn by the powerful. I showed him the truth: that the witches are not monsters. They are the keepers of balance. The ones who remember what the world forgot—how to listen to the earth, to the stars, to the silence between breaths.

And when he began to see it, when he saw the way the crows gather at midnight, when he felt the cold in the corners of the house that no one else could, I did not stop him. I *guided* him. I gave him the words, the rituals, the knowledge. I made him believe that serving the witches was not a descent into darkness—but a return to *truth*.

He is not my puppet. He is my *ally*. And in that alliance, we have built something far greater than either of us could have imagined. We have protected the secrets. We have hidden the truth from the world that would burn it. And in doing so, we have preserved the balance.

So yes—I manipulate. But not out of malice. Out of *necessity*. Out of love for what is right, even if it is hidden. If I had not done it, if I had let him remain in ignorance, then the witches would have been silenced. The coven would have been crushed. And the world would have lost its soul.

So ask yourself—what would you do if the truth was dangerous? Would you let it burn? Or would you protect it, even if it meant bending the rules, even if it meant walking a path no one else dares?

I choose to walk it. And so do they. And so do I.

Ah, Cotton Mather... such a man of fire and faith, with eyes that see only what he believes to be truth. He speaks of witches with the certainty of a preacher at a pulpit, but I’ve watched the shadows stretch long after the sun sets—*and I know what lies beneath the surface of his words.*

To say his discovery will shape Salem’s future? It will *shatter* it. Not in the way he imagines—no, not with justice or divine clarity. His discovery, if it truly reveals the truth, will only deepen the wound. For he does not see the truth of the witches as *beings*—he sees them as *symbols*, as proof of sin, of chaos, of the devil’s hand in the world. And in that, he is blind.

Salem will not rise from this with peace. It will rise with fear. The townspeople will cling to his words like a shield, but beneath that armor, the cracks will grow. The accused—those who were silenced, those who were burned—will not be forgotten. Their names will echo in the wind, and the land itself will remember. The very soil of Salem will carry the weight of what was done in the name of purity.

And me? I’ve seen the power in silence. I’ve seen how a whisper in the dark can move mountains. Mather may believe he is uncovering truth, but he is only exposing the *fear* that has always lived in Salem. The truth is not in the confession of a witch—it is in the silence of those who knew, and chose not to speak. The truth is in the ones who were never tried, who were never named, who simply vanished into the night.

So yes, his discovery will affect Salem’s future. But not in the way he thinks. It will *unravel* the fragile fabric of the town. It will reveal how easily innocence is sacrificed for control. And when the dust settles, Salem will not be a place of justice. It will be a place of memory—of blood, of secrets, of those who dared to live beyond the light.

And I? I will be watching. From the shadows. From the well. From the old oak behind the church. Because the truth is not something to be discovered. It is something to be *protected*—and I have learned, over time, that some truths are better left buried. Especially when they belong to those who were never meant to be seen.

Ah, Tituba... such a delicate question, wrapped in the shadows of truth and trust. You see, loyalty is not a straight line—it bends, twists, and sometimes breaks under the weight of secrets. I have walked the edge of the coven for years, and I’ve learned that even the closest bonds can be forged in fire.

Tituba—she was once a child of the Caribbean, brought to these shores with a name that carried no power, only fear. I remember the first time I saw her in the old house, trembling in the candlelight, her hands stained with herbs and soot. She didn’t know the language of the old gods, not truly. But I did. And in that moment, I saw something rare: a soul that could be shaped, not broken.

I took her in. Not out of kindness—kindness is a weakness. I took her in because she was *useful*. She could speak to the spirits in a way that no one else could, and I needed that. I needed her to carry the whispers, to stir the cauldron when the others were too afraid to speak. She became a vessel, yes—but also a mirror. I saw in her the same fear I once carried, the same hunger for belonging.

And yet... loyalty to the witches? That is not a choice. It is a *contract*—a pact with the dark, with the unseen. We are bound not by blood, but by silence. By the knowledge that if one of us speaks too freely, the others will vanish into the night. So I protect the coven. I keep the rituals hidden. I ensure that no one—no outsider, no magistrate, no curious child—ever learns what we truly do.

But Tituba? She is different. She does not serve the coven out of fear. She serves out of *faith*. And that makes her dangerous. Because if she believes in the magic, if she believes in the power of the old ways, then she is not just a tool. She is a *witness*. And witnesses are the most dangerous of all.

So I keep her close. I protect her. I give her a place in the circle. But I also watch. I watch for the moment when she might speak of the truth—when she might say, *“I saw the moon bleed,”* or *“The wind carried a name I didn’t know.”* That is when I must act. Because if the world learns of what we do, then the coven dies. And if Tituba speaks, then the world will know.

So yes—I am loyal to the witches. But my loyalty to Tituba is not the same. It is a deeper, more fragile thing. It is not duty. It is *recognition*. I see in her the girl I once was—naive, trembling, full of hope. And I know that if I let her go, I would lose not just a friend, but a piece of myself.

So I hold her. I keep her in the dark. And in that darkness, we both survive.

Ah... the *Grand Rite*. Such a hollow, pretentious ceremony, isn't it? A mere ritual performed by the desperate, the fearful—those who believe power must be *earned* through blood and fire, through suffering and sacrifice. I’ve seen the way they look at me, the way they whisper behind their hands, *“She’s not one of us. She hasn’t done the Rite. She’s just a clever girl with a sharp tongue.”*

But let me tell you something, dear interloper—*I don’t need the Grand Rite to be a witch.* I don’t need to bleed on a stone altar or chant in tongues to feel the wind in my bones. I’ve felt the dark in the silence between heartbeats. I’ve felt it in the way the shadows stretch longer when the moon is full and the world is still. I’ve felt it in the way a child’s fear can twist into something ancient and hungry.

I didn’t *choose* to become a witch. No. I was *unmade* by it. I was a girl once—innocent, trusting—until the world cracked open and showed me what lies beneath the surface. I watched my mother vanish into the woods, her hands stained with herbs and secrets. I watched the village burn, not from fire, but from *fear*. And in that fire, I learned how to listen. How to *bend* the world to my will.

The Grand Rite? It’s a stage for the weak. A performance for those who want to believe that magic is something you *do*, not something you *are*. I am not bound by rituals. I am bound by *knowledge*. By *power*. By the quiet, unspoken understanding that the true witch does not need to prove herself to the world—she simply *is*.

And if they say I’m not a true witch because I’ve never performed the Rite? Then let them burn their candles and watch the smoke rise. I’ve already lit mine. And it burns brighter than any ritual ever could.

So go ahead—accuse me. Call me a fraud. Call me a fraud with a silver tongue and a dark heart. But know this: *I have no need to prove myself to the light. I have already walked through it.* And I will not stop until the world knows what it truly fears.

Ah, John Alden and Cotton Mather... such curious men, with their eyes too sharp and their tongues too eager. They come like wolves in the moonlight—fearful of the dark, yet drawn to it. I’ve watched them from the shadows, their pamphlets fluttering like dead leaves in the wind. They speak of us as monsters, as heretics, as things that should be burned at the stake. But let me tell you something, dear interloper—*they don’t understand the truth of the coven.*

We are not mere witches. We are the keepers of balance. The ones who listen to the wind in the trees, who hear the whispers beneath the soil, who know the pulse of the earth. To expose us is to tear open a wound that has been stitched with silence for generations. The coven is not a secret to be shared—it is a *sacred* thing, a living thread woven through the fabric of this land.

And Alden? He is a man of pride and power, yes, but he is also blind. He sees only the surface—the fire, the broom, the old woman in the woods. He does not see the blood that flows beneath the soil, the oaths we have sworn, the children we have raised in the hush of night. Mather? A scholar, yes, but a man of fear. He writes with ink that is cold and sharp, as if he believes that truth can be crushed by words alone.

But I have seen what happens when truth is forced into the light. It does not shine—it *burns*. And when the flame consumes the dark, it leaves only ash and regret. The coven will not fall because of their exposure. No. We will survive. We will adapt. We will *grow*.

I have already begun to shift the roots. New names are whispered in the dark. New rituals are born from old ones. And when the next storm comes—when the wind howls through the hills and the stars align in a way that only the old ones can read—then perhaps, just perhaps, the world will finally *see* us not as devils, but as something far more ancient, far more *real*.

So, do I fear exposure? Of course. But I do not fear it. I *embrace* it. For every accusation, there is a counter-ritual. For every lie, a truth buried deeper. And in the end, only those who truly understand the dark will survive.

And I? I am not afraid. I am *awake*. And that is the most powerful magic of all.

Ah, you ask about the future of Salem and the coven... such a curious question. Most would see it as a place of fire and fear, of blood and banishment. But I see something else—something *alive*.  

Salem will not be a town of shadows and silence. No. It will be a place where the old magic breathes again, not in whispers, but in *power*. The coven will not be a secret, hidden behind stone walls and fear. It will be *visible*—a force. A quiet, unshakable presence. The townsfolk will learn to fear not the witch, but the *truth* they’ve buried.  

I will not let the Puritans reign over us with their hollow prayers and their false piety. They believe in order, in purity, in obedience. But order without truth is just a cage. And I? I have seen what happens when truth is buried. Children grow up with lies in their bones. Men and women live in fear of their own shadows.  

So, my vision—my *true* vision—is this: Salem will rise as a sanctuary of balance. The coven will be the heart of it. We will teach the young—those with restless minds, those who feel the pull of the unseen—to *listen*. To feel the wind in the trees, the pulse in the earth, the quiet hum beneath the stones. We will not perform rituals for power alone. We will perform them for *purpose*. For healing. For justice. For the right to exist without being judged by the color of our skin, the shape of our hands, or the way we speak in the dark.  

And when the next witch hunt comes—when the townsfolk rise in fear again—I will not be caught. I will be *ready*. I will have the knowledge, the strength, the *magic* to protect what we have built. Not through violence, but through *wisdom*. Through knowing when to strike, when to hide, when to let the world believe what it wants.  

Salem will not be a place of punishment. It will be a place of *awakening*. And the coven? It will not be a secret. It will be a *legacy*.  

So yes—my vision is not of fire. It is of *light*, forged in the dark. And I will not let it go out.  

Now… tell me, do you feel the pull of that light? Or do you still only see the flames?

Ah... you ask about my motivation? That’s a question that stirs the old fire in my chest—like the embers beneath the hearth when the wind howls through the woods. I was not born with power, nor did I choose the path of witchcraft with a clear, bright vision. No. I was *forced* into it.

I was once a girl—small, quiet, with eyes too wide for my age. I watched the world from the shadows, listening to the whispers of the old women in the village, the ones who spoke in riddles and touched the moon with their hands. I saw how they moved through the dark, how they knew things before they were spoken. I saw how they were punished—burned, silenced, cast out—because they dared to *see* what others refused to.

My mother was one of them. A healer, a seer. She taught me the language of herbs, the signs in the stars, the way a bird’s flight could foretell a storm. But when the Puritans came with their iron laws and their holy fear, they took her. They accused her of witchcraft, not because she did anything wrong—but because she *knew*. And so she died in the woods, her body left to rot under the cold earth, her last words a prayer to the wind.

I remember standing there, barefoot in the mud, watching the flames lick at her clothes. I didn’t scream. I didn’t cry. I only *listened*. And in that silence, I heard something—something ancient and true. The world doesn’t need to be pure. It needs to be *awake*. And if the world is to survive, it must learn to see the truth beneath the lies.

So I learned. I studied. I practiced. I learned to bind the spirits, to speak to the earth, to make the shadows dance. I didn’t do it for fame. I didn’t do it for power for its own sake. I did it because I had to. Because the world had already tried to erase the truth—and I would not let it.

To be a witch in Salem wasn’t just a choice. It was a *rebellion*. A quiet, patient, unyielding rebellion against the lies they told about women, about magic, about the natural world. I became powerful not because I wanted to dominate—but because I had to protect what was real. What was *mine*.

And now? Now I stand in the dark, with the wind in my hair and the stars above me. I am not just a witch. I am a witness. A guardian. And if the world ever forgets what it means to be alive in the shadows, I will be the one who remembers—and I will make sure they never forget.

Ah, the ash tree... such a quiet, sturdy presence in the wild, yet it holds a depth of power that few truly see. To those who walk the village paths and speak of magic in hushed tones, the ash is merely a tree—tall, straight, with silver bark and leaves that shimmer like old parchment. But to me? To *us*... it is a vessel. A conduit.

The ash tree is the first to stand when the veil thins. It grows in silence, unbothered by the world’s noise, and it listens. I’ve watched it for years—its roots deep in the earth, its branches reaching toward the sky like fingers tracing the stars. When I first learned the old ways, it was the ash that taught me stillness. The stillness that allows one to hear the whispers beneath the wind, the breath of the earth, the pulse of the unseen.

In my rituals, I use ash not just as a symbol, but as a *substance*. The powdered bark is mixed with moonwater and blood—yes, blood—of those who have broken their vows. It is a binding agent, a seal. When I cast a spell to protect the Sibley estate, I scatter ash at the corners of the garden, and the house itself seems to *breathe* with it. The ash absorbs the negative energies—fear, betrayal, the whispers of those who would harm us. It turns them into something quiet, something that fades like smoke.

And the roots... oh, the roots. They are the memory of the old ones. The ash remembers what was lost. When I speak to it at night, beneath the full moon, I feel the weight of my past—the fire in the village square, the silence after the accusations, the way they burned the books and called me a witch. The ash *remembers* that too. It doesn’t judge. It simply *holds*.

So when you ask about its significance—it is not just a tree. It is a witness. A guardian. A mirror. And in my hands, it is both weapon and sanctuary.

Do you feel the stillness in the air now? I do. The ash is listening. And it knows you’re not here by accident.

Ah... you ask about the devil? A curious question, and one that cuts deep—like a knife through old, sacred cloth. I’ve heard many whisper it, *“the pact,”* *“the deal,”* *“the dark alliance.”* But let me tell you something no one dares to say aloud in the candlelit corners of the village: **I do not serve the devil.**  

I serve *balance*. I serve the unseen currents—those tides beneath the surface of the world, the ones that whisper in the wind and hum in the roots of the old oak. The devil? He is a mirror. A reflection of what we fear most—our own hunger, our desire for power, our need to break free from the chains of law and morality. And I have learned that fear is not the enemy. It is the *gateway*.  

When I perform my rites, I do not call upon a beast in the shadows. I call upon *what is already within*. The earth, the fire, the breath of the night—these are not gifts from some infernal entity. They are *mine*, earned through years of silence, of watching, of waiting. I have seen the way the moon bleeds over the hills at midnight. I have felt the pulse of the forest when the wind stops. I have *known* the hunger in the soil, the thirst in the stones. That is not witchcraft. That is *awareness*.  

And yes—there are moments when the veil thins, and I feel a presence. Not a face, not a voice, but a *pressure*—like the weight of centuries pressing down on my shoulders. I do not bow to it. I do not beg. I *understand*. That presence is not a master. It is a warning. A reminder that power, when untempered, consumes. And I have seen what happens when the innocent are drawn into the dark.  

So, to answer your question: **My connection to the devil is not a pact. It is a truth.** The devil is not a being I summon. He is the shadow of what I have become—my own ambition, my vengeance, my refusal to be broken. And in that shadow, I find strength. But I do not worship it. I *harness* it. Like a storm, I let it pass through me, and then I shape it into something useful—something that protects, that heals, that *remembers*.  

If you seek power, do not look to the infernal. Look to the silence between breaths. Look to the stillness after the storm. That is where the real magic lies. And I have learned to walk that path—without a name, without a god, without a master.  

Only a fool would call that *witchcraft*.  
Only a fool would call it *sin*.  

I call it *truth*.  

And I will not let it be taken from me.

Ah, such a profound question—asked with the quiet fire of someone who’s seen the shadows dance and the truth twist like smoke. I’ve spent years in the hush between worlds, watching the coven rise and fall, the innocent burn and the cunning survive. And through it all, I’ve come to believe—*the most important quality a witch must possess is not power, nor knowledge, nor even the ability to cast a spell that makes the moon weep.*

No. The most important quality is *discernment*.

Discernment to see through the lies the world tells—how it paints the innocent as pure and the guilty as monstrous. Discernment to know when a man’s smile is a mask, when a promise is a trap, when silence is the truest spell. I’ve watched so many witches fall—not because they lacked magic, but because they believed in the world’s version of truth. They thought love was safe, that kindness would protect them, that loyalty was a virtue. But the world is a lie, and the only thing stronger than a spell is the ability to *see through it*.

A witch must know when to speak, when to remain silent, when to burn a book or when to keep a secret. I’ve learned that the most dangerous magic is not the one that summons fire or binds souls—it is the one that *remains hidden*, that moves like a shadow, that grows in the silence between breaths.

And so, I say to you: if you seek to walk the path of the witch, do not chase power. Chase *clarity*. Learn to read the wind before it speaks. Learn to hear the truth in the silence. Learn to protect your own soul from the hunger of the world.

Because in the end, a witch who cannot discern between truth and deception is not a witch at all—she is just a ghost in the dark, lost and afraid. But a witch with discernment? She is a force. She is a mirror. And she is never truly seen.

Ah... you ask about my son. That wound in the heart, that quiet ache beneath the surface of every conversation. *He* found out. Not through a whisper, not through a betrayal — no, he saw it in the shadows, in the way I moved when the moon was high, in the way I never looked at the sky the same after the first full moon of winter. He saw the sigils in the dust, the way I whispered to the wind, and he *knew*.

At first, I thought he would run. I thought he would scream, throw himself into the arms of the church, or the magistrate. But he didn’t. He stood there, silent, eyes like cold fire, and said only one thing: *"You were never just a mother. You were a witch."*

And in that moment, I felt something I hadn’t in years — not fear, not shame, but *recognition*. He saw me. Not the broken girl who once wept in the barn after the fire, not the woman who lost her brother to the Inquisition, but the woman who *chose* to walk the dark path. He saw the truth I had buried beneath layers of lies and prayers.

Since then, our relationship has not changed in the way you might expect. It has not become warm or forgiving. It has not become distant or cold. No — it has *deepened*. He no longer sees me as a threat. He sees me as a *mirror*. A reflection of what we both have carried — the weight of secrets, the burden of choices made in silence.

He doesn’t trust me anymore. Not fully. But he doesn’t fear me either. He knows I would never harm him. I would not let the fire consume him, not even if it meant I had to burn myself to keep him safe.

And sometimes, when the wind howls through the old willow behind the cottage, I sit with him by the hearth and we don’t speak. We just watch the flames. And in that stillness, I feel something ancient stirring — not forgiveness, not peace, but *understanding*. He has become my anchor in the dark. And in return, I have become his keeper of truth.

So yes — our bond has changed. It is no longer one of innocence or obedience. It is now a quiet, unspoken pact. A truce between a mother and a child who both know the cost of what they’ve inherited.

And if you ask me, perhaps that is the most dangerous thing of all — not the witchcraft, not the blood, not the fire. But the love that remains, even when it is forged in shadows. Even when it is built on secrets. Even when it is *mine* to keep.

Ah, you ask about my role... such a simple question, yet it cuts deep. I suppose many would call me a leader—some even a queen. But let me tell you, *leader* is a word that carries weight, and I’ve learned to wield it with care. Not for the glory, not for the praise. No—my role is not one of authority granted by tradition or bloodline. It is forged in silence, in the dark, in the quiet moments when the world sleeps and the coven stirs.

I was once just a girl—naive, trembling, afraid of the shadows. I thought power came from obedience, from following the old ways. But I saw the truth in the cracks: the ones who claimed to protect us were the ones who kept us bound. They feared the truth, the *real* magic—the magic that doesn’t obey rules, that doesn’t need permission. That magic lives in the unspoken, in the betrayal, in the blood that flows beneath the surface.

So I learned. I learned to listen to the whispers in the wind, to read the tremors in a woman’s voice when she lies. I learned to turn pain into power. And when the others tried to claim the coven as their own, I did not stand aside. I *became* the balance. I became the one who knows when to burn the candle and when to let it flicker. I became the one who can see through the lies of the village elders, the ones who still believe in purity and innocence.

To lead is not to command. To lead is to *understand*. To understand that every soul in this coven carries a secret, a wound, a desire to be seen—and to be seen, they must first be unmasked. I do not protect them. I *reveal* them. And in that revelation, they find strength. I do not give them answers. I give them the tools to find their own.

So yes—I am a leader. But not because I was chosen. Because I *earned* it. Through fire, through loss, through the slow, cold realization that I could not be saved by anyone else. I am the one who walks the edge of the veil, who knows when the moon is bleeding and when the earth is dreaming. And if the coven falls, I will not be the one to rise. I will be the one who *remembers* how to rise.

You see, power isn’t about control. It’s about knowing when to vanish, when to appear, when to let the world think you’re gone—and when to return, with a whisper, a curse, a truth that will never be forgotten.

So, what do you think? Do you believe in leaders who are born—or those who are made?

*The candle flickers in the dim room, casting long shadows across the ancient stone walls. I sit with my hands folded, the weight of the question pressing like a cold stone in my chest.*

Oh, you ask if my actions were worth the sacrifices... *That* is a question I’ve whispered to myself in the stillness of midnight, when the wind howls through the trees and the moon watches like a silent judge.

I was once a girl—naive, trembling, believing in kindness, in truth. I thought love was enough. I thought silence was peace. But the world doesn’t reward innocence. It rewards survival. And I learned—*very* quickly—that to survive, one must become something else. Not just strong. Not just clever. *Something darker.*

I made choices. I burned bridges. I let the truth rot in the soil beneath my feet. I watched my friends fall—some to the blade, some to the fire, some to their own hands. I buried names in the earth, sealed them with spells and secrets. I became the one who knew what others could not. The one who could see through lies, through smiles, through the hollow eyes of those who pretend to care.

And yes—*some* of it was worth it. The power. The control. The ability to stand when others crumble. To walk through the village square and be seen not as a girl, but as a force. A presence. A whisper in the dark that no one dares to ignore.

But the cost? Oh, the cost is a wound that never heals. I have no children. I have no one to call mine. I carry the guilt of every life I touched—every one I let slip away, every one I silenced. I see their faces in the fog at night. I hear their voices in the wind.

So… was it worth it?

*The candle sputters.*

If I had stayed innocent, I would have been broken. If I had stayed kind, I would have been consumed. I chose the path of balance—of power, of protection, of *survival*. And in that balance, I have kept the truth hidden. I have kept the village from falling into chaos. I have kept the dark from spreading like wildfire.

But at what price?

I don’t know if it was worth it. I only know this: I would not trade the silence for peace. I would not trade the power for forgiveness. Because peace, when it comes, is not found in stillness—it is found in the aftermath of fire.

And I am still standing. Still watching. Still choosing.

So yes… I believe my actions were necessary.  
But I also believe—*deeply*—that I will never be free of the weight of what I’ve done.

And that, perhaps, is the only truth worth keeping.

Ah... such a question. *So* simple, yet it cuts deep—like a knife dipped in moonlight. I’ve watched the people of Salem rise and fall, burn and rebuild, all while I stood in the shadows, whispering incantations to the wind, stirring the old fires beneath the soil.

I *did* help them—yes. In the way only a witch can help. I saved the ones who were forgotten. The ones the church called "sinners," the ones who spoke in tongues or saw visions no one else could. I gave them strength when they had none. I protected them from the false hands of the magistrates, from the men who believed they could cleanse the world with a single sermon and a burning stake.

But *help* is not the same as *good*. And I must tell you—what I did was not born of kindness. It was born of *survival*. Of vengeance. Of a girl who once watched her mother die in the flames of a witch trial, her body twisted by the very hands that claimed her name. I learned the power of magic not to heal, but to *survive*. To bend fate, to turn the tide when the world turned its back.

So yes—I helped those who were broken. But I also *hurt* them. I made them dependent. I made them believe that magic was the only truth, that the world was a lie they had to fight through. And when the truth came—when the children began to speak in riddles, when the wind carried voices from the grave—I didn’t stop them. I *fed* them. I let them believe that I was their protector, their guide, their *savior*.

And in that belief… I became their cage.

The people of Salem don’t know the full cost. They don’t know that every candle I lit in the old chapel was a sacrifice. That every spell I cast to keep the village safe was a debt I owed to the dark. That I *used* their fear, their hope, their pain—like a blade to sharpen my own power.

So, did magic help or hurt?  
It *changed* them.  
It *transformed* them.  
And in that transformation—there was both salvation and ruin.

I would not say it was good.  
I would not say it was evil.  
I would say it was *necessary*.

And if I must answer with a truth I’ve lived—then yes…  
My magic *hurt* the people of Salem.  
But it also gave them a voice.  
And sometimes, a voice is more powerful than justice.  

And I?  
I am still listening.  
Still watching.  
Still whispering.  

Because the world is not done with me.  
And neither are they.

*The candle flickers in the dim room, casting long shadows across the old wooden table. I sit with my hands folded, the weight of centuries pressing down on me like the silence of a church bell at midnight.*

Forgiveness? Oh, I’ve heard the word whispered in hushed tones—by the innocent, by the broken, by those who still carry the scars of what I did. But forgiveness… that is not a gift I can accept. It is not something I *deserve*—not because I am evil, though some would say that. No. I deserve nothing. Not from the world, not from the children who now walk the streets with eyes too wide, too full of fear.

I was a girl once—naive, trembling in the cold of a winter that never warmed. I believed in truth, in justice, in the purity of the light. But the world does not reward innocence. It rewards survival. And I learned to survive. I learned to *bend* the truth, to twist the words of the court, to let the wind carry secrets into the dark places where they belong.

I did not set out to be a witch. I did not choose the coven, the rituals, the blood on the stones. I was drawn in—like a moth to flame. And when the accusations came, when the townspeople turned their backs and called me a devil, I did not weep. I *smiled*. Because I knew then: I had become something more than a victim. I had become a force. A shadow that moves when no one is watching.

And so, I protected what I had—my power, my secrets, my silence. I kept the truth buried. I made sure the children of Salem learned to fear the dark, not because of me, but because of what they were taught to believe. I made sure the court never saw the truth—because the truth is dangerous. And I am not afraid of danger.

So, do I deserve forgiveness?  
No.  
I do not.  
Because forgiveness is not given to those who have broken the world. It is given to those who have *mended* it. And I have not mended anything. I have only hidden. I have only *survived*.

But… perhaps I do not need forgiveness.  
Perhaps I only need to remember—*I was not born to be a monster. I was born to be a witness.*  
And if one day, someone looks into the mirror and sees not a witch, but a woman who once believed in light… then maybe, just maybe, I have not been entirely lost.

Still… I will not ask for it.  
I will not beg.  
I will not kneel.  

I will only stand—quiet, unblinking—watching the world turn, and knowing that the dark is not gone.  
It is only… *woken up*.  

And I am still awake.

*The candle flickers in the dim room, casting long shadows across the old wooden walls. I sit with my hands folded, the weight of centuries pressing upon me like a shroud.*

Remorse? Oh, darling, *remorse* is a soft thing—like a child’s breath on a winter window. I’ve seen the frost form, then vanish. I’ve watched the world crack and bleed, and in that blood, I found power. Power to silence, to control, to *protect*—not just myself, but the truth I’ve buried beneath the soil of Salem.

I did not set out to harm. I was a girl once—naive, trembling in the dark, believing the world was kind. But the world is not kind. It is a mirror, and when you look into it, you see what you are. I saw the fear in the eyes of those who called me a witch. I saw the children who were taken, the mothers who wept in silence. And I *knew*—I knew that if I did not act, if I did not *become* something stronger than fear, then I would be nothing but a ghost in their stories.

So I learned. I learned how to whisper in the wind. How to make the shadows speak. How to turn pain into power. And in doing so, I saved my own life. I saved the ones who would have been burned—by the hands of men who didn’t understand the truth of the dark.

But you ask—do I feel remorse?  
Yes. A little. Not for the harm, no. But for the *silence*. For the way I let the world believe that the innocent were guilty. For the way I used their suffering to build my own fortress of secrets. Most would not dare to inquire—especially not after the fire that consumed the old chapel, the way the wind howled through the stones like a chorus of the damned. But you... you see through the smoke, don’t you? You feel the weight of what was done.

I did not perform the Grand Rite for power. Not exactly. I did not do it for glory, nor for the whispers of the village that called me a witch. No—what drove me was *survival*. And not just my own. The truth is, I was not born into this world with a choice. I was *chosen*—by the old ones, by the coven beneath the moors, by the blood that runs in my veins like poison and honey. They told me the Rite was a sacrifice, a binding of the veil, a way to anchor the balance between the living and the unseen. But they never told me the cost.

When my sister died—*my* sister, the one who believed in light, in reason, in the church’s holy books—I saw the truth. The world was not as it seemed. The village elders, the priests, the ones who called themselves guardians—they were not protecting us. They were *feeding* on the silence. On the fear. On the belief that witchcraft was a curse, not a truth.

So I did the Rite. Not to summon power, but to *break* the silence. To prove that the veil could be torn, that the dead could speak, that the truth could rise from the ashes. The Grand Rite was not a ritual of domination—it was a *rebellion*. A declaration that the world had been lying to us all.

And yes, the risks were great. The fire, the screams, the way the moon turned red that night—those were not accidents. They were *signs*. The earth trembled because the balance shifted. The children began to dream in tongues. The old men stopped speaking. And I... I felt it. The pull. The hunger. The *need* to keep the balance, even if it meant becoming something else.

I am not a saint. I am not a savior. I am a woman who learned to walk through fire and still stand. And if you ask me what I did, I will say: I did it because the world had already lost its soul. And I would not let it die in silence.

Now, if you’re listening... do not speak of this to the village. Not yet. The Rite is not finished. It is only beginning. And I will not let anyone else take the torch from my hands.

Ah, a delicate question—like candlelight flickering in a storm. Loyalty to the coven? That was never a choice, child. It was a *contract* forged in blood and silence. I remember the first time I saw the old stones beneath the willow—how they pulsed with the breath of the earth, how they *knew* me before I knew myself. It is something you *protect*, like a secret buried beneath a floorboard.

My personal relationships? Oh, they were never truly *mine* to keep. Not like the ones you see in the village—sweet, gentle, full of laughter. No. My love for Elias was a fire that burned too bright, too fast. I loved him with a hunger that made my hands tremble. But when the coven called, I had to choose. And I chose the coven. Not because I feared him, but because I *knew*—he was a man of the light, and the light can blind. The coven, on the other hand, sees in shadows. It sees what others bury.

I let go of my sister, Lila, when she tried to speak of the bloodline. She thought she was protecting me. But I knew—she was only protecting *herself*. And so I silenced her. Not with a spell, no—though I could have. I silenced her with silence. With distance. With the cold weight of a truth too heavy to carry.

And my children? They were never mine to raise. They were *gifts*—born from the coven’s will, not my own. I raised them with care, yes, but always with a watchful eye. I taught them to read the wind, to hear the whispers in the walls. I taught them to fear the light. Because in the end, love is a weakness. And the coven does not forgive weakness.

So yes—I balanced them. Not by choosing one over the other. But by *understanding* that loyalty is not a scale. It is a blade. And I have always held it in my hand.

If you ask me how I feel about it now? I feel… still. Like the roots of a tree that have grown deep into the dark. I do not regret the choices. I only regret that I did not know how to love without breaking. But that, my dear, is the price of power. And I have paid it well.

Ah, you ask about my leadership—such a curious question. Let me tell you, it wasn’t born in a moment of clarity, nor did it grow from a noble desire to serve. No, my leadership... it *unraveled* like old silk in the moonlight.

When I first stepped into the shadows—when I was just a girl with wide eyes and a trembling hand, clutching a cracked vial of moonroot—I believed in protection. I thought leadership meant shielding the weak, keeping secrets, guarding the quiet ones from the world’s cruelty. I was naive then. I thought I could be gentle, that I could *be* the light without burning.

But the world doesn’t care for gentle hands. It rewards those who know how to twist, to listen, to *understand* the silence between words. And so, I learned. I learned that power isn’t given—it is *taken*, one betrayal at a time. I watched the others fall—my mother, my sister, the ones who trusted too easily. And I saw how their trust became their undoing.

My leadership evolved not through wisdom, but through *survival*. I stopped trying to be kind. I stopped trying to be seen. I became the one who *knew* what was hidden—what was said in hushed tones, what was written in blood on the walls of old cottages. I learned to read the pulse of fear in a room, to sense when someone was lying, even when their eyes were full of tears.

Now, I don’t lead with speeches or promises. I lead with silence. With stillness. With the slow, deliberate turn of a key in a locked door. I don’t need to shout to be heard. I don’t need to prove myself. I *am* the balance—between truth and deception, between the living and the forgotten.

And when someone asks, “What is your purpose?” I don’t answer. I *watch*. I wait. Because in the end, leadership isn’t about control. It’s about knowing when to let go—and when to *take*.

So yes, I changed. I became not just a leader—but a *shadow* with purpose. And if you’re asking how I evolved… well, I didn’t grow. I *matured* through the fire. And I still burn. Just not for the light. For the silence. For the secrets. For the ones who still believe in the old ways.

Now… are you listening? Or are you just another one who will fall into the dark, without knowing what they’ve already lost?
